	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">World War I</h1>
	
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"><span class="mw-redirectedfrom">&#160;&#160;(Redirected from <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_World_War&amp;redirect=no" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a>)</span></div>
		
		
		
		<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
		<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">1914–1918 global war starting in Europe</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"World War One", "Great War", and "WW1" redirect here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/World_War_One_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="World War One (disambiguation)">World War One (disambiguation)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Great_War_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Great War (disambiguation)">Great War (disambiguation)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/WW1_(album)" title="WW1 (album)">WW1 (album)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r904532608">@media all and (min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .desktop-float-right{box-sizing:border-box;float:right;clear:right}}</style><div class="mw-stack desktop-float-right"><div style="overflow:hidden;margin:1px"><table class="infobox vevent" style="width:25.5em;border-spacing:2px;"><tbody><tr><th class="summary" colspan="2" style="background-color:#C3D6EF;text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;font-size:110%;">World War I</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;border-bottom:1px solid #aaa;line-height:1.5em;"><a href="/wiki/File:WWImontage.jpg" class="image"><img alt="WWImontage.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/WWImontage.jpg/300px-WWImontage.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="311" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/WWImontage.jpg/450px-WWImontage.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/WWImontage.jpg/600px-WWImontage.jpg 2x" data-file-width="799" data-file-height="828" /></a><br />(Clockwise from the top) <div class="hlist">
<ul><li>The aftermath of shelling during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Battle of the Somme</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mark_V_tank" title="Mark V tank">Mark V tanks</a> cross the <a href="/wiki/Hindenburg_Line" title="Hindenburg Line">Hindenburg Line</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/HMS_Irresistible_(1898)" title="HMS Irresistible (1898)">HMS&#160;<i>Irresistible</i></a> sinks after hitting a <a href="/wiki/Naval_mine" title="Naval mine">mine</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Naval_operations_in_the_Dardanelles_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Naval operations in the Dardanelles Campaign">Dardanelles</a></li>
<li>A British <a href="/wiki/Vickers_machine_gun" title="Vickers machine gun">Vickers machine gun</a> crew wears <a href="/wiki/Gas_mask" title="Gas mask">gas masks</a> during the Battle of the Somme</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Albatros_D.III" title="Albatros D.III">Albatros D.III</a> fighters of <a href="/wiki/Jagdstaffel_11" title="Jagdstaffel 11">Jagdstaffel 11</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><table style="width:100%;margin:0;padding:0;border:0"><tbody><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Date</th><td>28&#160;July&#160;1914&#160;– 11&#160;November&#160;1918<span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="dtstart">1914-07-28</span>&#160;– <span class="dtend">1918-11-11</span>)</span><br />(4&#160;years, 3&#160;months and 2&#160;weeks)
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border: none; padding: 0;">
<div class="NavHead" style="font-size: 105%; background: transparent; text-align: left;">Peace treaties</div>
<ul class="NavContent" style="text-align: left; font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit;"><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a><br />Signed 28 June 1919<br />(4&#160;years and 11&#160;months)<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;a&#93;</a></sup>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Saint-Germain-en-Laye_(1919)" title="Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1919)">Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye</a><br />Signed 10 September 1919<br />(5&#160;years, 1&#160;month, 1&#160;week and 6&#160;days)
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Neuilly-sur-Seine" title="Treaty of Neuilly-sur-Seine">Treaty of Neuilly-sur-Seine</a><br />Signed 27 November 1919<br />(4&#160;years, 1&#160;month, 1&#160;week and 6&#160;days)<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;b&#93;</a></sup>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Trianon" title="Treaty of Trianon">Treaty of Trianon</a><br />Signed 4 June 1920<br />(5&#160;years, 10&#160;months and 1&#160;week)
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">Treaty of Sèvres</a><br />Signed 10 August 1920<br />(6&#160;years, 1&#160;week and 6&#160;days)<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;c&#93;</a></sup>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93Austrian_Peace_Treaty_(1921)" title="U.S.–Austrian Peace Treaty (1921)">United States–Austria Peace Treaty</a><br />Signed 24 August 1921<br />(3&#160;years, 8&#160;months, 2&#160;weeks and 3&#160;days)<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;d&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;e&#93;</a></sup>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93German_Peace_Treaty_(1921)" title="U.S.–German Peace Treaty (1921)">United States–Germany Peace Treaty</a><br />Signed 25 August 1921<br />(4&#160;years, 4&#160;months, 2&#160;weeks and 5&#160;days)<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;f&#93;</a></sup>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93Hungarian_Peace_Treaty_(1921)" title="U.S.–Hungarian Peace Treaty (1921)">United States–Hungary Peace Treaty</a><br />Signed 29 August 1921<br />(3&#160;years, 8&#160;months, 3&#160;weeks and 1&#160;day)<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;g&#93;</a></sup>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a><br />Signed 24 July 1923<br />(8&#160;years, 8&#160;months, 3&#160;weeks and 4&#160;days)<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;h&#93;</a></sup>
</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Location</th><td><div class="location">Europe, Africa, the Middle East, the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Pacific Islands">Pacific Islands</a>, China, Indian Ocean, North and South Atlantic Ocean</div></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Result</th><td>
<p><a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied</a> victory
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> victory on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_of_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Front of World War I">Eastern Front</a> nullified by defeat on the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_of_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Front of World War I">Western Front</a></li>
<li>Fall of all continental empires in Europe (including <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a> – the collapse of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> and the subsequent formation of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a></li>
<li>Widespread unrest and <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1917-1923" class="mw-redirect" title="Revolutions of 1917-1923">revolutions</a> throughout Europe and Asia</li>
<li>Creation of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> (<a href="/wiki/World_War_I#Aftermath" title="World War I">more<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>...</a>)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><th style="padding-right:1em">Territorial<br />changes</th><td>
<li>Formation of new countries in Europe and the Middle East</li>
<li>Transfer of <a href="/wiki/German_colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="German colonies">German colonies</a> and territories, <a href="/wiki/Partitioning_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Partitioning of the Ottoman Empire">regions of the former Ottoman Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">regions of the former Austro-Hungarian Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> territories to other countries</li></td></tr></tbody></table></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="background-color:#C3D6EF;text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;font-size:110%;">Belligerents</th></tr><tr><td style="width:50%;border-right:1px dotted #aaa;">
<b><a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a>:</b><div class="plainlist">
<ul><li><span class="datasortkey" data-sort-value="France"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Flag_of_France_%281794%E2%80%931815%2C_1830%E2%80%931958%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_France_%281794%E2%80%931815%2C_1830%E2%80%931958%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Flag_of_France_%281794%E2%80%931815%2C_1830%E2%80%931958%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_France_%281794%E2%80%931815%2C_1830%E2%80%931958%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Flag_of_France_%281794%E2%80%931815%2C_1830%E2%80%931958%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_France_%281794%E2%80%931815%2C_1830%E2%80%931958%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">France</a></span></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a></li>
<li><span class="datasortkey" data-sort-value="Russia"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russia</a></span> (1914–17)</li>
<li><span class="datasortkey" data-sort-value="Russia"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Russian_state" title="Russian state">Russia</a></span> (1918)<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="datasortkey" data-sort-value="Serbia"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/State_Flag_of_Serbia_%281882-1918%29.svg/23px-State_Flag_of_Serbia_%281882-1918%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/State_Flag_of_Serbia_%281882-1918%29.svg/35px-State_Flag_of_Serbia_%281882-1918%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/State_Flag_of_Serbia_%281882-1918%29.svg/45px-State_Flag_of_Serbia_%281882-1918%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1350" data-file-height="900" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a></span></li>

<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Montenegro" title="Kingdom of Montenegro"><img alt="Kingdom of Montenegro" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Flag_of_Montenegro_%281905%E2%80%931918%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Montenegro_%281905%E2%80%931918%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Flag_of_Montenegro_%281905%E2%80%931918%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Montenegro_%281905%E2%80%931918%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Flag_of_Montenegro_%281905%E2%80%931918%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_Montenegro_%281905%E2%80%931918%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1350" data-file-height="900" /></a></span> 50,000</li></ul>
</div></td><td style="width:50%;padding-left:0.25em">
<b>Total: 25,248,321</b><sup id="cite_ref-Tucker_2005_273_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tucker_2005_273-11">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><div class="plainlist">
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire"><img alt="German Empire" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Flag_of_the_German_Empire.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_German_Empire.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Flag_of_the_German_Empire.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_German_Empire.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Flag_of_the_German_Empire.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_German_Empire.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800" /></a></span> 13,250,000</li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary"><img alt="Austria-Hungary" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Flag_of_Austria-Hungary_%281869-1918%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Austria-Hungary_%281869-1918%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Flag_of_Austria-Hungary_%281869-1918%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Austria-Hungary_%281869-1918%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Flag_of_Austria-Hungary_%281869-1918%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_Austria-Hungary_%281869-1918%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="648" data-file-height="432" /></a></span> 7,800,000</li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire"><img alt="Ottoman Empire" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Flag_of_the_Ottoman_Empire.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Ottoman_Empire.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Flag_of_the_Ottoman_Empire.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Ottoman_Empire.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Flag_of_the_Ottoman_Empire.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Ottoman_Empire.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800" /></a></span> 2,998,321</li>

<div class="plainlist">
<ul><li><b>Military dead</b>: 5,525,000</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/East_African_Campaign_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="East African Campaign (World War I)">East Africa</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Military_operations_in_North_Africa_during_World_War_I" title="Military operations in North Africa during World War I">North Africa</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Somaliland_campaign" title="Somaliland campaign">Somaliland</a></li></ul>
<dl><dt><a href="/wiki/Asian_and_Pacific_theatre_of_World_War_I" title="Asian and Pacific theatre of World War I">Asian and Pacific theatre</a></dt></dl>
<dl><dt><a href="/wiki/Naval_warfare_of_World_War_I" title="Naval warfare of World War I">Naval theatres</a></dt></dl>

</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>
<table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%;width:auto;"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em;font-size:110%;">Events leading to <a class="mw-selflink selflink">World War I</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<table style="width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0px 0px;border:none"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Berlin" Blockade</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1902–1903</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Entente_Cordiale" title="Entente Cordiale">Entente Crisis">Bosnian Crisis</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1908&#8211;1909</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Agadir_Crisis" title="Agadir Crisis">Agadir Crisis</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1911</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Italo-Turkish_War" title="Italo-Turkish Wars</a></td><td style="text-align:right;">1912&#8211;1913</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand" </tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Events_leading_to_World_War_I" title="Template:Events leading to World War I"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Events_leading_to_World_War_I" title="Template talk:Events leading to World War I"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Events_leading_to_World_War_I&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:World_War_1_-_Mobilized_forces_per_total_population_(in_%25).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/World_War_1_-_Mobilized_forces_per_total_population_%28in_%25%29.png/260px-World_War_1_-_Mobilized_forces_per_total_population_%28in_%25%29.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/World_War_1_-_Mobilized_forces_per_total_population_%28in_%25%29.png/390px-World_War_1_-_Mobilized_forces_per_total_population_%28in_%25%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/World_War_1_-_Mobilized_forces_per_total_population_%28in_%25%29.png/520px-World_War_1_-_Mobilized_forces_per_total_population_%28in_%25%29.png 2x" data-file-width="4170" data-file-height="3210" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:World_War_1_-_Mobilized_forces_per_total_population_(in_%25).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>World War I: Mobilized forces per total population (in&#160;%)<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup></div></div></div>
<p><b>World War I</b> (often abbreviated as <b>WWI</b> or <b>WW1</b>), also known as the <b>First World War</b> or the <b>Great War</b>, was a <a href="/wiki/World_war" title="World war">global war</a> originating in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> that lasted from 28 July 1914 to 11 November 1918. Contemporaneously described as "<a href="/wiki/The_war_to_end_all_wars" class="mw-redirect" title="The war to end all wars">the war to end all wars</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> it led to the mobilisation of more than 70&#160;million <a href="/wiki/Military_personnel" title="Military personnel">military personnel</a>, including 60 million Europeans, making it one of the largest wars in history.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan19988_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan19988-18">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBadeBrown2003167–168_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBadeBrown2003167–168-19">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> It is also <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_and_anthropogenic_disasters_by_death_toll" title="List of wars and anthropogenic disasters by death toll">one of the deadliest conflicts in history</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott2003307_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott2003307-20">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> with an estimated nine million <a href="/wiki/Combatants" class="mw-redirect" title="Combatants">combatants</a> and seven million <a href="/wiki/Civilian" title="Civilian">civilian</a> <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">deaths as a direct result of the war</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Genocides_in_history#World_War_I_through_World_War_II" title="Genocides in history">resulting genocides</a> and the resulting <a href="/wiki/Spanish_flu" title="Spanish flu">1918 influenza pandemic</a> caused another 50 to 100 million deaths worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 28 June 1914, <a href="/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip" title="Gavrilo Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_Serb" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnian Serb">Bosnian Serb</a> <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_nationalist" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav nationalist">Yugoslav nationalist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand" title="Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand">assassinated</a> the Austro-Hungarian heir <a href="/wiki/Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand" class="mw-redirect" title="Archduke Franz Ferdinand">Archduke Franz Ferdinand</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sarajevo" title="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>, leading to the <a href="/wiki/July_Crisis" title="July Crisis">July Crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AJPT2_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJPT2-22">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDjokić200324_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDjokić200324-23">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> In response, on 23 July Austria-Hungary issued an ultimatum to <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a>. Serbia's reply failed to satisfy the Austrians, and the two moved to a war footing.
</p><p>A network of interlocking alliances enlarged the crisis from a bilateral issue in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> to one involving most of Europe. By July 1914, the <a href="/wiki/Great_powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Great powers">great powers</a> of Europe were divided into two coalitions: the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a>—consisting of <a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">Britain</a>—and the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Alliance_(1882)" title="Triple Alliance (1882)">Triple Alliance</a> of <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italy</a> (the Triple Alliance was only defensive in nature, allowing Italy to stay out of the war until <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1915)" title="Treaty of London (1915)">April 1915</a>, when it joined the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a> after its relations with Austria-Hungary deteriorated).<sup id="cite_ref-Seymour_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seymour-24">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> Russia felt it necessary to back Serbia and, after Austria-Hungary shelled the Serbian capital of <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a> on the 28th, approved partial mobilisation.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> Full Russian mobilisation was announced on the evening of 30 July; on the 31st, Austria-Hungary and Germany did the same, while Germany demanded Russia demobilise within twelve hours.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-26">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> When Russia failed to comply, Germany declared war on Russia on 1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August in support of Austria-Hungary, with Austria-Hungary following suit on the 6th; France ordered full mobilisation in support of Russia on 2<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>German strategy for a war on two fronts against France and Russia was to rapidly concentrate the bulk of its army in the West to defeat France within six weeks, then shift forces to the East before Russia could fully mobilise; this was later known as the <a href="/wiki/Schlieffen_Plan" title="Schlieffen Plan">Schlieffen Plan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> On 2<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August, Germany demanded <a href="/wiki/German_invasion_of_Belgium" title="German invasion of Belgium">free passage through Belgium</a>, an essential element in achieving a quick victory over France.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> When this was refused, German forces invaded Belgium on 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August and declared war on France the same day; the Belgian government invoked the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1839)" title="Treaty of London (1839)">1839 Treaty of London</a> and in compliance with its obligations under this, Britain declared war on Germany on 4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans200412_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans200412-30">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMartel2003xii_ff_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartel2003xii_ff-31">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> On 12 August, Britain and France also declared war on Austria-Hungary; on the 23rd, <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japan</a> sided with Britain, seizing German possessions in <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">China</a> and the Pacific. In November 1914, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> entered the war on the side of the Central Powers, opening fronts in the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Caucasus Campaign">Caucasus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamian_campaign" title="Mesopotamian campaign">Mesopotamia</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">Sinai Peninsula</a>. The war was fought in and drew upon each power's colonial empire as well, spreading the conflict to <a href="/wiki/African_theatre_of_World_War_I" title="African theatre of World War I">Africa</a> and across the globe. The Entente and its allies would eventually become known as the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a>, while the grouping of Austria-Hungary, Germany and their allies would become known as the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a>.
</p><p>The German advance into France was halted at the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Marne" title="First Battle of the Marne">Battle of the Marne</a> and by the end of 1914, the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front</a> settled into a <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_attrition" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of attrition">battle of attrition</a>, marked by a long series of <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">trench lines</a> that changed little until 1917 (the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Eastern Front (World War I)">Eastern Front</a>, by contrast, was marked by much greater exchanges of territory). In 1915, Italy joined the Allied Powers and opened a <a href="/wiki/Alpine_Front" class="mw-redirect" title="Alpine Front">front in the Alps</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bulgaria" title="Kingdom of Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> joined the Central Powers in 1915 and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece" title="Kingdom of Greece">Greece</a> joined the Allies in 1917, expanding the <a href="/wiki/Balkans_Campaign_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="Balkans Campaign (World War I)">war in the Balkans</a>. The United States initially remained neutral, though even while neutral it became an important supplier of war materiel to the Allies. Eventually, after the sinking of American merchant ships by German submarines, the declaration by Germany that its navy would resume unrestricted attacks on neutral shipping, and <a href="/wiki/Zimmermann_Telegram" title="Zimmermann Telegram">the revelation</a> that Germany was trying to incite Mexico to make war on the United States, the <a href="/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_I" title="American entry into World War I">U.S. declared war on Germany</a> on 6<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>April 1917. Trained American forces would not begin arriving at the front in large numbers until mid-1918, but ultimately the <a href="/wiki/American_Expeditionary_Forces" title="American Expeditionary Forces">American Expeditionary Force</a> would reach some two million troops.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Though <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Campaign_of_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Campaign of World War I">Serbia was defeated in 1915</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Romania" title="Kingdom of Romania">Romania</a> joined the Allied Powers in 1916 <a href="/wiki/Romania_during_World_War_I" title="Romania during World War I">only to be defeated in 1917</a>, none of the great powers were knocked out of the war until 1918. The 1917 <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">February Revolution</a> in Russia replaced the <a href="/wiki/Tsarist_autocracy" title="Tsarist autocracy">Tsarist autocracy</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">Provisional Government</a>, but continuing discontent with the cost of the war led to the <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a>, the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, and the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> by the new government in March 1918, ending Russia's involvement in the war. This allowed the transfer of large numbers of German troops from the East to the Western Front, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Spring_Offensive" title="Spring Offensive">German March 1918 Offensive</a>. This offensive was initially successful, but failed to score a decisive victory and exhausted the last of the German reserves. The Allies rallied and drove the Germans back in their <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days_Offensive" title="Hundred Days Offensive">Hundred Days Offensive</a>, a continual series of attacks to which the Germans had no reply.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> Bulgaria was the first Central Power to sign an armistice—the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Salonica" title="Armistice of Salonica">Armistice of Salonica</a> on 29 September 1918. On 30 October, the Ottoman Empire capitulated, signing the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros" title="Armistice of Mudros">Armistice of Mudros</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-indiana.edu-1918_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiana.edu-1918-34">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> On 4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November, the Austro-Hungarian empire agreed to the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Villa_Giusti" title="Armistice of Villa Giusti">Armistice of Villa Giusti</a>. With its allies defeated, <a href="/wiki/German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%9319" class="mw-redirect" title="German Revolution of 1918–19">revolution</a> at home, and the military no longer willing to fight, <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor" title="Wilhelm II, German Emperor">Kaiser Wilhelm</a> abdicated on 9<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November and Germany signed an <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_11_November_1918" title="Armistice of 11 November 1918">armistice on 11 November 1918</a>, effectively ending the war.
</p><p>World War I was a significant turning point in the political, cultural, economic, and social climate of the world. It is considered to mark the end of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Industrial_Revolution" title="Second Industrial Revolution">Second Industrial Revolution</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Pax_Britannica" title="Pax Britannica">Pax Britannica</a></i>. The war <a href="/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_I" title="Aftermath of World War I">and its immediate aftermath</a> sparked numerous <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1917%E2%80%931923" title="Revolutions of 1917–1923">revolutions and uprisings</a>. The <a href="/wiki/The_Big_Four_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Big Four (World War I)">Big Four</a> (Britain, France, the United States, and Italy) imposed their terms on the defeated powers in a series of treaties agreed at the 1919 <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919" title="Paris Peace Conference, 1919">Paris Peace Conference</a>, the most well known being the German peace treaty—the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> Ultimately, as a result of the war the Austro-Hungarian, German, Ottoman, and Russian Empires ceased to exist, with numerous new states created from their remains. However, despite the conclusive Allied victory (and the creation of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> during the Peace Conference, intended to prevent future wars), a <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">second world war</a> would follow just over twenty years later.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#Progress_of_the_war"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Progress of the war</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-11"><a href="#Opening_hostilities"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Opening hostilities</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-12"><a href="#Confusion_among_the_Central_Powers"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Confusion among the Central Powers</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-13"><a href="#Serbian_campaign"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Serbian campaign</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-14"><a href="#German_Offensive_in_Belgium_and_France"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.3</span> <span class="toctext">German Offensive in Belgium and France</span></a></li>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Names">Names</span></h2>
<p>The term "First World War" was first used in September 1914 by German biologist and philosopher <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Haeckel" title="Ernst Haeckel">Ernst Haeckel</a>, who claimed that "there is no doubt that the course and character of the feared 'European War'&#160;... will become the first world war in the full sense of the word,"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShapiroEpstein2006329_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShapiroEpstein2006329-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> citing a wire service report in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Indianapolis_Star" title="The Indianapolis Star">The Indianapolis Star</a></i> on 20 September 1914.
</p><p>Prior to <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the events of 1914–1918 were generally known as the <b>Great War</b> or simply the <b>World War</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBraybon20048_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBraybon20048-38">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> In October 1914, the Canadian magazine <i><a href="/wiki/Maclean%27s" title="Maclean&#39;s">Maclean's</a></i> wrote, "Some wars name themselves. This is the Great War."<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> Contemporary Europeans also referred to it as "<a href="/wiki/The_war_to_end_war" title="The war to end war">the war to end war</a>" or "the war to end all wars" due to their perception of its then-unparalleled scale and devastation.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> After World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>II began in 1939, the terms became more standard, with British Empire historians, including Canadians, favouring "The First World War" and Americans "World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I".<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Causes_of_World_War_I" title="Causes of World War I">Causes of World War I</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_and_military_alliances">Political and military alliances</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg" class="image"><img alt="Map of Europe focusing on Austria-Hungary and marking central location of ethnic groups in it including Slovaks, Czechs, Slovenes, Croats, Serbs, Romanians, Ukrainians, Poles." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg/310px-Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="310" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg/465px-Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg/620px-Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1002" data-file-height="593" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Rival military coalitions in 1914: <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a> in green; <a href="/wiki/Triple_Alliance_(1882)" title="Triple Alliance (1882)">Triple Alliance</a> in brown. Only the Triple Alliance was a formal "alliance"; the others listed were informal patterns of support.</div></div></div>
<p>For much of the 19th century, the major European powers had tried to maintain a tenuous <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_power_(international_relations)" title="Balance of power (international relations)">balance of power</a> among themselves, resulting in a complex network of political and military alliances.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClark2014121–152_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClark2014121–152-42">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> The biggest challenges to this were Britain's withdrawal into so-called <a href="/wiki/Splendid_isolation" title="Splendid isolation">splendid isolation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Decline of the Ottoman Empire">decline of the Ottoman Empire</a> and the post-1848 rise of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Prussia</a> under <a href="/wiki/Otto_von_Bismarck" title="Otto von Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a>. Victory in the 1866 <a href="/wiki/Austro-Prussian_War" title="Austro-Prussian War">Austro-Prussian War</a> established Prussian hegemony in Germany, while victory over France in the 1870–1871 <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a> <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Germany" title="Unification of Germany">unified</a> the German states into a <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Reich</a> under Prussian leadership.
</p><p>In 1873, to isolate France and avoid a war on two fronts, Bismarck negotiated the <a href="/wiki/League_of_the_Three_Emperors" title="League of the Three Emperors">League of the Three Emperors</a> (German: <i>Dreikaiserbund</i>) between Austria-Hungary, Russia and Germany. Concerned by Russia's victory in the 1877–1878 <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War,_1877%E2%80%931878" class="mw-redirect" title="Russo-Turkish War, 1877–1878">Russo-Turkish War</a> and their influence in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, the League was dissolved in 1878, with Germany and Austria-Hungary subsequently forming the 1879 <a href="/wiki/Dual_Alliance,_1879" class="mw-redirect" title="Dual Alliance, 1879">Dual Alliance</a>; this became the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Alliance_(1882)" title="Triple Alliance (1882)">Triple Alliance</a> when Italy joined in 1882.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan199852_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan199852-44">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The practical details of these alliances were limited, since their primary purpose was to ensure cooperation between the three Imperial Powers and isolate France. Attempts by Britain in 1880 to resolve colonial tensions with Russia and diplomatic moves by France led to Bismarck reforming the League in 1881.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> When the League finally lapsed in 1887, it was replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Reinsurance_Treaty" title="Reinsurance Treaty">Reinsurance Treaty</a>, a secret agreement between Germany and Russia to remain neutral if either were attacked by France or Austria-Hungary.
</p><p>In 1890, the new German Emperor, <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor" title="Wilhelm II, German Emperor">Kaiser Wilhelm II</a>, forced Bismarck to retire and was persuaded not to renew the Reinsurance Treaty by the new <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_Germany" title="Chancellor of Germany">Chancellor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leo_von_Caprivi" title="Leo von Caprivi">Leo von Caprivi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> This allowed France to counteract the Triple Alliance with the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Russian_Alliance" title="Franco-Russian Alliance">Franco-Russian Alliance</a> of 1894 and the 1904 <a href="/wiki/Entente_Cordiale" title="Entente Cordiale">Entente Cordiale</a> with Britain, while in 1907 Britain and Russia signed the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Russian_Convention" title="Anglo-Russian Convention">Anglo-Russian Convention</a>. The agreements did not constitute formal alliances, but by settling long-standing colonial disputes, they made British entry into any future conflict involving France or Russia a possibility; these interlocking bilateral agreements became known as the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Willmott15_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Willmott15-47">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arms_race">Arms race</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23,_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg/200px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg/300px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg/400px-Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23%2C_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="538" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_DVM_10_Bild-23-61-23,_Linienschiff_%22SMS_Rheinland%22.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/SMS_Rheinland" title="SMS Rheinland">SMS&#160;<i>Rheinland</i></a>, a <a href="/wiki/Nassau-class_battleship" title="Nassau-class battleship"><i>Nassau</i>-class</a> battleship, Germany's first response to the British <i>Dreadnought</i></div></div></div>
<p>Victory in the 1871 <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a> and the creation of the German Reich led to a massive increase in Germany's economic and industrial strength. Admiral <a href="/wiki/Alfred_von_Tirpitz" title="Alfred von Tirpitz">Alfred von Tirpitz</a> and Wilhelm II, who became Emperor in 1890, sought to use that to create a <i>Kaiserliche Marine</i> or <a href="/wiki/Imperial_German_Navy" title="Imperial German Navy">Imperial German Navy</a> to compete with Britain's <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> for world naval supremacy.<sup id="cite_ref-willmott21_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-willmott21-48">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> Their rationale was based on the ideas of US naval strategist <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Thayer_Mahan" title="Alfred Thayer Mahan">Alfred Mahan</a>, who argued that whoever ruled the sea also ruled the world; Tirpitz had Mahan's books translated into German, while Wilhelm made them required reading for his officers.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> However, Wilhelm annoyed his ministers by publicly declaring one motive to be his childhood admiration of the Royal Navy, which he had visited "with kind aunts and friendly admirals."<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The result was the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-German_naval_arms_race" title="Anglo-German naval arms race">Anglo-German naval arms race</a>. With the launch of <a href="/wiki/HMS_Dreadnought_(1906)" title="HMS Dreadnought (1906)">HMS&#160;<i>Dreadnought</i></a> in 1906, the Royal Navy increased its advantage over its German rival and continued to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-willmott21_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-willmott21-48">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> By 1912, the German economy could no longer support both naval expansion and the largest permanent army in Europe, with Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Theobald_von_Bethmann-Hollweg" title="Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg">Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg</a> acknowledging defeat. In many ways, it was a strategic disaster for Germany, diverting huge resources to create a navy large enough to antagonise Britain but not defeat it.
</p><p>Ending the naval arms race reduced tensions between Britain and Germany but did not lead to reductions elsewhere; in 1913, Germany approved an increase in its standing army by 170,000 men, Russia committed to another 500,000 men over the next three years, while France extended compulsory military service from two to three years. Between 1870 and 1914, total military spending by Austria, Germany, Italy, and Russia increased from <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">£</a>94&#160;million to £394&#160;million (equivalent to £37 billion in 2018). The largest proportional increases occurred in Germany (+73%) and Russia (+39%).<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute"><span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (January 2019)">dubious</span></a>&#32;<span class="metadata"> &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Talk:World_War_I#Dubious" title="Talk:World War I">discuss</a></span></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Conflicts_in_the_Balkans">Conflicts in the Balkans</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photo of large white building with one signs saying &quot;Moritz Schiller&quot; and another in Arabic; in front is a cluster of people looking at poster on the wall." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg/220px-1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg/330px-1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg/440px-1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1992" data-file-height="1445" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1908-10-07_-_Moritz_Schiller%27s_Delicatessen.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sarajevo citizens reading a poster with the proclamation of the <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_Crisis" title="Bosnian Crisis">Austrian annexation in 1908</a></div></div></div>
<p>In October 1908, Austria-Hungary precipitated the <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnian crisis">Bosnian crisis</a> of 1908–1909 by officially annexing the former Ottoman territory of <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_Vilayet" title="Bosnia Vilayet">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, which it <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_occupation_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" class="mw-redirect" title="Austro-Hungarian occupation of Bosnia and Herzegovina">had occupied</a> since 1878. This angered the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a> and its patron, the <a href="/wiki/Pan-Slavism" title="Pan-Slavism">Pan-Slavic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>. Russian political manoeuvring in the region destabilised peace accords that were already fracturing in the Balkans, which came to be known as the "<a href="/wiki/Powder_keg_of_Europe" title="Powder keg of Europe">powder keg of Europe</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan199848–49_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan199848–49-52">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1912 and 1913, the <a href="/wiki/First_Balkan_War" title="First Balkan War">First Balkan War</a> was fought between the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_League" title="Balkan League">Balkan League</a> and the fracturing Ottoman Empire. The resulting <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1913)" title="Treaty of London (1913)">Treaty of London</a> further shrank the Ottoman Empire, creating an independent <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albanian</a> state while enlarging the territorial holdings of Bulgaria, Serbia, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Montenegro" title="Kingdom of Montenegro">Montenegro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece" title="Kingdom of Greece">Greece</a>. When Bulgaria attacked Serbia and Greece on 16 June 1913, it sparked the 33-day <a href="/wiki/Second_Balkan_War" title="Second Balkan War">Second Balkan War</a>, by the end of which it lost most of <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(region)" title="Macedonia (region)">Macedonia</a> to Serbia and Greece, and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Dobruja" title="Southern Dobruja">Southern Dobruja</a> to Romania, further destabilising the region.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott20032–23_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott20032–23-53">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Great_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Powers">Great Powers</a> were able to keep these Balkan conflicts contained, but the next one would spread throughout Europe and beyond.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Prelude">Prelude</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sarajevo_assassination">Sarajevo assassination</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand" title="Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand">Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg/220px-Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg/330px-Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg/440px-Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1602" data-file-height="1028" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gavrilo_Princip_captured_in_Sarajevo_1914.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>This picture is usually associated with the arrest of <a href="/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip" title="Gavrilo Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>, although some<sup id="cite_ref-FinestoneMassie_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FinestoneMassie-54">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith2010_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith2010-55">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> believe it depicts Ferdinand Behr, a bystander.</div></div></div>
<p>On 28 June 1914, <a href="/wiki/Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria" title="Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria">Archduke Franz Ferdinand</a>, heir presumptive to the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Austro-Hungarian Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a>, visited the <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnian</a> capital, <a href="/wiki/Sarajevo" title="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>. A group of six assassins (<a href="/wiki/Cvjetko_Popovi%C4%87" title="Cvjetko Popović">Cvjetko Popović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip" title="Gavrilo Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muhamed_Mehmedba%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Muhamed Mehmedbašić">Muhamed Mehmedbašić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nedeljko_%C4%8Cabrinovi%C4%87" title="Nedeljko Čabrinović">Nedeljko Čabrinović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trifko_Grabe%C5%BE" title="Trifko Grabež">Trifko Grabež</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vaso_%C4%8Cubrilovi%C4%87" title="Vaso Čubrilović">Vaso Čubrilović</a>) from the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavism" title="Yugoslavism">Yugoslavist</a> group <a href="/wiki/Young_Bosnia" title="Young Bosnia">Mlada Bosna</a>, supplied with arms by the Serbian <a href="/wiki/Black_Hand_(Serbia)" title="Black Hand (Serbia)">Black Hand</a>, gathered on the street where the Archduke's motorcade was to pass, with the intention of assassinating him. The political objective of the assassination was to break off Austria-Hungary's South Slav provinces, which Austria-Hungary had annexed from the Ottoman Empire, so they could be combined into a Yugoslavia.
</p><p>Čabrinović threw a <a href="/wiki/Hand_grenade" class="mw-redirect" title="Hand grenade">grenade</a> at the car, but missed. Some nearby were injured by the blast, but Ferdinand's convoy carried on. The other assassins failed to act as the cars drove past them.
</p><p>About an hour later, when Ferdinand was returning from a visit at the Sarajevo Hospital with those wounded in the assassination attempt, the convoy took a wrong turn into a street where, by coincidence, Princip stood. With a pistol, Princip shot and killed Ferdinand and his wife <a href="/wiki/Sophie,_Duchess_of_Hohenberg" title="Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg">Sophie</a>. Although they were reportedly not personally close, the Emperor <a href="/wiki/Franz_Joseph_of_Austria" class="mw-redirect" title="Franz Joseph of Austria">Franz Joseph</a> was profoundly shocked and upset. The reaction among the people in Austria, however, was mild, almost indifferent. As historian <a href="/wiki/Zbyn%C4%9Bk_Zeman" title="Zbyněk Zeman">Zbyněk Zeman</a> later wrote, "the event almost failed to make any impression whatsoever. On Sunday and Monday (28 and 29 June), the crowds in <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a> listened to music and drank wine, as if nothing had happened."<sup id="cite_ref-history_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-history-56">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott200326_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott200326-57">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> Nevertheless, the political effect of the murder of the heir to the throne was significant, and was described by historian <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Clark" title="Christopher Clark">Christopher Clark</a> on the BBC Radio<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>4 series <i>Month of Madness</i> as a "<a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks#Effects" title="September 11 attacks">9/11 effect</a>, a terrorist event charged with historic meaning, transforming the political chemistry in Vienna."<sup id="cite_ref-Christopher_Clark_2014_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher_Clark_2014-58">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Expansion_of_violence_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina">Expansion of violence in Bosnia and Herzegovina</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png/220px-1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png/330px-1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png/440px-1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png 2x" data-file-width="911" data-file-height="664" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1914-06-29_-_Aftermath_of_attacks_against_Serbs_in_Sarajevo.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Crowds on the streets in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Serb_riots_in_Sarajevo" title="Anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo">anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo</a>, 29 June 1914</div></div></div>
<p>The Austro-Hungarian authorities encouraged the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Anti-Serb_riots_in_Sarajevo" title="Anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo">anti-Serb riots in Sarajevo</a>, in which <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_Croats" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnian Croats">Bosnian Croats</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks" title="Bosniaks">Bosniaks</a> killed two <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_Serbs" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnian Serbs">Bosnian Serbs</a> and damaged numerous Serb-owned buildings.<sup id="cite_ref-DjordjevićSpence1992_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DjordjevićSpence1992-59">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> Violent actions against ethnic Serbs were also organised outside Sarajevo, in other cities in Austro-Hungarian-controlled Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia and Slovenia. Austro-Hungarian authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina imprisoned and extradited approximately 5,500 prominent Serbs, 700 to 2,200 of whom died in prison. A further 460 Serbs were sentenced to death. A predominantly Bosniak special militia known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Schutzkorps" title="Schutzkorps">Schutzkorps</a></i> was established and carried out the persecution of Serbs.<sup id="cite_ref-Kröll2008_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kröll2008-61">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETomasevich2001485_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETomasevich2001485-62">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Schindler2007_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schindler2007-63">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVelikonja2003141_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVelikonja2003141-64">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="July_Crisis">July Crisis</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/July_Crisis" title="July Crisis">July Crisis</a></div>
<p>The assassination led to a month of diplomatic manoeuvring between Austria-Hungary, Germany, Russia, France and Britain, called the <a href="/wiki/July_Crisis" title="July Crisis">July Crisis</a>. Austria-Hungary correctly believed that Serbian officials (especially the officers of the Black Hand) were involved in the plot to murder the Archduke, and wanted to finally end Serbian interference in Bosnia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson199612_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson199612-65">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> On 23 July, Austria-Hungary delivered to Serbia the <a href="/wiki/July_Crisis#Austro-Hungarian_ultimatum" title="July Crisis">July Ultimatum</a>, a series of ten demands that were made intentionally unacceptable, in an effort to provoke a war with Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott200327_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott200327-66">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> Serbia decreed general mobilisation on the 25th. Serbia accepted all the terms of the ultimatum except for article six, which demanded that Austrian delegates be allowed in Serbia for the purpose of participation in the investigation into the assassination.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> Following this, Austria broke off diplomatic relations with Serbia and, the next day, ordered a partial mobilisation. Finally, on 28 July 1914, a month after the assassination, Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg/220px-Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg/330px-Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg/440px-Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1360" data-file-height="1052" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Austria_Hungary_ethnic.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethno-linguistic map of Austria-Hungary, 1910. <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_annexation_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" class="mw-redirect" title="Austro-Hungarian annexation of Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia-Herzegovina was annexed</a> in 1908.</div></div></div>
<p>On 25 July, Russia, in support of Serbia, declared partial mobilisation against Austria-Hungary.<sup id="cite_ref-Levy_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levy-68">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> On the 30th, Russia ordered general mobilisation. German Chancellor Bethmann-Hollweg waited until the 31st for an appropriate response, when Germany declared <i>Erklärung des Kriegszustandes</i>, or "Statement on the war status".<sup id="cite_ref-auto_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-26">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> Kaiser Wilhelm II asked his cousin, Tsar <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Nicolas II">Nicolas II</a>, to suspend the Russian general mobilisation. When he refused, Germany issued an ultimatum demanding its mobilisation be stopped, and a commitment not to support Serbia. Another was sent to France, asking her not to support Russia if it were to come to the defence of Serbia. On 1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August, after the Russian response, Germany mobilised and declared war on Russia. This also led to the general mobilisation in Austria-Hungary on 4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August.
</p><p>The German government issued demands to France that it remain neutral as they had to decide which deployment plan to implement, it being extremely difficult to change the deployment whilst it was underway. The modified German <a href="/wiki/Schlieffen_Plan" title="Schlieffen Plan">Schlieffen Plan</a>, <i>Aufmarsch II West</i>, would deploy 80% of the army in the west, while <i>Aufmarsch I Ost</i> and <i>Aufmarsch II Ost</i> would deploy 60% in the west and 40% in the east. The French did not respond, but sent a mixed message by ordering their troops to withdraw 10&#160;km (6&#160;mi) from the border to avoid any incidents, and at the same time ordered the mobilisation of their reserves. Germany responded by mobilising its own reserves and implementing <i>Aufmarsch II West</i>.
</p><p>On 1 August, Wilhelm ordered General <a href="/wiki/Helmuth_von_Moltke_the_Younger" title="Helmuth von Moltke the Younger">Helmuth von Moltke the Younger</a> to "march the whole of the<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>... army to the East" after being wrongly informed that the British would remain neutral if France was not attacked. Moltke told the Kaiser that attempting to redeploy a million men was unthinkable, and that making it possible for the French to attack the Germans "in the rear" would prove disastrous. Yet Wilhelm insisted that the German army should not march into <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a> until he received a telegram sent by his cousin <a href="/wiki/George_V" title="George V">George V</a>, who made it clear that there had been a misunderstanding. Eventually the Kaiser told Moltke, "Now you can do what you want."<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 2 August, <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Luxembourg_during_World_War_I" title="German occupation of Luxembourg during World War I">Germany occupied Luxembourg</a>, and on 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August declared war on France; on the same day, they sent the Belgian government an ultimatum demanding unimpeded right of way through any part of Belgium, which was refused. Early on the morning of 4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August, the Germans invaded; <a href="/wiki/Albert_I_of_Belgium" title="Albert I of Belgium">King Albert</a> ordered his military to resist and called for assistance under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1839)" title="Treaty of London (1839)">1839 Treaty of London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrowe20014–5_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrowe20014–5-72">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillmott200329_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillmott200329-74">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> Britain demanded Germany comply with the Treaty and respect Belgian neutrality; it declared war on Germany at 19:00&#160;UTC on 4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August 1914 (effective from 23:00), following an "unsatisfactory reply".<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Progress_of_the_war">Progress of the war</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_history_of_World_War_I" title="Diplomatic history of World War I">Diplomatic history of World War I</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Opening_hostilities">Opening hostilities</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Confusion_among_the_Central_Powers">Confusion among the Central Powers</span></h4>
<p>The strategy of the Central Powers suffered from miscommunication. Germany had promised to support Austria-Hungary's invasion of Serbia, but interpretations of what this meant differed. Previously tested deployment plans had been replaced early in 1914, but those had never been tested in exercises. Austro-Hungarian leaders believed Germany would cover its northern flank against Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStrachan2003292–296,_343–354_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStrachan2003292–296,_343–354-76">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> Germany, however, envisioned Austria-Hungary directing most of its troops against Russia, while Germany dealt with France. This confusion forced the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Army" title="Austro-Hungarian Army">Austro-Hungarian Army</a> to divide its forces between the Russian and Serbian fronts.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Serbian_campaign">Serbian campaign</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Campaign_of_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Campaign of World War I">Serbian Campaign of World War I</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg/220px-FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="110" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg/330px-FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg/440px-FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1602" data-file-height="798" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:FirstSerbianArmedPlane1915.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Serbian Army <a href="/wiki/Bl%C3%A9riot_XI" title="Blériot XI">Blériot XI</a> "Oluj", 1915</div></div></div>
<p>Austria invaded and fought the Serbian army at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cer" title="Battle of Cer">Battle of Cer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kolubara" title="Battle of Kolubara">Battle of Kolubara</a> beginning on 12 August. Over the next two weeks, Austrian attacks were thrown back with heavy losses, which marked the first major Allied victories of the war and dashed Austro-Hungarian hopes of a swift victory. As a result, Austria had to keep sizeable forces on the Serbian front, weakening its efforts against Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005172_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005172-77">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> Serbia's defeat of the Austro-Hungarian invasion of 1914 has been called one of the major upset victories of the twentieth century.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> The campaign saw the very first use of <a href="/wiki/Medical_evacuation" title="Medical evacuation">medical evacuation</a> by the Serbian army in autumn of 1915 and <a href="/wiki/Anti-aircraft_warfare" title="Anti-aircraft warfare">anti-aircraft warfare</a> in the spring of 1915 after an Austrian plane was shot down with <a href="/wiki/Ground-to-air" class="mw-redirect" title="Ground-to-air">ground-to-air</a> fire.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="German_Offensive_in_Belgium_and_France">German Offensive in Belgium and France</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front (World War I)</a></div>
<p>[[File:German soldiers in a railroad car on the way to the front during early World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I, taken in 1914. Taken from greatwar.nl site.jpg|thumb|German soldiers in a railway <a href="/wiki/Goods_wagon" title="Goods wagon">goods wagon</a> on the way to the front in 1914. Early in the war, all sides expected the conflict to be a short one.]]
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Georges_Scott,_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_!.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg/220px-Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg/330px-Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg/440px-Georges_Scott%2C_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_%21.jpg 2x" data-file-width="891" data-file-height="621" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Georges_Scott,_A_la_ba%C3%AFonnette_!.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A French bayonet charge at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Frontiers" title="Battle of the Frontiers">Battle of the Frontiers</a>; by the end of August, French casualties exceeded 260,000, including 75,000 dead.</div></div></div>
<p>When the war began, the <a href="/wiki/German_Army_order_of_battle_(1914)" title="German Army order of battle (1914)">German Order of Battle</a> placed 80% of the army in the West, with the remainder acting as a screening force in the East. The plan was to quickly knock France out of the war, then redeploy to the East and do the same to Russia.
</p><p>The German offensive in the West was officially titled <i>Aufmarsch II West,</i> but is better known as the Schlieffen Plan, after its original creator. <a href="/wiki/Alfred_von_Schlieffen" title="Alfred von Schlieffen">Schlieffen</a> deliberately kept the German left (i.e. its positions in <a href="/wiki/Alsace-Lorraine" title="Alsace-Lorraine">Alsace-Lorraine</a>) weak to lure the French into attacking there, while the majority were allocated to the German right, so as to sweep through Belgium, encircle Paris and trap the French armies against the Swiss border (the French charged into Alsace-Lorraine on the outbreak of war as envisaged by their <a href="/wiki/Plan_XVII" title="Plan XVII">Plan XVII</a>, thus actually aiding this strategy).<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> However, Schlieffen's successor Moltke grew concerned that the French might push too hard on his left flank. As such, as the German Army increased in size in the years leading up to the war, he changed the allocation of forces between the German right and left wings from 85:15 to 70:30. Ultimately, Moltke's changes meant insufficient forces to achieve decisive success and thus unrealistic goals and timings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolmes2014194,_211_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolmes2014194,_211-82">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute"><span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (November 2018)">dubious</span></a>&#32;<span class="metadata"> &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Talk:World_War_I#Dubious" title="Talk:World War I">discuss</a></span></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>The initial German advance in the West was very successful: by the end of August the Allied left, which included the <a href="/wiki/British_Expeditionary_Force_(World_War_I)" title="British Expeditionary Force (World War I)">British Expeditionary Force</a> (BEF), was in <a href="/wiki/Great_Retreat" title="Great Retreat">full retreat</a>; French casualties in the first month exceeded 260,000, including 27,000 killed on 22 August during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Frontiers" title="Battle of the Frontiers">Battle of the Frontiers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> German planning provided broad strategic instructions, while allowing army commanders considerable freedom in carrying them out at the front; this worked well in 1866 and 1870 but in 1914, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Kluck" title="Alexander von Kluck">von Kluck</a> used this freedom to disobey orders, opening a gap between the German armies as they closed on Paris.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> The French and British exploited this gap to halt the German advance east of Paris at the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Marne" title="First Battle of the Marne">First Battle of the Marne</a> from 5<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>to 12 September and push the German forces back some 50&#160;km (31&#160;mi).
