</p><p>In 1911, the Russian <a href="/wiki/Stavka" title="Stavka">Stavka</a> had agreed with the French to attack Germany within 15 days of mobilisation; this was unrealistic and the two Russian armies that entered <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussia</a> on 17 August did so without many of their support elements.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2nd_Army_(Russian_Empire)" title="2nd Army (Russian Empire)">Russian Second Army</a> was effectively destroyed at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tannenberg" title="Battle of Tannenberg">Battle of Tannenberg</a> on 26–30 August but the Russian advance caused the Germans to re-route their <a href="/wiki/8th_Army_(German_Empire)" title="8th Army (German Empire)">8th Field Army</a> from France to East Prussia, a factor in Allied victory on the Marne.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>By the end of 1914, German troops held strong defensive positions inside France, controlled the bulk of France's domestic coalfields and had inflicted 230,000 more casualties than it lost itself. However, communications problems and questionable command decisions cost Germany the chance of a decisive outcome while it had failed to achieve the primary objective of avoiding a long, two-front war.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005376–378_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005376–378-86">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> This amounted to a strategic defeat; shortly after the Marne, <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm,_German_Crown_Prince" title="Wilhelm, German Crown Prince">Crown Prince Wilhelm</a> told an American reporter; "We have lost the war. It will go on for a long time but lost it is already."<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia_and_the_Pacific">Asia and the Pacific</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Asian_and_Pacific_theatre_of_World_War_I" title="Asian and Pacific theatre of World War I">Asian and Pacific theatre of World War I</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a href="/wiki/File:World_empires_and_colonies_around_World_War_I.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/World_empires_and_colonies_around_World_War_I.png/280px-World_empires_and_colonies_around_World_War_I.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="113" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/World_empires_and_colonies_around_World_War_I.png/420px-World_empires_and_colonies_around_World_War_I.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/World_empires_and_colonies_around_World_War_I.png/560px-World_empires_and_colonies_around_World_War_I.png 2x" data-file-width="1554" data-file-height="627" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:World_empires_and_colonies_around_World_War_I.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>World empires and colonies around 1914</div></div></div>
<p>New Zealand <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_German_Samoa" title="Occupation of German Samoa">occupied</a> <a href="/wiki/German_Samoa" title="German Samoa">German Samoa</a> (later Western Samoa) on 30 August 1914. On 11 September, the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Naval_and_Military_Expeditionary_Force" title="Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force">Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force</a> landed on the island of <a href="/wiki/New_Britain" title="New Britain">Neu Pommern</a> (later New Britain), which formed part of <a href="/wiki/German_New_Guinea" title="German New Guinea">German New Guinea</a>. On 28 October, the German cruiser <a href="/wiki/SMS_Emden_(1908)" class="mw-redirect" title="SMS Emden (1908)">SMS&#160;<i>Emden</i></a> sank the <a href="/wiki/Russian_cruiser_Zhemchug" title="Russian cruiser Zhemchug">Russian cruiser Zhemchug</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Penang" title="Battle of Penang">Battle of Penang</a>. Japan seized Germany's Micronesian colonies and, after the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Tsingtao" title="Siege of Tsingtao">Siege of Tsingtao</a>, the German coaling port of <a href="/wiki/Qingdao" title="Qingdao">Qingdao</a> on the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Shandong" title="Shandong">Shandong</a> peninsula. As Vienna refused to withdraw the Austro-Hungarian cruiser <a href="/wiki/SMS_Kaiserin_Elisabeth" title="SMS Kaiserin Elisabeth">SMS&#160;<i>Kaiserin Elisabeth</i></a> from Tsingtao, Japan declared war not only on Germany, but also on Austria-Hungary; the ship participated in the defence of Tsingtao where it was sunk in November 1914.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> Within a few months, the Allied forces had seized all the German territories in the Pacific; only isolated commerce raiders and a few holdouts in New Guinea remained.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan1998224–232_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan1998224–232-89">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFalls196079–80_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFalls196079–80-90">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="African_campaigns">African campaigns</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/African_theatre_of_World_War_I" title="African theatre of World War I">African theatre of World War I</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Recruiting_for_the_Holy_War_near_Tiberias_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Recruiting_for_the_Holy_War_near_Tiberias_1914.jpg/220px-Recruiting_for_the_Holy_War_near_Tiberias_1914.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Recruiting_for_the_Holy_War_near_Tiberias_1914.jpg/330px-Recruiting_for_the_Holy_War_near_Tiberias_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Recruiting_for_the_Holy_War_near_Tiberias_1914.jpg/440px-Recruiting_for_the_Holy_War_near_Tiberias_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2349" data-file-height="1620" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Recruiting_for_the_Holy_War_near_Tiberias_1914.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Military_recruitment" title="Military recruitment">Military recruitment</a> near <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, 1914</div></div></div>
<p>Some of the first clashes of the war involved British, French, and German colonial forces in Africa. On 6–7 August, French and British troops invaded the German protectorate of <a href="/wiki/Togoland" title="Togoland">Togoland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kamerun" class="mw-redirect" title="Kamerun">Kamerun</a>. On 10 August, German forces in <a href="/wiki/German_South-West_Africa" class="mw-redirect" title="German South-West Africa">South-West Africa</a> attacked South Africa; sporadic and fierce fighting continued for the rest of the war. The German colonial forces in <a href="/wiki/German_East_Africa" title="German East Africa">German East Africa</a>, led by Colonel <a href="/wiki/Paul_von_Lettow-Vorbeck" title="Paul von Lettow-Vorbeck">Paul von Lettow-Vorbeck</a>, fought a <a href="/wiki/Guerrilla_warfare" title="Guerrilla warfare">guerrilla warfare</a> campaign during World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I and only surrendered two weeks after the armistice took effect in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFarwell1989353_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFarwell1989353-91">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_support_for_the_Allies">Indian support for the Allies</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Hindu%E2%80%93German_Conspiracy" title="Hindu–German Conspiracy">Hindu–German Conspiracy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Niedermayer%E2%80%93Hentig_Expedition" title="Niedermayer–Hentig Expedition">Niedermayer–Hentig Expedition</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Third_Anglo-Afghan_War" title="Third Anglo-Afghan War">Third Anglo-Afghan War</a></div>
<p>Germany attempted to use Indian nationalism and pan-Islamism to its advantage, <a href="/wiki/Hindu%E2%80%93German_Conspiracy" title="Hindu–German Conspiracy">instigating uprisings in India</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Niedermayer%E2%80%93Hentig_Expedition" title="Niedermayer–Hentig Expedition">sending a mission</a> that urged Afghanistan to join the war on the side of Central Powers. However, contrary to British fears of a revolt in India, the outbreak of the war saw an unprecedented outpouring of loyalty and goodwill towards Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown1994197–198_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown1994197–198-92">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown1994201–203_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown1994201–203-93">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> Indian political leaders from the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> and other groups were eager to support the British war effort, since they believed that strong support for the war effort would further the cause of <a href="/wiki/Indian_Home_Rule_movement" title="Indian Home Rule movement">Indian Home Rule</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Army" title="British Indian Army">Indian Army</a> in fact outnumbered the British Army at the beginning of the war; about 1.3&#160;million Indian soldiers and labourers served in Europe, Africa, and the Middle East, while the central government and the <a href="/wiki/Princely_state" title="Princely state">princely states</a> sent large supplies of food, money, and ammunition. In all, 140,000&#160;men served on the Western Front and nearly 700,000 in the Middle East. Casualties of Indian soldiers totalled 47,746 killed and 65,126 wounded during World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup>
The suffering engendered by the war, as well as the failure of the British government to grant self-government to India after the end of hostilities, bred disillusionment and fuelled <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">the campaign for full independence</a> that would be led by <a href="/wiki/Mohandas_Karamchand_Gandhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi">Mohandas K. Gandhi</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-95">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_Front">Western Front</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front (World War I)</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Trench_warfare_begins">Trench warfare begins</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cheshire_Regiment_trench_Somme_1916.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Cheshire_Regiment_trench_Somme_1916.jpg/220px-Cheshire_Regiment_trench_Somme_1916.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Cheshire_Regiment_trench_Somme_1916.jpg/330px-Cheshire_Regiment_trench_Somme_1916.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Cheshire_Regiment_trench_Somme_1916.jpg/440px-Cheshire_Regiment_trench_Somme_1916.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="1069" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cheshire_Regiment_trench_Somme_1916.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trenches of the 11th <a href="/wiki/Cheshire_Regiment" title="Cheshire Regiment">Cheshire Regiment</a> at Ovillers-la-Boisselle, on the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Somme</a>, July 1916</div></div></div>
<p>Military tactics developed before World War I failed to keep pace with advances in technology and had become obsolete. These advances had allowed the creation of strong defensive systems, which out-of-date military tactics could not break through for most of the war. <a href="/wiki/Barbed_wire" title="Barbed wire">Barbed wire</a> was a significant hindrance to massed infantry advances, while <a href="/wiki/Artillery" title="Artillery">artillery</a>, vastly more lethal than in the 1870s, coupled with <a href="/wiki/Machine_gun" title="Machine gun">machine guns</a>, made crossing open ground extremely difficult.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaudzens1990424_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaudzens1990424-96">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> Commanders on both sides failed to develop tactics for <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">breaching entrenched</a> positions without heavy casualties. In time, however, technology began to produce new offensive weapons, such as <a href="/wiki/Chemical_weapons_in_World_War_I" title="Chemical weapons in World War I">gas warfare</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tanks_in_World_War_I" title="Tanks in World War I">tank</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaudzens1990421–423_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaudzens1990421–423-97">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Marne" title="First Battle of the Marne">First Battle of the Marne</a> (5–12 September 1914), Allied and German forces unsuccessfully tried to outflank each other, a series of manoeuvres later known as the "<a href="/wiki/Race_to_the_Sea" title="Race to the Sea">Race to the Sea</a>". By the end of 1914, the opposing forces were left confronting each other along an uninterrupted line of entrenched positions from <a href="/wiki/Alsace" title="Alsace">Alsace</a> to Belgium's North Sea coast.<sup id="cite_ref-AJPT2_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJPT2-22">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> Since the Germans were able to choose where to stand, they normally had the advantage of the high ground; in addition, their trenches tended to be better built, since Anglo-French trenches were initially intended as "temporary," preparatory to breaking the German defences.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoodspeed1985199_(footnote)_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodspeed1985199_(footnote)-98">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Both sides tried to break the stalemate using scientific and technological advances. On 22 April 1915, at the <a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Ypres" title="Second Battle of Ypres">Second Battle of Ypres</a>, the Germans (violating the <a href="/wiki/Hague_Conventions_of_1899_and_1907" title="Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907">Hague Convention</a>) used <a href="/wiki/Chlorine" title="Chlorine">chlorine</a> gas for the first time on the Western Front. Several types of gas soon became widely used by both sides, and though it never proved a decisive, battle-winning weapon, poison gas became one of the most-feared and best-remembered horrors of the war.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELove1996_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELove1996-100">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> Tanks were developed by Britain and France and were first used in combat by the British during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Flers%E2%80%93Courcelette" title="Battle of Flers–Courcelette">Battle of Flers–Courcelette</a> (part of the Battle of the Somme) on 15 September 1916, with only partial success. However, their effectiveness would grow as the war progressed; the Allies built tanks in large numbers, whilst the Germans employed only a few of their own design, supplemented by captured Allied tanks.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Continuation_of_trench_warfare">Continuation of trench warfare</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:French_87th_Regiment_Cote_34_Verdun_1916.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/French_87th_Regiment_Cote_34_Verdun_1916.jpg/170px-French_87th_Regiment_Cote_34_Verdun_1916.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="212" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/French_87th_Regiment_Cote_34_Verdun_1916.jpg/255px-French_87th_Regiment_Cote_34_Verdun_1916.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/French_87th_Regiment_Cote_34_Verdun_1916.jpg/340px-French_87th_Regiment_Cote_34_Verdun_1916.jpg 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="499" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:French_87th_Regiment_Cote_34_Verdun_1916.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>French 87th regiment near Verdun, 1916</div></div></div>
<p>Neither side proved able to deliver a decisive blow for the next two years. Throughout 1915–17, the British Empire and France suffered more casualties than Germany, because of both the strategic and tactical stances chosen by the sides. Strategically, while the Germans mounted only one major offensive, the Allies made several attempts to break through the German lines.
</p><p>In February 1916 the Germans attacked French defensive positions at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Verdun" title="Battle of Verdun">Battle of Verdun</a>, lasting until December 1916. The Germans made initial gains, before French counter-attacks returned matters to near their starting point. Casualties were greater for the French, but the Germans bled heavily as well, with anywhere from 700,000<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDupuy19931042_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDupuy19931042-101">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> to 975,000<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrant2005276_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrant2005276-102">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> casualties suffered between the two combatants. Verdun became a symbol of French determination and self-sacrifice.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Mud stained British soldiers at rest" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/220px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/330px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/440px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg 2x" data-file-width="949" data-file-height="671" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Royal_Irish_Rifles" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Irish Rifles">Royal Irish Rifles</a> in a communications trench, <a href="/wiki/First_day_on_the_Somme" title="First day on the Somme">first day on the Somme</a>, 1916</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Battle of the Somme</a> was an Anglo-French offensive of July to November 1916. The <a href="/wiki/First_day_on_the_Somme" title="First day on the Somme">opening day</a> of the offensive (1 July 1916) was the bloodiest day in the history of the <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a>, suffering 57,470 casualties, including 19,240 dead. The entire Somme offensive cost the British Army some 420,000 casualties. The French suffered another estimated 200,000 casualties and the Germans an estimated 500,000.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris2008271_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris2008271-104">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> Gun fire wasn't the only factor taking lives; the diseases that emerged in the trenches were a major killer on both sides. The living conditions made it so that countless diseases and infections occurred, such as <a href="/wiki/Trench_foot" title="Trench foot">trench foot</a>, shell shock, blindness/burns from mustard gas, lice, trench fever, cooties (body lice) and the 'Spanish Flu'.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. It&#39;s a self-published Weebly website (June 2018)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>To maintain morale, wartime censors minimised early reports of widespread <a href="/wiki/Spanish_flu" title="Spanish flu">influenza</a> illness and mortality in Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEValentine2006_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEValentine2006-106">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> Papers were free to report the epidemic's effects in neutral Spain (such as the grave illness of <a href="/wiki/King_Alfonso_XIII" class="mw-redirect" title="King Alfonso XIII">King Alfonso XIII</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPorras-GalloDavis2014_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorras-GalloDavis2014-108">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> This created a false impression of Spain as especially hard hit,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarry2004171_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarry2004171-109">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> thereby giving rise to the pandemic's nickname, "Spanish Flu".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalvin2007_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalvin2007-110">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Canadian_tank_and_soldiers_Vimy_1917.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Files of soldiers with rifles slung follow close behind a tank, there is a dead body in the foreground" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Canadian_tank_and_soldiers_Vimy_1917.jpg/220px-Canadian_tank_and_soldiers_Vimy_1917.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="174" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Canadian_tank_and_soldiers_Vimy_1917.jpg/330px-Canadian_tank_and_soldiers_Vimy_1917.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Canadian_tank_and_soldiers_Vimy_1917.jpg/440px-Canadian_tank_and_soldiers_Vimy_1917.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="505" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Canadian_tank_and_soldiers_Vimy_1917.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Canadian troops advancing with a British <a href="/wiki/Mark_I_tank#Mark_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Mark I tank">Mark II tank</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vimy_Ridge" title="Battle of Vimy Ridge">Battle of Vimy Ridge</a>, 1917</div></div></div>
<p>Protracted action at Verdun throughout 1916,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts20051221_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts20051221-111">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> combined with the bloodletting at the Somme, brought the exhausted French army to the brink of collapse. Futile attempts using <a href="/wiki/Frontal_assault" title="Frontal assault">frontal assault</a> came at a high price for both the British and the French and led to the widespread <a href="/wiki/French_Army_Mutinies" class="mw-redirect" title="French Army Mutinies">French Army Mutinies</a>, after the failure of the costly <a href="/wiki/Nivelle_Offensive" title="Nivelle Offensive">Nivelle Offensive</a> of April–May 1917.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005854_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005854-112">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup> The concurrent British <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Arras_(1917)" title="Battle of Arras (1917)">Battle of Arras</a> was more limited in scope, and more successful, although ultimately of little strategic value.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan1998325–326_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan1998325–326-113">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStrachan2003244_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStrachan2003244-114">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> A smaller part of the Arras offensive, the capture of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vimy_Ridge" title="Battle of Vimy Ridge">Vimy Ridge</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Corps" title="Canadian Corps">Canadian Corps</a>, became highly significant to that country: the idea that Canada's national identity was born out of the battle is an opinion widely held in military and general histories of Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInglis19952_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInglis19952-115">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHumphries200766_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHumphries200766-116">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The last large-scale offensive of this period was a British attack (with French support) at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Passchendaele" title="Battle of Passchendaele">Passchendaele</a> (July–November 1917). This offensive opened with great promise for the Allies, before bogging down in the October mud. Casualties, though disputed, were roughly equal, at some 200,000–400,000 per side.
</p><p>The years of trench warfare on the Western front achieved no major exchanges of territory and, as a result, are often thought of as static and unchanging. However, throughout this period, British, French, and German <a href="/wiki/Tactical_development_on_the_Western_Front_in_1917" class="mw-redirect" title="Tactical development on the Western Front in 1917">tactics constantly evolved</a> to meet new battlefield challenges.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Naval_war">Naval war</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Naval_warfare_of_World_War_I" title="Naval warfare of World War I">Naval warfare of World War I</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a href="/wiki/File:King_George_V_and_officials_inspecting_munitions_factory_in_1917.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/King_George_V_and_officials_inspecting_munitions_factory_in_1917.PNG/240px-King_George_V_and_officials_inspecting_munitions_factory_in_1917.PNG" decoding="async" width="240" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/King_George_V_and_officials_inspecting_munitions_factory_in_1917.PNG/360px-King_George_V_and_officials_inspecting_munitions_factory_in_1917.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/King_George_V_and_officials_inspecting_munitions_factory_in_1917.PNG/480px-King_George_V_and_officials_inspecting_munitions_factory_in_1917.PNG 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="380" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:King_George_V_and_officials_inspecting_munitions_factory_in_1917.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/George_V" title="George V">King George V</a> (<i>front left</i>) and a group of officials inspect a British munitions factory in 1917.</div></div></div>
<p>At the start of the war, the German Empire had <a href="/wiki/Cruiser" title="Cruiser">cruisers</a> scattered across the globe, some of which were subsequently used to attack Allied <a href="/wiki/Merchant_shipping" class="mw-redirect" title="Merchant shipping">merchant shipping</a>. The British Royal Navy systematically hunted them down, though not without some embarrassment from its inability to protect Allied shipping. Before the beginning of the war, it was widely understood that Britain held the position of strongest, most influential navy in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. Looks to be a SPS blog post. (May 2018)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> The publishing of the book <i><a href="/wiki/The_Influence_of_Sea_Power_upon_History" title="The Influence of Sea Power upon History">The Influence of Sea Power upon History</a></i> by Alfred Thayer Mahan in 1890 was intended to encourage the United States to increase their naval power. Instead, this book made it to Germany and inspired its readers to try to over-power the British Royal Navy.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> For example, the German detached light cruiser <a href="/wiki/SMS_Emden" title="SMS Emden">SMS&#160;<i>Emden</i></a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Squadron" title="East Asia Squadron">East Asia Squadron</a> stationed at Qingdao, seized or destroyed 15 merchantmen, as well as sinking a Russian cruiser and a French destroyer. However, most of the <a href="/wiki/German_East_Asia_Squadron" class="mw-redirect" title="German East Asia Squadron">German East-Asia squadron</a>—consisting of the armoured cruisers <a href="/wiki/SMS_Scharnhorst" title="SMS Scharnhorst">SMS&#160;<i>Scharnhorst</i></a> and <a href="/wiki/SMS_Gneisenau" title="SMS Gneisenau"><i>Gneisenau</i></a>, light cruisers <a href="/wiki/SMS_N%C3%BCrnberg_(1906)" title="SMS Nürnberg (1906)"><i>Nürnberg</i></a> and <a href="/wiki/SMS_Leipzig_(1905)" title="SMS Leipzig (1905)"><i>Leipzig</i></a> and two transport ships—did not have orders to raid shipping and was instead underway to Germany when it met British warships. The German flotilla and <a href="/wiki/SMS_Dresden_(1907)" title="SMS Dresden (1907)"><i>Dresden</i></a> sank two armoured cruisers at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Coronel" title="Battle of Coronel">Battle of Coronel</a>, but was virtually destroyed at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Falkland_Islands" title="Battle of the Falkland Islands">Battle of the Falkland Islands</a> in December 1914, with only <i>Dresden</i> and a few auxiliaries escaping, but after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_M%C3%A1s_a_Tierra" title="Battle of Más a Tierra">Battle of Más a Tierra</a> these too had been destroyed or interned.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor200739–47_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor200739–47-119">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hochseeflotte_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Hochseeflotte_2.jpg/220px-Hochseeflotte_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Hochseeflotte_2.jpg/330px-Hochseeflotte_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Hochseeflotte_2.jpg/440px-Hochseeflotte_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="380" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hochseeflotte_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Battleships of the <a href="/wiki/High_Seas_Fleet" title="High Seas Fleet"><i>Hochseeflotte</i></a>, 1917</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:NationaalArchief_uboat155London.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/NationaalArchief_uboat155London.jpg/220px-NationaalArchief_uboat155London.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/NationaalArchief_uboat155London.jpg/330px-NationaalArchief_uboat155London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/NationaalArchief_uboat155London.jpg/440px-NationaalArchief_uboat155London.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="904" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:NationaalArchief_uboat155London.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/German_submarine_Deutschland" title="German submarine Deutschland">U-155</a> exhibited near Tower Bridge in London, after the 1918 Armistice</div></div></div>
<p>Soon after the outbreak of hostilities, Britain began a naval <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_Germany" title="Blockade of Germany">blockade of Germany</a>. The strategy proved effective, cutting off vital military and civilian supplies, although this blockade violated accepted international law codified by several international agreements of the past two centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeene20065_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeene20065-120">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> Britain mined international waters to prevent any ships from entering entire sections of ocean, causing danger to even neutral ships.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalpern1995293_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalpern1995293-121">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> Since there was limited response to this tactic of the British, Germany expected a similar response to its unrestricted submarine warfare.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZieger200150_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZieger200150-122">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jutland" title="Battle of Jutland">Battle of Jutland</a> (German: <i>Skagerrakschlacht</i>, or "Battle of the <a href="/wiki/Skagerrak" title="Skagerrak">Skagerrak</a>") in May/June 1916 developed into the largest naval battle of the war. It was the only full-scale clash of battleships during the war, and one of the largest in history. The Kaiserliche Marine's High Seas Fleet, commanded by Vice Admiral <a href="/wiki/Reinhard_Scheer" title="Reinhard Scheer">Reinhard Scheer</a>, fought the Royal Navy's <a href="/wiki/Grand_Fleet" title="Grand Fleet">Grand Fleet</a>, led by Admiral Sir <a href="/wiki/John_Jellicoe,_1st_Earl_Jellicoe" title="John Jellicoe, 1st Earl Jellicoe">John Jellicoe</a>. The engagement was a stand off, as the Germans were outmanoeuvred by the larger British fleet, but managed to escape and inflicted more damage to the British fleet than they received. Strategically, however, the British asserted their control of the sea, and the bulk of the German surface fleet remained confined to port for the duration of the war.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>German <a href="/wiki/U-boat" title="U-boat">U-boats</a> attempted to cut the supply lines between North America and Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-Sheffield_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sheffield-124">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> The nature of <a href="/wiki/Submarine_warfare" title="Submarine warfare">submarine warfare</a> meant that attacks often came without warning, giving the crews of the merchant ships little hope of survival.<sup id="cite_ref-Sheffield_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sheffield-124">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilbert2004306_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilbert2004306-125">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> The United States launched a protest, and Germany changed its rules of engagement. After the sinking of the passenger ship <a href="/wiki/RMS_Lusitania" title="RMS Lusitania">RMS <i>Lusitania</i></a> in 1915, Germany promised not to target passenger liners, while Britain armed its merchant ships, placing them beyond the protection of the "<a href="/wiki/Prize_rules" class="mw-redirect" title="Prize rules">cruiser rules</a>", which demanded warning and movement of crews to "a place of safety" (a standard that lifeboats did not meet).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvon_der_Porten1969_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvon_der_Porten1969-126">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> Finally, in early 1917, Germany adopted a policy of <a href="/wiki/Unrestricted_submarine_warfare" title="Unrestricted submarine warfare">unrestricted submarine warfare</a>, realising the Americans would eventually enter the war.<sup id="cite_ref-Sheffield_124-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sheffield-124">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJones200180_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJones200180-127">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup> Germany sought to strangle Allied <a href="/wiki/Sea_lane" title="Sea lane">sea lanes</a> before the United States could transport a large army overseas, but after initial successes eventually failed to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-Sheffield_124-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sheffield-124">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The U-boat threat lessened in 1917, when merchant ships began travelling in <a href="/wiki/Convoys_in_World_War_I" title="Convoys in World War I">convoys</a>, escorted by <a href="/wiki/Destroyer" title="Destroyer">destroyers</a>. This tactic made it difficult for U-boats to find targets, which significantly lessened losses; after the <a href="/wiki/Hydrophone" title="Hydrophone">hydrophone</a> and <a href="/wiki/Depth_charge" title="Depth charge">depth charges</a> were introduced, accompanying destroyers could attack a submerged submarine with some hope of success. Convoys slowed the flow of supplies, since ships had to wait as convoys were assembled. The solution to the delays was an extensive program of building new freighters. Troopships were too fast for the submarines and did not travel the North Atlantic in convoys.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> The U-boats had sunk more than 5,000 Allied ships, at a cost of 199 submarines.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>World War I also saw the first use of <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carriers</a> in combat, with <a href="/wiki/HMS_Furious_(47)" title="HMS Furious (47)">HMS&#160;<i>Furious</i></a> launching <a href="/wiki/Sopwith_Camel" title="Sopwith Camel">Sopwith Camels</a> in a successful raid against the <a href="/wiki/Zeppelin" title="Zeppelin">Zeppelin</a> hangars at <a href="/wiki/Tondern_raid" title="Tondern raid">Tondern</a> in July 1918, as well as <a href="/wiki/Blimp" title="Blimp">blimps</a> for antisubmarine patrol.<sup id="cite_ref-price1980_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-price1980-130">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Southern_theatres">Southern theatres</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="War_in_the_Balkans">War in the Balkans</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Balkans_Campaign_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="Balkans Campaign (World War I)">Balkans Campaign (World War I)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria_during_World_War_I" title="Bulgaria during World War I">Bulgaria during World War I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Campaign_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Campaign (World War I)">Serbian Campaign (World War I)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Macedonian_Front" class="mw-redirect" title="Macedonian Front">Macedonian Front</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fl%C3%BCchtlingstransport_Leibnitz_-_k.k._Innenministerium_-_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Fl%C3%BCchtlingstransport_Leibnitz_-_k.k._Innenministerium_-_1914.jpg/220px-Fl%C3%BCchtlingstransport_Leibnitz_-_k.k._Innenministerium_-_1914.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Fl%C3%BCchtlingstransport_Leibnitz_-_k.k._Innenministerium_-_1914.jpg/330px-Fl%C3%BCchtlingstransport_Leibnitz_-_k.k._Innenministerium_-_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Fl%C3%BCchtlingstransport_Leibnitz_-_k.k._Innenministerium_-_1914.jpg/440px-Fl%C3%BCchtlingstransport_Leibnitz_-_k.k._Innenministerium_-_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2488" data-file-height="2068" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Fl%C3%BCchtlingstransport_Leibnitz_-_k.k._Innenministerium_-_1914.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Refugee transport from Serbia in <a href="/wiki/Leibnitz" title="Leibnitz">Leibnitz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Styria" title="Styria">Styria</a>, 1914</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bulgaria_southern_front.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Bulgaria_southern_front.jpg/220px-Bulgaria_southern_front.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Bulgaria_southern_front.jpg/330px-Bulgaria_southern_front.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Bulgaria_southern_front.jpg/440px-Bulgaria_southern_front.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="754" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bulgaria_southern_front.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bulgarian soldiers in a trench, preparing to fire against an incoming aeroplane</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Austrians_executing_Serbs_1917.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Austrians_executing_Serbs_1917.JPG/220px-Austrians_executing_Serbs_1917.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Austrians_executing_Serbs_1917.JPG/330px-Austrians_executing_Serbs_1917.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Austrians_executing_Serbs_1917.JPG/440px-Austrians_executing_Serbs_1917.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2601" data-file-height="1829" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Austrians_executing_Serbs_1917.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Austro-Hungarian troops executing captured Serbians, 1917. <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a> lost about 850,000 people during the war, a quarter of its pre-war population.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Faced with Russia in the east, Austria-Hungary could spare only one-third of its army to attack Serbia. After suffering heavy losses, the Austrians briefly occupied the Serbian capital, <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a>. A Serbian counter-attack in the Battle of Kolubara succeeded in driving them from the country by the end of 1914. For the first ten months of 1915, Austria-Hungary used most of its military reserves to fight Italy. German and Austro-Hungarian diplomats, however, scored a coup by persuading Bulgaria to join the attack on Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-TuckerRoberts2005_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TuckerRoberts2005-132">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> The Austro-Hungarian provinces of <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>, Croatia and <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_(region)" title="Bosnia (region)">Bosnia</a> provided troops for Austria-Hungary in the fight with Serbia, Russia and Italy. Montenegro allied itself with Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeiberg200554–55_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeiberg200554–55-133">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bulgaria declared war on Serbia on 12 October 1915 and joined in the attack by the Austro-Hungarian army under Mackensen's army of 250,000 that was already underway. Serbia was conquered in a little more than a month, as the Central Powers, now including Bulgaria, sent in 600,000 troops total. The Serbian army, fighting on two fronts and facing certain defeat, retreated into northern <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Albania" title="Principality of Albania">Albania</a>. The Serbs suffered defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Offensive_(1915)" title="Kosovo Offensive (1915)">Battle of Kosovo</a>. Montenegro covered the Serbian retreat towards the Adriatic coast in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mojkovac" title="Battle of Mojkovac">Battle of Mojkovac</a> in 6–7 January 1916, but ultimately the Austrians also conquered Montenegro. The surviving Serbian soldiers were evacuated by ship to Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts20051075–1076_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts20051075–1076-134">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> After conquest, Serbia was divided between Austro-Hungary and Bulgaria.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiNardo2015102_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiNardo2015102-135">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In late 1915, a Franco-British force landed at <a href="/wiki/Salonica" class="mw-redirect" title="Salonica">Salonica</a> in Greece to offer assistance and to pressure its government to declare war against the Central Powers. However, the pro-German <a href="/wiki/Constantine_I_of_Greece" title="Constantine I of Greece">King Constantine I</a> dismissed the pro-Allied government of <a href="/wiki/Eleftherios_Venizelos" title="Eleftherios Venizelos">Eleftherios Venizelos</a> before the Allied expeditionary force arrived.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeiberg2005108–110_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeiberg2005108–110-136">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> The friction between the King of Greece and the Allies continued to accumulate with the <a href="/wiki/National_Schism" title="National Schism">National Schism</a>, which effectively divided Greece between regions still loyal to the king and the new provisional government of Venizelos in Salonica. After intense negotiations and an armed confrontation in <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a> between Allied and royalist forces (an incident known as <a href="/wiki/Noemvriana" title="Noemvriana">Noemvriana</a>), the King of Greece resigned and his second son <a href="/wiki/Alexander_of_Greece" title="Alexander of Greece">Alexander</a> took his place; Greece officially joined the war on the side of the Allies in June 1917.
</p><p>The Macedonian Front was initially mostly static. French and Serbian forces retook limited areas of Macedonia by recapturing <a href="/wiki/Bitola" title="Bitola">Bitola</a> on 19 November 1916 following the costly <a href="/wiki/Monastir_Offensive" title="Monastir Offensive">Monastir Offensive</a>, which brought stabilisation of the front.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Serbian and French troops finally made a breakthrough in September 1918 in the <a href="/wiki/Vardar_Offensive" title="Vardar Offensive">Vardar Offensive</a>, after most of the German and Austro-Hungarian troops had been withdrawn. The Bulgarians were defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dobro_Pole" title="Battle of Dobro Pole">Battle of Dobro Pole</a>, and by 25 September British and French troops had crossed the border into Bulgaria proper as the Bulgarian army collapsed. Bulgaria capitulated four days later, on 29 September 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerWoodMurphy1999150–152_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerWoodMurphy1999150–152-138">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> The German high command responded by despatching troops to hold the line, but these forces were far too weak to reestablish a front.<sup id="cite_ref-militera_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-militera-139">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The disappearance of the Macedonian Front meant that the road to <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">Budapest</a> and Vienna was now opened to Allied forces. Hindenburg and Ludendorff concluded that the strategic and operational balance had now shifted decidedly against the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> and, a day after the Bulgarian collapse, insisted on an immediate peace settlement.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoughty2005491_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoughty2005491-140">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_Empire">Ottoman Empire</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Ottoman_Empire_during_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Ottoman Empire during World War I">History of the Ottoman Empire during World War I</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_theatre_of_World_War_I" title="Middle Eastern theatre of World War I">Middle Eastern theatre of World War I</a></div>
<p>[[File:Scene just before the evacuation at Anzac. Australian troops charging near a Turkish trench. When they got there the<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>... - NARA - 533108.tif|thumb|left|Australian troops charging near a Turkish trench during the <a href="/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Gallipoli Campaign">Gallipoli Campaign</a>]]
</p><p>The Ottomans threatened Russia's <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasian</a> territories and Britain's communications with India via the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a>. As the conflict progressed, the Ottoman Empire took advantage of the European powers' preoccupation with the war and conducted large-scale ethnic cleansing of the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_people" title="Assyrian people">Assyrian</a> Christian populations, known as the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" title="Armenian Genocide">Armenian Genocide</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_Genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Genocide">Greek Genocide</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Assyrian Genocide">Assyrian Genocide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lieberman_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lieberman-143">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The British and French opened overseas fronts with the <a href="/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Gallipoli Campaign">Gallipoli</a> (1915) and <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamian_campaign" title="Mesopotamian campaign">Mesopotamian campaigns</a> (1914). In Gallipoli, the Ottoman Empire successfully repelled the British, French, and <a href="/wiki/Australian_and_New_Zealand_Army_Corps" title="Australian and New Zealand Army Corps">Australian and New Zealand Army Corps</a> (ANZACs). In <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, by contrast, after the defeat of the British defenders in the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Kut" title="Siege of Kut">Siege of Kut</a> by the Ottomans (1915–16), British Imperial forces reorganised and captured <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a> in March 1917. The British were aided in Mesopotamia by local Arab and Assyrian tribesmen, while the Ottomans employed local Kurdish and Turcoman tribes.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sultan_Mehmed_V_of_Turkey_greeting_Kaiser_Wilhelm_II_on_his_arrival_at_Constantinople.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Sultan_Mehmed_V_of_Turkey_greeting_Kaiser_Wilhelm_II_on_his_arrival_at_Constantinople.jpg/220px-Sultan_Mehmed_V_of_Turkey_greeting_Kaiser_Wilhelm_II_on_his_arrival_at_Constantinople.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Sultan_Mehmed_V_of_Turkey_greeting_Kaiser_Wilhelm_II_on_his_arrival_at_Constantinople.jpg/330px-Sultan_Mehmed_V_of_Turkey_greeting_Kaiser_Wilhelm_II_on_his_arrival_at_Constantinople.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Sultan_Mehmed_V_of_Turkey_greeting_Kaiser_Wilhelm_II_on_his_arrival_at_Constantinople.jpg/440px-Sultan_Mehmed_V_of_Turkey_greeting_Kaiser_Wilhelm_II_on_his_arrival_at_Constantinople.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="501" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sultan_Mehmed_V_of_Turkey_greeting_Kaiser_Wilhelm_II_on_his_arrival_at_Constantinople.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mehmed_V" title="Mehmed V">Mehmed V</a> greeting <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Wilhelm II">Wilhelm II</a> on his arrival at <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a></div></div></div>
<p>Further to the west, the Suez Canal was defended from Ottoman attacks in 1915 and 1916; in August, a German and Ottoman force was defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Romani" title="Battle of Romani">Battle of Romani</a> by the <a href="/wiki/ANZAC_Mounted_Division" title="ANZAC Mounted Division">ANZAC Mounted Division</a> and the <a href="/wiki/52nd_(Lowland)_Infantry_Division" title="52nd (Lowland) Infantry Division">52nd (Lowland) Infantry Division</a>. Following this victory, an <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Expeditionary_Force" title="Egyptian Expeditionary Force">Egyptian Expeditionary Force</a> advanced across the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a>, pushing Ottoman forces back in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Magdhaba" title="Battle of Magdhaba">Battle of Magdhaba</a> in December and the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Rafa" title="Battle of Rafa">Battle of Rafa</a> on the border between the Egyptian <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai</a> and Ottoman Palestine in January 1917.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Russian armies generally had success in the Caucasus. <a href="/wiki/Enver_Pasha" title="Enver Pasha">Enver Pasha</a>, supreme commander of the Ottoman armed forces, was ambitious and dreamed of re-conquering central Asia and areas that had been lost to Russia previously. He was, however, a poor commander.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFromkin2004119_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFromkin2004119-146">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> He launched an offensive against the Russians in the Caucasus in December 1914 with 100,000 troops, insisting on a frontal attack against mountainous Russian positions in winter. He lost 86% of his force at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sarikamish" title="Battle of Sarikamish">Battle of Sarikamish</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-caven_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-caven-147">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ottoman_15th_Corps.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Ottoman_15th_Corps.jpg/220px-Ottoman_15th_Corps.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Ottoman_15th_Corps.jpg/330px-Ottoman_15th_Corps.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Ottoman_15th_Corps.jpg/440px-Ottoman_15th_Corps.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="475" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ottoman_15th_Corps.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kaiser Wilhelm II inspecting Turkish troops of the 15th Corps in East Galicia, Austria-Hungary (now Poland). Prince Leopold of Bavaria, the Supreme Commander of the German Army on the Eastern Front, is second from the left.</div></div></div>
<p>The Ottoman Empire, with German support, invaded <a href="/wiki/Persia" class="mw-redirect" title="Persia">Persia</a> (modern <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>) in December 1914 in an effort to cut off British and Russian access to <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_reservoir" title="Petroleum reservoir">petroleum reservoirs</a> around <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a> near the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> Persia, ostensibly neutral, had long been under the spheres of British and Russian influence. The Ottomans and Germans were aided by <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Kurdish people">Kurdish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Azeri" class="mw-redirect" title="Azeri">Azeri</a> forces, together with a large number of major Iranian tribes, such as the <a href="/wiki/Qashqai_people" title="Qashqai people">Qashqai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tangistani" class="mw-redirect" title="Tangistani">Tangistanis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luristani" class="mw-redirect" title="Luristani">Luristanis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Khamseh" title="Khamseh">Khamseh</a>, while the Russians and British had the support of Armenian and Assyrian forces. The <a href="/wiki/Persian_Campaign" title="Persian Campaign">Persian Campaign</a> was to last until 1918 and end in failure for the Ottomans and their allies. However, the Russian withdrawal from the war in 1917 led to Armenian and Assyrian forces, who had hitherto inflicted a series of defeats upon the forces of the Ottomans and their allies, being cut off from supply lines, outnumbered, outgunned and isolated, forcing them to fight and flee towards British lines in northern Mesopotamia.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sarikam.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Sarikam.jpg/220px-Sarikam.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Sarikam.jpg/330px-Sarikam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Sarikam.jpg/440px-Sarikam.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1353" data-file-height="966" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sarikam.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russian forest trench at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sarikamish" title="Battle of Sarikamish">Battle of Sarikamish</a>, 1914–1915</div></div></div>
<p>General <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Yudenich" title="Nikolai Yudenich">Yudenich</a>, the Russian commander from 1915 to 1916, drove the Turks out of most of the southern Caucasus with a string of victories.<sup id="cite_ref-caven_147-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-caven-147">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup> In 1917, Russian <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duke_Nicholas" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Duke Nicholas">Grand Duke Nicholas</a> assumed command of the Caucasus front. Nicholas planned a railway from <a href="/wiki/Georgia_within_the_Russian_Empire" title="Georgia within the Russian Empire">Russian Georgia</a> to the conquered territories, so that fresh supplies could be brought up for a new offensive in 1917. However, in March 1917 (February in the pre-revolutionary Russian calendar), the Czar abdicated in the course of the <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">February Revolution</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Caucasus_Army_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Caucasus Army (World War I)">Russian Caucasus Army</a> began to fall apart.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Arab_Revolt" title="Arab Revolt">Arab Revolt</a>, instigated by the Arab bureau of the British <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Office" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign Office">Foreign Office</a>, started June 1916 with the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mecca_(1916)" title="Battle of Mecca (1916)">Battle of Mecca</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/Sherif_Hussein" class="mw-redirect" title="Sherif Hussein">Sherif Hussein</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, and ended with the Ottoman surrender of Damascus. <a href="/wiki/Fakhri_Pasha" title="Fakhri Pasha">Fakhri Pasha</a>, the Ottoman commander of <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>, resisted for more than two and half years during the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Medina" title="Siege of Medina">Siege of Medina</a> before surrendering in January 1919.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESachar1970122–138_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESachar1970122–138-150">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Senussi" title="Senussi">Senussi</a> tribe, along the border of Italian Libya and British Egypt, incited and armed by the Turks, waged a small-scale guerrilla war against Allied troops. The British were forced to dispatch 12,000 troops to oppose them in the <a href="/wiki/Senussi_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Senussi Campaign">Senussi Campaign</a>. Their rebellion was finally crushed in mid-1916.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilbert1994_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilbert1994-151">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Total Allied casualties on the Ottoman fronts amounted 650,000 men. Total Ottoman casualties were 725,000 (325,000 dead and 400,000 wounded).<sup id="cite_ref-Brief_Ottoman_History_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brief_Ottoman_History-152">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Italian_participation">Italian participation</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Italian_Front_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Front (World War I)">Italian Front (World War I)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Italy_during_World_War_I" title="Military history of Italy during World War I">Military history of Italy during World War I</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Albania_during_World_War_I" title="Albania during World War I">Albania during World War I</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Interventisti_Bologna_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Interventisti_Bologna_1914.jpg/220px-Interventisti_Bologna_1914.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Interventisti_Bologna_1914.jpg/330px-Interventisti_Bologna_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Interventisti_Bologna_1914.jpg/440px-Interventisti_Bologna_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1165" data-file-height="848" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Interventisti_Bologna_1914.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A pro-war demonstration in <a href="/wiki/Bologna" title="Bologna">Bologna</a>, Italy, 1914</div></div></div>
<p>Italy had been allied with the German and Austro-Hungarian Empires since 1882 as part of the Triple Alliance. However, the nation had its own designs on Austrian territory in <a href="/wiki/Trentino" title="Trentino">Trentino</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Littoral" title="Austrian Littoral">Austrian Littoral</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rijeka" title="Rijeka">Fiume</a> (Rijeka) and <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a>. Rome had a secret 1902 pact with France, effectively nullifying its part in the Triple Alliance;<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> Italy secretly agreed with France to remain neutral if the latter was attacked by Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-Seymour_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seymour-24">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> At the start of hostilities, Italy refused to commit troops, arguing that the Triple Alliance was defensive and that Austria-Hungary was an aggressor. The Austro-Hungarian government began negotiations to secure Italian neutrality, offering the French colony of Tunisia in return. The Allies made a counter-offer in which Italy would receive the <a href="/wiki/Trentino-Alto_Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol" title="Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol">Southern Tyrol</a>, Austrian Littoral and territory on the Dalmatian coast after the defeat of Austria-Hungary. This was formalised by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1915)" title="Treaty of London (1915)">Treaty of London</a>. Further encouraged by the Allied invasion of Turkey in April 1915, Italy joined the Triple Entente and declared war on Austria-Hungary on 23 May. Fifteen months later, Italy declared war on Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Austro-Hungarian_mountain_corps.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Austro-Hungarian_mountain_corps.jpg/170px-Austro-Hungarian_mountain_corps.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Austro-Hungarian_mountain_corps.jpg/255px-Austro-Hungarian_mountain_corps.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Austro-Hungarian_mountain_corps.jpg/340px-Austro-Hungarian_mountain_corps.jpg 2x" data-file-width="595" data-file-height="795" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Austro-Hungarian_mountain_corps.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Austro-Hungarian troops, Tyrol</div></div></div>
<p>The Italians had numerical superiority, but this advantage was lost, not only because of the difficult terrain in which the fighting took place, but also because of the strategies and tactics employed.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="A complete citation is needed (September 2019)">full citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> <a href="/wiki/Field_Marshal" class="mw-redirect" title="Field Marshal">Field Marshal</a> <a href="/wiki/Luigi_Cadorna" title="Luigi Cadorna">Luigi Cadorna</a>, a staunch proponent of the frontal assault, had dreams of breaking into the Slovenian plateau, taking <a href="/wiki/Ljubljana" title="Ljubljana">Ljubljana</a> and threatening Vienna.
</p><p>On the Trentino front, the Austro-Hungarians took advantage of the mountainous terrain, which favoured the defender. After an initial strategic retreat, the front remained largely unchanged, while Austrian <a href="/wiki/Kaisersch%C3%BCtzen" title="Kaiserschützen">Kaiserschützen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Standsch%C3%BCtzen" title="Standschützen">Standschützen</a> engaged Italian <a href="/wiki/Alpini" title="Alpini">Alpini</a> in bitter hand-to-hand combat throughout the summer. The Austro-Hungarians counterattacked in the <a href="/wiki/Asiago" title="Asiago">Altopiano of Asiago</a>, towards Verona and Padua, in the spring of 1916 (<i><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Asiago" title="Battle of Asiago">Strafexpedition</a></i>), but made little progress and were defeated by the Italians.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Beginning in 1915, the Italians under Cadorna mounted eleven offensives on the <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_the_Isonzo" title="Battles of the Isonzo">Isonzo front</a> along the <a href="/wiki/So%C4%8Da" title="Soča">Isonzo</a> (Soča) River, northeast of <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a>. Of this eleven offensives, five were won by Italy, three remained inconclusive, and other three were repelled by the Austro-Hungarians, who held the higher ground. In the summer of 1916, after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Doberd%C3%B2" title="Battle of Doberdò">Battle of Doberdò</a>, the Italians captured the town of <a href="/wiki/Gorizia" title="Gorizia">Gorizia</a>. After this victory, the front remained static for over a year, despite several Italian offensives, centred on the <a href="/wiki/Banj%C5%A1ice_Plateau" title="Banjšice Plateau">Banjšice</a> and Karst Plateau east of Gorizia.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:K%C3%A4mpfe_auf_dem_Doberdo.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/K%C3%A4mpfe_auf_dem_Doberdo.JPG/220px-K%C3%A4mpfe_auf_dem_Doberdo.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/K%C3%A4mpfe_auf_dem_Doberdo.JPG/330px-K%C3%A4mpfe_auf_dem_Doberdo.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/K%C3%A4mpfe_auf_dem_Doberdo.JPG/440px-K%C3%A4mpfe_auf_dem_Doberdo.JPG 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="542" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:K%C3%A4mpfe_auf_dem_Doberdo.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Depiction of the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Doberd%C3%B2" title="Battle of Doberdò">Battle of Doberdò</a>, fought in August 1916 between the Italian and the Austro-Hungarian armies</div></div></div>
<p>The Central Powers launched a crushing offensive on 26 October 1917, spearheaded by the Germans, and achieved a victory at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Caporetto" title="Battle of Caporetto">Caporetto</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kobarid" title="Kobarid">Kobarid</a>). The Italian Army was routed and retreated more than 100 kilometres (62&#160;mi) to reorganise. The new Italian chief of staff, <a href="/wiki/Armando_Diaz" title="Armando Diaz">Armando Diaz</a>, ordered the Army to stop their retreat and defend the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Monte_Grappa" title="First Battle of Monte Grappa">Monte Grappa</a> summit, where fortified defenses were constructed; the Italians repelled the Austro-Hungarian and German Army, and stabilised the front at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Piave_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of the Piave River">Piave River</a>. Since the Italian Army had suffered heavy losses in the Battle of Caporetto, the Italian Government ordered conscription of the so-called <i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>99 Boys</i> (<i>Ragazzi del '99</i>): all males born in 1899 and prior, who were 18 years old or older. In 1918, the Austro-Hungarians failed to break through in a series of battles on the Piave and were finally decisively defeated in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vittorio_Veneto" title="Battle of Vittorio Veneto">Battle of Vittorio Veneto</a> in October. On 1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November, the Italian Navy destroyed much of the Austro-Hungarian fleet stationed in <a href="/wiki/Pula" title="Pula">Pula</a>, preventing it from being handed over to the new <a href="/wiki/State_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs" title="State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs">State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs</a>. On 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November, the Italians invaded Trieste from the sea. On the same day, the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Villa_Giusti" title="Armistice of Villa Giusti">Armistice of Villa Giusti</a> was signed. By mid-November 1918, the Italian military occupied the entire former Austrian Littoral and had seized control of the portion of Dalmatia that had been guaranteed to Italy by the London Pact.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> By the end of hostilities in November 1918,<sup id="cite_ref-Paul_O_2005._Pp._17_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Paul_O_2005._Pp._17-158">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup> Admiral <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Millo" title="Enrico Millo">Enrico Millo</a> declared himself Italy's Governor of Dalmatia.<sup id="cite_ref-Paul_O_2005._Pp._17_158-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Paul_O_2005._Pp._17-158">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup> Austria-Hungary surrendered on 11 November 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHickey200360–65_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHickey200360–65-159">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETucker2005585–589_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETucker2005585–589-160">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Romanian_participation">Romanian participation</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Romania_during_World_War_I" title="Romania during World War I">Romania during World War I</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Marshal_Joffre_inspecting_Romanian_troops_during_WWI.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Marshal_Joffre_inspecting_Romanian_troops_during_WWI.jpg/220px-Marshal_Joffre_inspecting_Romanian_troops_during_WWI.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="111" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Marshal_Joffre_inspecting_Romanian_troops_during_WWI.jpg/330px-Marshal_Joffre_inspecting_Romanian_troops_during_WWI.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Marshal_Joffre_inspecting_Romanian_troops_during_WWI.jpg/440px-Marshal_Joffre_inspecting_Romanian_troops_during_WWI.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="757" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Marshal_Joffre_inspecting_Romanian_troops_during_WWI.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Marshal <a href="/wiki/Joffre" class="mw-redirect" title="Joffre">Joffre</a> inspecting Romanian troops, 1916</div></div></div>
<p>Romania had been allied with the Central Powers since 1882. When the war began, however, it declared its neutrality, arguing that because Austria-Hungary had itself declared war on Serbia, Romania was under no obligation to join the war. On 4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August 1916, Romania and the Entente signed the Political Treaty and Military Convention, that established the coordinates of Romania's participation in the war. In return, it received the Allies' formal sanction for <a href="/wiki/Transylvania" title="Transylvania">Transylvania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banat" title="Banat">Banat</a> and other territories of Austria-Hungary to be annexed to Romania. The action had large popular support.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> On 27 August 1916, the Romanian Army <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Transylvania" title="Battle of Transylvania">launched an attack</a> against Austria-Hungary, with limited Russian support. The Romanian offensive was initially successful in Transylvania, but a Central Powers counterattack by the drove them back.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> As a result of the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Bucharest" title="Battle of Bucharest">Battle of Bucharest</a>, the Central Powers occupied Bucharest on 6<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>December 1916. Fighting in Moldova <a href="/wiki/Romanian_Campaign#Stabilization_and_stalemate_(1917)" class="mw-redirect" title="Romanian Campaign">continued in 1917</a>, but Russian withdrawal from the war in late 1917 as a result of the <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a> meant that Romania was forced to sign an armistice with the Central Powers on 9<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>December 1917.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Romanian_troops_at_Marasesti_in_1917.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Romanian_troops_at_Marasesti_in_1917.jpg/220px-Romanian_troops_at_Marasesti_in_1917.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Romanian_troops_at_Marasesti_in_1917.jpg/330px-Romanian_troops_at_Marasesti_in_1917.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Romanian_troops_at_Marasesti_in_1917.jpg/440px-Romanian_troops_at_Marasesti_in_1917.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="913" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Romanian_troops_at_Marasesti_in_1917.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Romanian troops during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_M%C4%83r%C4%83%C5%9Fe%C5%9Fti" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Mărăşeşti">Battle of Mărăşeşti</a>, 1917</div></div></div>
<p>In January 1918, Romanian forces established control over <a href="/wiki/Bessarabia" title="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a> as the Russian Army abandoned the province. Although a treaty was signed by the Romanian and <a href="/wiki/Bolshevik" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a> Russian governments following talks between 5<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>and 9<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>March 1918 on the withdrawal of Romanian forces from Bessarabia within two months, on 27 March 1918 Romania formally attached Bessarabia, inhabited by a Romanian majority, to its territory, based on a resolution passed by the local assembly of that territory on its unification with Romania.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Romania officially made peace with the Central Powers by signing the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1918)" title="Treaty of Bucharest (1918)">Treaty of Bucharest</a> on 7<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>May 1918. Under the treaty, Romania was obliged to end the war with the Central Powers and make small territorial concessions to Austria-Hungary, ceding control of some passes in the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a>, and to grant oil concessions to Germany. In exchange, the Central Powers recognised the sovereignty of Romania over Bessarabia.
