The treaty was renounced in October 1918 by the <a href="/wiki/Alexandru_Marghiloman" title="Alexandru Marghiloman">Alexandru Marghiloman</a> government, and Romania nominally re-entered the war on 10 November 1918 against the Central Powers. The next day, the Treaty of Bucharest was nullified by the terms of the Armistice of <a href="/wiki/Compi%C3%A8gne" title="Compiègne">Compiègne</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> Total Romanian deaths from 1914 to 1918, military and civilian, within contemporary borders, were estimated at 748,000.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Eastern_Front">Eastern Front</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Eastern Front (World War I)">Eastern Front (World War I)</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Initial_actions">Initial actions</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nastepca_tronu_w_twierdzy_przemysl.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Nastepca_tronu_w_twierdzy_przemysl.jpg/220px-Nastepca_tronu_w_twierdzy_przemysl.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="133" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Nastepca_tronu_w_twierdzy_przemysl.jpg/330px-Nastepca_tronu_w_twierdzy_przemysl.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Nastepca_tronu_w_twierdzy_przemysl.jpg/440px-Nastepca_tronu_w_twierdzy_przemysl.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="617" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Nastepca_tronu_w_twierdzy_przemysl.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Heir presumptive Karl visiting the fortress of Przemyśl after the first siege. The Russian <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Przemy%C5%9Bl" title="Siege of Przemyśl">Siege of Przemyśl</a> was the longest siege of the war.</div></div></div>
<p>Russian plans for the start of the war called for simultaneous invasions of Austrian <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Galicia_and_Lodomeria" title="Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria">Galicia</a> and East Prussia. Although Russia's initial advance into Galicia was largely successful, it was driven back from East Prussia by Hindenburg and <a href="/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff" title="Erich Ludendorff">Ludendorff</a> at the battles of Tannenberg and the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Masurian_Lakes" title="First Battle of the Masurian Lakes">Masurian Lakes</a> in August and September 1914.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETucker2005715_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETucker2005715-168">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeyer2006152–154,_161,_163,_175,_182_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeyer2006152–154,_161,_163,_175,_182-169">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> Russia's less developed industrial base and ineffective military leadership were instrumental in the events that unfolded. By the spring of 1915, the Russians had retreated to Galicia, and, in May, the Central Powers achieved a remarkable breakthrough on Poland's southern frontiers with their <a href="/wiki/Gorlice%E2%80%93Tarn%C3%B3w_Offensive" title="Gorlice–Tarnów Offensive">Gorlice–Tarnów Offensive</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Smele_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Smele-170">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> On 5<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August, they captured <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> and forced the Russians to withdraw from Poland.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_Revolution">Russian Revolution</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wladiwostok_Parade_1918.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Wladiwostok_Parade_1918.jpg/220px-Wladiwostok_Parade_1918.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Wladiwostok_Parade_1918.jpg/330px-Wladiwostok_Parade_1918.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Wladiwostok_Parade_1918.jpg/440px-Wladiwostok_Parade_1918.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2261" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Wladiwostok_Parade_1918.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Allied troops parade through <a href="/wiki/Vladivostok" title="Vladivostok">Vladivostok</a> in armed support of the anti-communist <a href="/wiki/White_Movement#White_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="White Movement">White Army</a>, September 1918</div></div></div>
<p>Despite Russia's success in the June 1916 <a href="/wiki/Brusilov_Offensive" title="Brusilov Offensive">Brusilov Offensive</a> against the Austrians in eastern Galicia,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchindler2003_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchindler2003-171">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> the offensive was undermined by the reluctance of other Russian generals to commit their forces to support the victory. Allied and Russian forces were revived only briefly by <a href="/wiki/Romania_during_World_War_I" title="Romania during World War I">Romania's entry into the war</a> on 27 August, as Romania was rapidly defeated by a Central Powers offensive. Meanwhile, unrest grew in Russia as <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia" title="Nicholas II of Russia">the Tsar</a> remained at the front. The increasingly incompetent rule of <a href="/wiki/Alexandra_Feodorovna_(Alix_of_Hesse)" title="Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)">Empress Alexandra</a> drew protests and resulted in the murder of her favourite, <a href="/wiki/Grigori_Rasputin" title="Grigori Rasputin">Rasputin</a>, at the end of 1916.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk-en.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Map_Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk-en.jpg/190px-Map_Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk-en.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="295" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Map_Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk-en.jpg/285px-Map_Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk-en.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Map_Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk-en.jpg/380px-Map_Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk-en.jpg 2x" data-file-width="589" data-file-height="916" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk-en.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Territory lost under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a></div></div></div>
<p>In March 1917, demonstrations in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Petrograd</a> culminated in the abdication of Tsar Nicholas II and the appointment of a weak <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">Provisional Government</a>, which shared power with the <a href="/wiki/Petrograd_Soviet" title="Petrograd Soviet">Petrograd Soviet</a> socialists. This arrangement led to confusion and chaos both at the front and at home. The army became increasingly ineffective.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the Tsar's abdication, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>—with the help of the German government—was ushered by train from Switzerland into Russia 16 April 1917.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup> Discontent and the weaknesses of the Provisional Government led to a rise in the popularity of the Bolshevik Party, led by Lenin, which demanded an immediate end to the war. The Revolution of November was followed in December by an armistice and negotiations with Germany. At first, the Bolsheviks refused the German terms, but when German troops began marching across Ukraine unopposed, the new government acceded to the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> on 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>March 1918. The treaty ceded vast territories, including Finland, the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic provinces</a>, parts of Poland and Ukraine to the Central Powers.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> Despite this enormous German success, the manpower required by the Germans to occupy the captured territory may have contributed to the failure of their <a href="/wiki/Spring_Offensive" title="Spring Offensive">Spring Offensive</a>, and secured relatively little food or other <a href="/wiki/Materiel" title="Materiel">materiel</a> for the Central Powers war effort.
</p><p>With the adoption of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, the Entente no longer existed. The Allied powers led <a href="/wiki/Allied_intervention_in_the_Russian_Civil_War" title="Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War">a small-scale invasion</a> of Russia, partly to stop Germany from exploiting Russian resources, and to a lesser extent, to support the <a href="/wiki/White_movement" title="White movement">"Whites"</a> (as opposed to the "Reds") in the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMawdsley200854–55_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMawdsley200854–55-175">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> Allied troops landed in <a href="/wiki/Arkhangelsk" title="Arkhangelsk">Arkhangelsk</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Vladivostok" title="Vladivostok">Vladivostok</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/North_Russia_Intervention" class="mw-redirect" title="North Russia Intervention">North Russia Intervention</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Czechoslovak_Legion">Czechoslovak Legion</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovak_Legion" title="Czechoslovak Legion">Czechoslovak Legion</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Czech_Troops.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Czech_Troops.jpg/260px-Czech_Troops.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Czech_Troops.jpg/390px-Czech_Troops.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Czech_Troops.jpg/520px-Czech_Troops.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="353" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Czech_Troops.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Czechoslovak_Legion" title="Czechoslovak Legion">Czechoslovak Legion</a>, Vladivostok, 1918</div></div></div>
<p>The Czechoslovak Legion fought on the side of the Entente. Its goal was to win support for the independence of <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovakia" title="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a>. The Legion in Russia was established in September 1914, in December 1917 in <a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">France</a> (including volunteers from America) and in April 1918 in <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italy</a>. Czechoslovak Legion troops defeated the <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a> army at the Ukrainian village of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Zborov_(1917)" title="Battle of Zborov (1917)">Zborov</a>, in July 1917. After this success, the number of Czechoslovak legionaries increased, as well as Czechoslovak military power. In the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Bakhmach" title="Battle of Bakhmach">Battle of Bakhmach</a>, the Legion defeated the Germans and forced them to make a truce.
</p><p>In Russia, they were heavily involved in the Russian Civil War, siding with the Whites against the <a href="/wiki/Bolsheviks" title="Bolsheviks">Bolsheviks</a>, at times controlling most of the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Trans-Siberian railway">Trans-Siberian railway</a> and conquering all the major cities of <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>. The presence of the Czechoslovak Legion near <a href="/wiki/Yekaterinburg" title="Yekaterinburg">Yekaterinburg</a> appears to have been one of the motivations for the Bolshevik <a href="/wiki/Shooting_of_the_Romanov_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Shooting of the Romanov family">execution of the Tsar and his family</a> in July 1918. Legionaries arrived less than a week afterwards and captured the city. Because Russia's European ports were not safe, the corps was evacuated by a long detour via the port of Vladivostok. The last transport was the American ship Heffron in September 1920.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Central_Powers_peace_overtures">Central Powers peace overtures</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:River_Crossing_NGM-v31-p338.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/River_Crossing_NGM-v31-p338.jpg/220px-River_Crossing_NGM-v31-p338.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/River_Crossing_NGM-v31-p338.jpg/330px-River_Crossing_NGM-v31-p338.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/River_Crossing_NGM-v31-p338.jpg/440px-River_Crossing_NGM-v31-p338.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1552" data-file-height="1132" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:River_Crossing_NGM-v31-p338.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"<i><a href="/wiki/They_shall_not_pass" title="They shall not pass">They shall not pass</a>"</i>, a phrase typically associated with the defence of Verdun</div></div></div>
<p>On 12 December 1916, after ten brutal months of the Battle of Verdun and a <a href="/wiki/Romania_during_World_War_I#The_counteroffensive_of_the_Central_Powers_(September–December_1916)" title="Romania during World War I">successful offensive against Romania</a>, Germany attempted to negotiate a peace with the Allies.<sup id="cite_ref-lanoszka_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lanoszka-176">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> However, this attempt was rejected out of hand as a "duplicitous war ruse".<sup id="cite_ref-lanoszka_176-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lanoszka-176">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Soon after, the US President, Woodrow Wilson, attempted to intervene as a peacemaker, asking in a note for both sides to state their demands. <a href="/wiki/David_Lloyd_George" title="David Lloyd George">Lloyd George's</a> War Cabinet considered the German offer to be a ploy to create divisions amongst the Allies. After initial outrage and much deliberation, they took Wilson's note as a separate effort, signalling that the United States was on the verge of entering the war against Germany following the "submarine outrages". While the Allies debated a response to Wilson's offer, the Germans chose to rebuff it in favour of "a direct exchange of views". Learning of the German response, the Allied governments were free to make clear demands in their response of 14 January. They sought restoration of damages, the evacuation of occupied territories, reparations for France, Russia and Romania, and a recognition of the principle of nationalities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan1998345_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan1998345-177">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> This included the liberation of Italians, Slavs, Romanians, Czecho-Slovaks, and the creation of a "free and united Poland".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan1998345_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan1998345-177">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> On the question of security, the Allies sought guarantees that would prevent or limit future wars, complete with sanctions, as a condition of any peace settlement.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKernek1970721–766_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKernek1970721–766-178">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> The negotiations failed and the Entente powers rejected the German offer on the grounds that Germany had not put forward any specific proposals.
</p>
<h3><span id="1917.E2.80.931918"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1917–1918">1917–1918</span></h3>
<p>Events of 1917 proved decisive in ending the war, although their effects were not fully felt until 1918.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Developments_in_1917">Developments in 1917</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Guetteur_au_poste_de_l%27%C3%A9cluse_26.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Guetteur_au_poste_de_l%27%C3%A9cluse_26.jpg/170px-Guetteur_au_poste_de_l%27%C3%A9cluse_26.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Guetteur_au_poste_de_l%27%C3%A9cluse_26.jpg/255px-Guetteur_au_poste_de_l%27%C3%A9cluse_26.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Guetteur_au_poste_de_l%27%C3%A9cluse_26.jpg/340px-Guetteur_au_poste_de_l%27%C3%A9cluse_26.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="853" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Guetteur_au_poste_de_l%27%C3%A9cluse_26.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>French Army lookout at his observation post, <a href="/wiki/Haut-Rhin" title="Haut-Rhin">Haut-Rhin</a>, France, 1917</div></div></div>
<p>The British naval blockade began to have a serious impact on Germany. In response, in February 1917, the <a href="/wiki/German_General_Staff" title="German General Staff">German General Staff</a> convinced <a href="/wiki/Chancellor" title="Chancellor">Chancellor</a> Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg to declare unrestricted submarine warfare, with the goal of starving Britain out of the war. German planners estimated that unrestricted submarine warfare would cost Britain a monthly shipping loss of 600,000 tons. The General Staff acknowledged that the policy would almost certainly bring the United States into the conflict, but calculated that British shipping losses would be so high that they would be forced to sue for peace after five to six months, before American intervention could have an effect. Tonnage sunk rose above 500,000&#160;tons per month from February to July. It peaked at 860,000&#160;tons in April. After July, the newly re-introduced <a href="/wiki/Convoy" title="Convoy">convoy</a> system became effective in reducing the U-boat threat. Britain was safe from starvation, while German industrial output fell, and the United States joined the war far earlier than Germany had anticipated.
</p><p>On 3 May 1917, during the Nivelle Offensive, the French 2nd Colonial Division, veterans of the Battle of Verdun, refused orders, arriving drunk and without their weapons. Their officers lacked the means to punish an entire division, and harsh measures were not immediately implemented. The French Army Mutinies eventually spread to a further 54 French divisions, and 20,000 men deserted. However, appeals to patriotism and duty, as well as mass arrests and trials, encouraged the soldiers to return to defend their trenches, although the French soldiers refused to participate in further offensive action.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Robert_Nivelle" title="Robert Nivelle">Robert Nivelle</a> was removed from command by 15 May, replaced by General <a href="/wiki/Philippe_P%C3%A9tain" title="Philippe Pétain">Philippe Pétain</a>, who suspended bloody large-scale attacks.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1983-0323-501,_Kriegskinematograph_im_Sch%C3%BCtzengraben.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1983-0323-501%2C_Kriegskinematograph_im_Sch%C3%BCtzengraben.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1983-0323-501%2C_Kriegskinematograph_im_Sch%C3%BCtzengraben.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1983-0323-501%2C_Kriegskinematograph_im_Sch%C3%BCtzengraben.jpg/330px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1983-0323-501%2C_Kriegskinematograph_im_Sch%C3%BCtzengraben.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1983-0323-501%2C_Kriegskinematograph_im_Sch%C3%BCtzengraben.jpg/440px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1983-0323-501%2C_Kriegskinematograph_im_Sch%C3%BCtzengraben.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="544" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1983-0323-501,_Kriegskinematograph_im_Sch%C3%BCtzengraben.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>German film crew recording the action</div></div></div>
<p>The victory of the Central Powers at the Battle of Caporetto led the Allies to convene the <a href="/wiki/Rapallo_Conference" title="Rapallo Conference">Rapallo Conference</a> at which they formed the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_War_Council" title="Supreme War Council">Supreme War Council</a> to co-ordinate planning. Previously, British and French armies had operated under separate commands.
</p><p>In December, the Central Powers signed an armistice with Russia, thus freeing large numbers of German troops for use in the west. With German reinforcements and new American troops pouring in, the outcome was to be decided on the Western Front. The Central Powers knew that they could not win a protracted war, but they held high hopes for success based on a final quick offensive. Furthermore, both sides became increasingly fearful of social unrest and revolution in Europe. Thus, both sides urgently sought a decisive victory.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeyman1997146–147_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeyman1997146–147-180">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1917, Emperor <a href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_Austria" title="Charles I of Austria">Charles I of Austria</a> secretly attempted separate peace negotiations with Clemenceau, through his wife's brother <a href="/wiki/Prince_Sixtus_of_Bourbon-Parma" title="Prince Sixtus of Bourbon-Parma">Sixtus</a> in Belgium as an intermediary, without the knowledge of Germany. Italy opposed the proposals. When the negotiations failed, his attempt was revealed to Germany, resulting in a diplomatic catastrophe.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKurlander2006_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKurlander2006-181">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShanafelt1985125–130_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShanafelt1985125–130-182">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Ottoman_Empire_conflict.2C_1917.E2.80.931918"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_Empire_conflict,_1917–1918">Ottoman Empire conflict, 1917–1918</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">Sinai and Palestine Campaign</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_howitzer_10.5cm_leFH_98_09_LOC_00121.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Turkish_howitzer_10.5cm_leFH_98_09_LOC_00121.jpg/220px-Turkish_howitzer_10.5cm_leFH_98_09_LOC_00121.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Turkish_howitzer_10.5cm_leFH_98_09_LOC_00121.jpg/330px-Turkish_howitzer_10.5cm_leFH_98_09_LOC_00121.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Turkish_howitzer_10.5cm_leFH_98_09_LOC_00121.jpg/440px-Turkish_howitzer_10.5cm_leFH_98_09_LOC_00121.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2360" data-file-height="1466" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_howitzer_10.5cm_leFH_98_09_LOC_00121.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/10.5_cm_Feldhaubitze_98/09" title="10.5 cm Feldhaubitze 98/09">10.5 cm Feldhaubitze 98/09</a> and Ottoman artillerymen at Hareira in 1917 before the Southern Palestine offensive</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Capture_of_Jerusalem_1917d.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Capture_of_Jerusalem_1917d.jpg/220px-Capture_of_Jerusalem_1917d.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="118" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Capture_of_Jerusalem_1917d.jpg/330px-Capture_of_Jerusalem_1917d.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Capture_of_Jerusalem_1917d.jpg/440px-Capture_of_Jerusalem_1917d.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2433" data-file-height="1305" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Capture_of_Jerusalem_1917d.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British artillery battery on <a href="/wiki/Mount_Scopus" title="Mount Scopus">Mount Scopus</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jerusalem_(1917)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Jerusalem (1917)">Battle of Jerusalem</a>, 1917. Foreground, a battery of 16 heavy guns. Background, conical tents and support vehicles.</div></div></div>
<p>In March and April 1917, at the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Gaza" title="First Battle of Gaza">First</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Gaza" title="Second Battle of Gaza">Second Battles of Gaza</a>, German and Ottoman forces stopped the advance of the Egyptian Expeditionary Force, which had begun in August 1916 at the Battle of Romani.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup>
At the end of October, the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">Sinai and Palestine Campaign</a> resumed, when General <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Allenby,_1st_Viscount_Allenby" title="Edmund Allenby, 1st Viscount Allenby">Edmund Allenby</a>'s <a href="/wiki/XX_Corps_(United_Kingdom)" title="XX Corps (United Kingdom)">XXth Corps</a>, <a href="/wiki/XXI_Corps_(United_Kingdom)" title="XXI Corps (United Kingdom)">XXI Corps</a> and <a href="/wiki/Desert_Mounted_Corps" title="Desert Mounted Corps">Desert Mounted Corps</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Beersheba_(1917)" title="Battle of Beersheba (1917)">Battle of Beersheba</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup> Two Ottoman armies were defeated a few weeks later at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mughar_Ridge" title="Battle of Mughar Ridge">Battle of Mughar Ridge</a> and, early in December, <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> was captured following another Ottoman defeat at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jerusalem_(1917)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Jerusalem (1917)">Battle of Jerusalem</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> About this time, <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Freiherr_Kress_von_Kressenstein" title="Friedrich Freiherr Kress von Kressenstein">Friedrich Freiherr Kress von Kressenstein</a> was relieved of his duties as the Eighth Army's commander, replaced by <a href="/wiki/Cevat_%C3%87obanl%C4%B1" title="Cevat Çobanlı">Djevad Pasha</a>, and a few months later the commander of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Army">Ottoman Army</a> in Palestine, <a href="/wiki/Erich_von_Falkenhayn" title="Erich von Falkenhayn">Erich von Falkenhayn</a>, was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Otto_Liman_von_Sanders" title="Otto Liman von Sanders">Otto Liman von Sanders</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ottoman_soldiers_WWI.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Ottoman_soldiers_WWI.jpg/220px-Ottoman_soldiers_WWI.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Ottoman_soldiers_WWI.jpg/330px-Ottoman_soldiers_WWI.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Ottoman_soldiers_WWI.jpg/440px-Ottoman_soldiers_WWI.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3645" data-file-height="2479" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ottoman_soldiers_WWI.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ottoman troops during the <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamian_campaign" title="Mesopotamian campaign">Mesopotamian campaign</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:British_Troops_Marching_in_Mesopotamia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/British_Troops_Marching_in_Mesopotamia.jpg/220px-British_Troops_Marching_in_Mesopotamia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="184" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/British_Troops_Marching_in_Mesopotamia.jpg/330px-British_Troops_Marching_in_Mesopotamia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/British_Troops_Marching_in_Mesopotamia.jpg/440px-British_Troops_Marching_in_Mesopotamia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1338" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:British_Troops_Marching_in_Mesopotamia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British troops on the march during the <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamian_campaign" title="Mesopotamian campaign">Mesopotamian campaign</a>, 1917</div></div></div>
<p>In early 1918, the front line was <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Jericho_(1918)" class="mw-redirect" title="Capture of Jericho (1918)">extended</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Jordan_Valley_(1918)" class="mw-redirect" title="Occupation of the Jordan Valley (1918)">Jordan Valley</a> was occupied, following the <a href="/wiki/First_Transjordan_attack_on_Amman" title="First Transjordan attack on Amman">First Transjordan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Second_Transjordan_attack_on_Shunet_Nimrin_and_Es_Salt_(1918)" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Transjordan attack on Shunet Nimrin and Es Salt (1918)">Second Transjordan</a> attacks by British Empire forces in March and April 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> In March, most of the Egyptian Expeditionary Force's British infantry and <a href="/wiki/Yeomanry" title="Yeomanry">Yeomanry</a> cavalry were sent to the Western Front as a consequence of the Spring Offensive. They were replaced by Indian Army units. During several months of reorganisation and training of the summer, a <a href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign#Summer_front_line_operations" class="mw-redirect" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">number of attacks</a> were carried out on sections of the Ottoman front line. These pushed the front line north to more advantageous positions for the Entente in preparation for an attack and to acclimatise the newly arrived Indian Army infantry. It was not until the middle of September that the integrated force was ready for large-scale operations.
</p><p>The reorganised Egyptian Expeditionary Force, with an additional mounted division, broke Ottoman forces at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Megiddo_(1918)" title="Battle of Megiddo (1918)">Battle of Megiddo</a> in September 1918. In two days the British and Indian infantry, supported by a creeping barrage, broke the Ottoman front line and captured the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Eighth_Army_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Eighth Army (Ottoman Empire)">Eighth Army (Ottoman Empire)</a> at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tulkarm_(1918)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Tulkarm (1918)">Tulkarm</a>, the continuous trench lines at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tabsor_(1918)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Tabsor (1918)">Tabsor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Arara" title="Battle of Arara">Arara</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Army_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Seventh Army (Ottoman Empire)">Seventh Army (Ottoman Empire)</a> headquarters at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nablus_(1918)" title="Battle of Nablus (1918)">Nablus</a>. The Desert Mounted Corps rode through the break in the front line created by the infantry. During virtually continuous operations by <a href="/wiki/Australian_Light_Horse" title="Australian Light Horse">Australian Light Horse</a>, British mounted Yeomanry, Indian <a href="/wiki/Lancers" class="mw-redirect" title="Lancers">Lancers</a>, and New Zealand <a href="/wiki/Mounted_Riflemen" class="mw-redirect" title="Mounted Riflemen">Mounted Rifle</a> brigades in the <a href="/wiki/Jezreel_Valley" title="Jezreel Valley">Jezreel Valley</a>, they captured <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nazareth_(1918)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Nazareth (1918)">Nazareth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Afulah_and_Beisan" title="Capture of Afulah and Beisan">Afulah and Beisan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Jenin_(1918)" class="mw-redirect" title="Capture of Jenin (1918)">Jenin</a>, along with <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Haifa_(1918)" title="Battle of Haifa (1918)">Haifa</a> on the Mediterranean coast and <a href="/wiki/Daraa" title="Daraa">Daraa</a> east of the Jordan River on the Hejaz railway. <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Samakh_(1918)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Samakh (1918)">Samakh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a> were captured on the way northwards to <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a>. Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/Third_Transjordan_attack" title="Third Transjordan attack">Chaytor's Force</a> of Australian light horse, New Zealand mounted rifles, Indian, British West Indies and Jewish infantry captured the crossings of the <a href="/wiki/Jordan_River" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salt,_Jordan" class="mw-redirect" title="Salt, Jordan">Es Salt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amman" title="Amman">Amman</a> and at Ziza most of the <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Army_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Fourth Army (Ottoman Empire)">Fourth Army (Ottoman Empire)</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros" title="Armistice of Mudros">Armistice of Mudros</a>, signed at the end of October, ended hostilities with the Ottoman Empire when fighting was continuing north of <a href="/wiki/Aleppo" title="Aleppo">Aleppo</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="15_August_1917:_Peace_offer_by_the_Pope">15 August 1917: Peace offer by the Pope</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XV#Peace_efforts" title="Pope Benedict XV">Pope Benedict XV §&#160;Peace efforts</a></div>
<p>On or shortly before 15 August 1917 <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XV" title="Pope Benedict XV">Pope Benedict XV</a> made a peace proposal<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> suggesting:
</p>
<ul><li>No annexations</li>
<li>No indemnities, except to compensate for severe war damage in Belgium and parts of France and of Serbia</li>
<li>A solution to the problems of <a href="/wiki/Alsace-Lorraine" title="Alsace-Lorraine">Alsace-Lorraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trentino" title="Trentino">Trentino</a> and <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a></li>
<li>Restoration of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_Poland" title="Congress Poland">Kingdom of Poland</a></li>
<li>Germany to pull out of Belgium and France</li>
<li>Germany's overseas colonies to be returned to Germany</li>
<li>General disarmament</li>
<li>A Supreme Court of arbitration to settle future disputes between nations</li>
<li>The freedom of the seas</li>
<li>Abolish all retaliatory economic conflicts</li>
<li>No point in ordering reparations, because so much damage had been caused to all belligerents</li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Entry_of_the_United_States">Entry of the United States</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_I" title="American entry into World War I">American entry into World War I</a></div>
<p>At the outbreak of the war, the United States pursued a policy of <a href="/wiki/Non-intervention" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-intervention">non-intervention</a>, avoiding conflict while trying to broker a peace. When the German U-boat <a href="/wiki/SM_U-20_(Germany)" title="SM U-20 (Germany)"><i>U-20</i></a> <a href="/wiki/Sinking_of_the_RMS_Lusitania" title="Sinking of the RMS Lusitania">sank the British liner RMS <i>Lusitania</i></a> on 7<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>May 1915 with 128 Americans among the dead, President <a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson" title="Woodrow Wilson">Woodrow Wilson</a> insisted that America is "too proud to fight" but demanded an end to attacks on passenger ships. Germany complied. Wilson unsuccessfully tried to mediate a settlement. However, he also repeatedly warned that the United States would not tolerate unrestricted submarine warfare, in violation of international law. Former president <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> denounced German acts as "piracy".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrands1997756_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrands1997756-193">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> Wilson was narrowly re-elected in <a href="/wiki/1916_United_States_presidential_election" title="1916 United States presidential election">1916</a> after campaigning with the slogan "he kept us out of war".<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USA_bryter_de_diplomatiska_f%C3%B6rbindelserna_med_Tyskland_3_februari_1917.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/USA_bryter_de_diplomatiska_f%C3%B6rbindelserna_med_Tyskland_3_februari_1917.jpg/220px-USA_bryter_de_diplomatiska_f%C3%B6rbindelserna_med_Tyskland_3_februari_1917.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="161" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/USA_bryter_de_diplomatiska_f%C3%B6rbindelserna_med_Tyskland_3_februari_1917.jpg/330px-USA_bryter_de_diplomatiska_f%C3%B6rbindelserna_med_Tyskland_3_februari_1917.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/USA_bryter_de_diplomatiska_f%C3%B6rbindelserna_med_Tyskland_3_februari_1917.jpg/440px-USA_bryter_de_diplomatiska_f%C3%B6rbindelserna_med_Tyskland_3_februari_1917.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1185" data-file-height="867" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:USA_bryter_de_diplomatiska_f%C3%B6rbindelserna_med_Tyskland_3_februari_1917.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson" title="Woodrow Wilson">President Wilson</a> before Congress, announcing the break in official relations with Germany on 3 February 1917</div></div></div>
<p>In January 1917, Germany decided to resume unrestricted submarine warfare, in the hopes of starving Britain into surrender. Germany did this realising it would mean American entry. The German Foreign Minister, in the <a href="/wiki/Zimmermann_Telegram" title="Zimmermann Telegram">Zimmermann Telegram</a>, invited Mexico to join the war as Germany's ally against the United States. In return, the Germans would finance Mexico's war and help it recover the territories of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuchman1966_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuchman1966-197">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup> The United Kingdom intercepted the message and presented it to the US embassy in the UK. From there it made its way to President Wilson who released the Zimmermann note to the public, and Americans saw it as <i><a href="/wiki/Casus_belli" title="Casus belli">casus belli</a></i>. Wilson called on anti-war elements to end all wars, by winning this one and eliminating militarism from the globe. He argued that the war was so important that the US had to have a voice in the peace conference.<sup id="cite_ref-Karp-PoW-1979_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Karp-PoW-1979-198">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> After the sinking of seven US merchant ships by submarines and the publication of the Zimmermann telegram, Wilson called for war on Germany on 2<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>April 1917,<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> which the <a href="/wiki/US_Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="US Congress">US Congress</a> <a href="/wiki/United_States_declaration_of_war_on_Germany_(1917)" title="United States declaration of war on Germany (1917)">declared 4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>days later</a>.
</p><p>The United States was never formally a member of the Allies but became a self-styled "Associated Power". The United States had a small army, but, after the passage of the <a href="/wiki/Selective_Service_Act_of_1917" title="Selective Service Act of 1917">Selective Service Act</a>, it drafted 2.8&#160;million men,<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> and, by summer 1918, was sending 10,000 fresh soldiers to France every day. In 1917, the US Congress granted US citizenship to Puerto Ricans to allow them to be drafted to participate in World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Jones%E2%80%93Shafroth_Act" title="Jones–Shafroth Act">Jones–Shafroth Act</a>. German General Staff assumptions that it would be able to defeat the British and French forces before American troops reinforced them were proven incorrect.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy" title="United States Navy">United States Navy</a> sent a <a href="/wiki/United_States_Battleship_Division_Nine_(World_War_I)" title="United States Battleship Division Nine (World War I)">battleship group</a> to <a href="/wiki/Scapa_Flow" title="Scapa Flow">Scapa Flow</a> to join with the British Grand Fleet, destroyers to <a href="/wiki/Cobh" title="Cobh">Queenstown</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarines</a> to help guard convoys. Several regiments of <a href="/wiki/US_Marines" class="mw-redirect" title="US Marines">US Marines</a> were also dispatched to France. The British and French wanted American units used to reinforce their troops already on the battle lines and not waste scarce shipping on bringing over supplies. General <a href="/wiki/John_J._Pershing" title="John J. Pershing">John J. Pershing</a>, <a href="/wiki/American_Expeditionary_Forces" title="American Expeditionary Forces">American Expeditionary Forces</a> (AEF) commander, refused to break up American units to be used as filler material. As an exception, he did allow African-American combat regiments to be used in French divisions. The <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Hellfighters" class="mw-redirect" title="Harlem Hellfighters">Harlem Hellfighters</a> fought as part of the French 16th Division, and earned a unit <a href="/wiki/Croix_de_guerre_1914%E2%80%931918_(France)" title="Croix de guerre 1914–1918 (France)">Croix de Guerre</a> for their actions at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ch%C3%A2teau-Thierry_(1918)" title="Battle of Château-Thierry (1918)">Château-Thierry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Belleau_Wood" title="Battle of Belleau Wood">Belleau Wood</a>, and Sechault.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup> AEF doctrine called for the use of frontal assaults, which had long since been discarded by British Empire and French commanders due to the large loss of life that resulted.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMillettMurray1988143_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMillettMurray1988143-203">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="German_Spring_Offensive_of_1918">German Spring Offensive of 1918</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Spring_Offensive" title="Spring Offensive">Spring Offensive</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:General_gouraud_french_army_world_war_i_machinegun_marne_1918.JPEG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/General_gouraud_french_army_world_war_i_machinegun_marne_1918.JPEG/220px-General_gouraud_french_army_world_war_i_machinegun_marne_1918.JPEG" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/General_gouraud_french_army_world_war_i_machinegun_marne_1918.JPEG/330px-General_gouraud_french_army_world_war_i_machinegun_marne_1918.JPEG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/General_gouraud_french_army_world_war_i_machinegun_marne_1918.JPEG/440px-General_gouraud_french_army_world_war_i_machinegun_marne_1918.JPEG 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2097" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:General_gouraud_french_army_world_war_i_machinegun_marne_1918.JPEG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>French soldiers under <a href="/wiki/Henri_Gouraud_(French_Army_officer)" class="mw-redirect" title="Henri Gouraud (French Army officer)">General Gouraud</a>, with machine guns amongst the ruins of a cathedral near the <a href="/wiki/Marne_(river)" title="Marne (river)">Marne</a>, 1918</div></div></div>
<p>Ludendorff drew up plans (<a href="/wiki/Code_name" title="Code name">codenamed</a> <a href="/wiki/Operation_Michael" title="Operation Michael">Operation Michael</a>) for the 1918 offensive on the Western Front. The Spring Offensive sought to divide the British and French forces with a series of feints and advances. The German leadership hoped to end the war before significant US forces arrived. The operation commenced on 21 March 1918 with an attack on British forces near <a href="/wiki/Saint-Quentin,_Aisne" title="Saint-Quentin, Aisne">Saint-Quentin</a>. German forces achieved an unprecedented advance of 60 kilometres (37&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWestwell2004_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWestwell2004-204">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>British and French trenches were penetrated using novel <a href="/wiki/Infiltration_tactics" title="Infiltration tactics">infiltration tactics</a>, also named <i>Hutier</i> tactics after General <a href="/wiki/Oskar_von_Hutier" title="Oskar von Hutier">Oskar von Hutier</a>, by specially trained units called <a href="/wiki/Stosstruppen" class="mw-redirect" title="Stosstruppen">stormtroopers</a>. Previously, attacks had been characterised by long artillery bombardments and massed assaults. In the Spring Offensive of 1918, however, Ludendorff used artillery only briefly and infiltrated small groups of infantry at weak points. They attacked command and logistics areas and bypassed points of serious resistance. More heavily armed infantry then destroyed these isolated positions. This German success relied greatly on the element of surprise.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPosen1984190_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPosen1984190-205">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Template:Harvard_citation_documentation#Wikilink_to_citation_does_not_work" title="Template:Harvard citation documentation"><span title="Template:Harvard citation documentation#Wikilink to citation does not work">citation not found</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:British_55th_Division_gas_casualties_10_April_1918.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/British_55th_Division_gas_casualties_10_April_1918.jpg/220px-British_55th_Division_gas_casualties_10_April_1918.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/British_55th_Division_gas_casualties_10_April_1918.jpg/330px-British_55th_Division_gas_casualties_10_April_1918.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/British_55th_Division_gas_casualties_10_April_1918.jpg/440px-British_55th_Division_gas_casualties_10_April_1918.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="743" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:British_55th_Division_gas_casualties_10_April_1918.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British <a href="/wiki/55th_(West_Lancashire)_Infantry_Division" title="55th (West Lancashire) Infantry Division">55th Division</a> soldiers blinded by tear gas during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Lys_(1918)" title="Battle of the Lys (1918)">Battle of Estaires</a>, 10 April 1918</div></div></div>
<p>The front moved to within 120 kilometres (75&#160;mi) of Paris. Three heavy <a href="/wiki/Krupp" title="Krupp">Krupp</a> <a href="/wiki/Railway_gun" title="Railway gun">railway guns</a> fired 183&#160;shells on the capital, causing many Parisians to flee. The initial offensive was so successful that Kaiser Wilhelm II declared 24 March a <a href="/wiki/Public_holiday" title="Public holiday">national holiday</a>. Many Germans thought victory was near. After heavy fighting, however, the offensive was halted. Lacking tanks or <a href="/wiki/Self-propelled_artillery" title="Self-propelled artillery">motorised artillery</a>, the Germans were unable to consolidate their gains. The problems of re-supply were also exacerbated by increasing distances that now stretched over terrain that was shell-torn and often impassable to traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGray199186_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGray199186-206">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Foch" title="Ferdinand Foch">General Foch</a> pressed to use the arriving American troops as individual replacements, whereas Pershing sought to field American units as an independent force. These units were assigned to the depleted French and British Empire commands on 28 March. A Supreme War Council of Allied forces was created at the <a href="/wiki/Doullens_Conference" title="Doullens Conference">Doullens Conference</a> on 5<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November 1917. General Foch was appointed as supreme commander of the Allied forces. Haig, Petain, and Pershing retained tactical control of their respective armies; Foch assumed a co-ordinating rather than a directing role, and the British, French, and US commands operated largely independently.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMoon1996495–196_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoon1996495–196-207">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Following Operation Michael, Germany launched <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Lys_(1918)" title="Battle of the Lys (1918)">Operation Georgette</a> against the northern <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> ports. The Allies halted the drive after limited territorial gains by Germany. The German Army to the south then conducted <a href="/wiki/Third_Battle_of_the_Aisne" title="Third Battle of the Aisne">Operations Blücher and Yorck</a>, pushing broadly towards Paris. Germany launched Operation Marne (<a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_the_Marne" title="Second Battle of the Marne">Second Battle of the Marne</a>) on 15 July, in an attempt to encircle <a href="/wiki/Reims" title="Reims">Reims</a>. The resulting counter-attack, which started the <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days_Offensive" title="Hundred Days Offensive">Hundred Days Offensive</a>, marked the first successful Allied offensive of the war. By 20 July, the Germans had retreated across the Marne to their starting lines,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERickard2007_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERickard2007-208">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> having achieved little, and the German Army never regained the initiative. German casualties between March and April 1918 were 270,000, including many highly trained stormtroopers.
</p><p>Meanwhile, Germany was falling apart at home. <a href="/wiki/Anti-war" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-war">Anti-war</a> marches became frequent and morale in the army fell. Industrial output was half the 1913 levels.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="New_states_enter_the_war">New states enter the war</span></h4>
<p>In the late spring of 1918, three new states were formed in the <a href="/wiki/South_Caucasus" class="mw-redirect" title="South Caucasus">South Caucasus</a>: the <a href="/wiki/First_Republic_of_Armenia" title="First Republic of Armenia">First Republic of Armenia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan_Democratic_Republic" title="Azerbaijan Democratic Republic">Azerbaijan Democratic Republic</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Georgia" title="Democratic Republic of Georgia">Democratic Republic of Georgia</a>, which declared their independence from the Russian Empire. Two other minor entities were established, the <a href="/wiki/Centrocaspian_Dictatorship" title="Centrocaspian Dictatorship">Centrocaspian Dictatorship</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_West_Caucasian_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="South West Caucasian Republic">South West Caucasian Republic</a> (the former was liquidated by Azerbaijan in the autumn of 1918 and the latter by a joint Armenian-British task force in early 1919). With the withdrawal of the Russian armies from the Caucasus front in the winter of 1917–18, the three major republics braced for an imminent Ottoman advance, which commenced in the early months of 1918. Solidarity was briefly maintained when the <a href="/wiki/Transcaucasian_Democratic_Federative_Republic" title="Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic">Transcaucasian Federative Republic</a> was created in the spring of 1918, but this collapsed in May, when the Georgians <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Poti" title="Treaty of Poti">asked for and received protection</a> from Germany and the Azerbaijanis concluded a treaty with the Ottoman Empire that was more akin to a military alliance. Armenia was left to fend for itself and struggled for five months against the threat of a full-fledged occupation by the Ottoman Turks before defeating them at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sardarabad" title="Battle of Sardarabad">Battle of Sardarabad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHovannisian19671–39_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHovannisian19671–39-209">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Allied_victory:_summer_1918_onwards">Allied victory: summer 1918 onwards</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hundred_Days_Offensive">Hundred Days Offensive</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days_Offensive" title="Hundred Days Offensive">Hundred Days Offensive</a> and <a href="/wiki/Weimar_Republic" title="Weimar Republic">Weimar Republic</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Riflemen-1918-Western-Front.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Riflemen-1918-Western-Front.png/200px-Riflemen-1918-Western-Front.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Riflemen-1918-Western-Front.png/300px-Riflemen-1918-Western-Front.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Riflemen-1918-Western-Front.png/400px-Riflemen-1918-Western-Front.png 2x" data-file-width="636" data-file-height="471" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Riflemen-1918-Western-Front.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Between April and November 1918, the Allies increased their front-line rifle strength while German strength fell by half.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAyers1919104_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAyers1919104-210">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_ruins_of_Vaux,_France,_1918,_ca._03-1918_-_ca._11-1918_-_NARA_-_512862.tif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Aerial_view_of_ruins_of_Vaux%2C_France%2C_1918%2C_ca._03-1918_-_ca._11-1918_-_NARA_-_512862.tif/lossy-page1-200px-Aerial_view_of_ruins_of_Vaux%2C_France%2C_1918%2C_ca._03-1918_-_ca._11-1918_-_NARA_-_512862.tif.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Aerial_view_of_ruins_of_Vaux%2C_France%2C_1918%2C_ca._03-1918_-_ca._11-1918_-_NARA_-_512862.tif/lossy-page1-300px-Aerial_view_of_ruins_of_Vaux%2C_France%2C_1918%2C_ca._03-1918_-_ca._11-1918_-_NARA_-_512862.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Aerial_view_of_ruins_of_Vaux%2C_France%2C_1918%2C_ca._03-1918_-_ca._11-1918_-_NARA_-_512862.tif/lossy-page1-400px-Aerial_view_of_ruins_of_Vaux%2C_France%2C_1918%2C_ca._03-1918_-_ca._11-1918_-_NARA_-_512862.tif.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2257" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_ruins_of_Vaux,_France,_1918,_ca._03-1918_-_ca._11-1918_-_NARA_-_512862.tif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Aerial view of ruins of <a href="/wiki/Vaux-devant-Damloup" title="Vaux-devant-Damloup">Vaux-devant-Damloup</a>, France, 1918</div></div></div>
<p>The Allied counteroffensive, known as the Hundred Days Offensive, began on 8<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August 1918, with the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Amiens_(1918)" title="Battle of Amiens (1918)">Battle of Amiens</a>. The battle involved over 400 tanks and 120,000 British, <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">Dominion</a>, and French troops, and by the end of its first day a gap 24 kilometres (15&#160;mi) long had been created in the German lines. The defenders displayed a marked collapse in morale, causing Ludendorff to refer to this day as the "Black Day of the German army".<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERickard2001_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERickard2001-212">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> After an advance as far as 23 kilometres (14&#160;mi), German resistance stiffened, and the battle was concluded on 12 August.
</p><p>Rather than continuing the Amiens battle past the point of initial success, as had been done so many times in the past, the Allies shifted attention elsewhere. Allied leaders had now realised that to continue an attack after resistance had hardened was a waste of lives, and it was better to turn a line than to try to roll over it. They began to undertake attacks in quick order to take advantage of successful advances on the flanks, then broke them off when each attack lost its initial impetus.<sup id="cite_ref-Pitt-1962_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pitt-1962-214">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The day after the Offensive began, Ludendorff said: "We cannot win the war any more, but we must not lose it either." On 11 August he offered his resignation to the Kaiser, who refused it, replying, "I see that we must strike a balance. We have nearly reached the limit of our powers of resistance. The war must be ended." On 13 August, at <a href="/wiki/Spa,_Belgium" title="Spa, Belgium">Spa</a>, Hindenburg, Ludendorff, the Chancellor, and Foreign Minister Hintz agreed that the war could not be ended militarily and, on the following day, the German Crown Council decided that victory in the field was now most improbable. Austria and Hungary warned that they could continue the war only until December, and Ludendorff recommended immediate peace negotiations. Prince Rupprecht warned Prince Max of Baden: "Our military situation has deteriorated so rapidly that I no longer believe we can hold out over the winter; it is even possible that a catastrophe will come earlier."<sup id="cite_ref-Chron-FWW_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chron-FWW-215">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Battle_of_Albert">Battle of Albert</span></h5>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Canadian_Scottish_at_Canal_du_Nord_Sept_1918_IWM_CO_3289.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Canadian_Scottish_at_Canal_du_Nord_Sept_1918_IWM_CO_3289.jpg/200px-Canadian_Scottish_at_Canal_du_Nord_Sept_1918_IWM_CO_3289.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Canadian_Scottish_at_Canal_du_Nord_Sept_1918_IWM_CO_3289.jpg/300px-Canadian_Scottish_at_Canal_du_Nord_Sept_1918_IWM_CO_3289.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Canadian_Scottish_at_Canal_du_Nord_Sept_1918_IWM_CO_3289.jpg/400px-Canadian_Scottish_at_Canal_du_Nord_Sept_1918_IWM_CO_3289.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="630" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Canadian_Scottish_at_Canal_du_Nord_Sept_1918_IWM_CO_3289.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/16th_Battalion_(Canadian_Scottish),_CEF" title="16th Battalion (Canadian Scottish), CEF">Canadian Scottish</a>, advancing during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Canal_du_Nord" title="Battle of the Canal du Nord">Battle of the Canal du Nord</a>, 1918</div></div></div>
<p>British and Dominion forces launched the next phase of the campaign with the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Albert_(1918)" title="Battle of Albert (1918)">Battle of Albert</a> on 21 August.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETerraine1963_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETerraine1963-216">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> The assault was widened by French<sup id="cite_ref-Chron-FWW_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chron-FWW-215">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> and then further British forces in the following days. During the last week of August the Allied pressure along a 110-kilometre (68&#160;mi) front against the enemy was heavy and unrelenting. From German accounts, "Each day was spent in bloody fighting against an ever and again on-storming enemy, and nights passed without sleep in retirements to new lines."<sup id="cite_ref-Pitt-1962_214-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pitt-1962-214">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Faced with these advances, on 2 September the German <a href="/wiki/Oberste_Heeresleitung" title="Oberste Heeresleitung">Supreme Army Command</a> issued orders to withdraw in the south to the <a href="/wiki/Hindenburg_Line" title="Hindenburg Line">Hindenburg Line</a>. This ceded without a fight the <a href="/wiki/Salient_(territory)" class="mw-redirect" title="Salient (territory)">salient</a> seized the previous April.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson1962_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson1962-217">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> According to Ludendorff, "We had to admit the necessity&#160;... to withdraw the entire front from the Scarpe to the Vesle.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELudendorff1919_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudendorff1919-218">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> In nearly four weeks of fighting beginning on 8<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August, over 100,000 German prisoners were taken. The German High Command realised that the war was lost and made attempts to reach a satisfactory end. On 10 September Hindenburg urged peace moves to Emperor Charles of Austria, and Germany appealed to the Netherlands for mediation. On 14 September Austria sent a note to all belligerents and neutrals suggesting a meeting for peace talks on neutral soil, and on 15 September Germany made a peace offer to Belgium. Both peace offers were rejected.<sup id="cite_ref-Chron-FWW_215-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chron-FWW-215">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Allied_advance_to_the_Hindenburg_Line">Allied advance to the Hindenburg Line</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:World_War_I_Observation_Balloon_HD-SN-99-02269.JPEG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/World_War_I_Observation_Balloon_HD-SN-99-02269.JPEG/180px-World_War_I_Observation_Balloon_HD-SN-99-02269.JPEG" decoding="async" width="180" height="280" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/World_War_I_Observation_Balloon_HD-SN-99-02269.JPEG/270px-World_War_I_Observation_Balloon_HD-SN-99-02269.JPEG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/World_War_I_Observation_Balloon_HD-SN-99-02269.JPEG/360px-World_War_I_Observation_Balloon_HD-SN-99-02269.JPEG 2x" data-file-width="1930" data-file-height="3000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:World_War_I_Observation_Balloon_HD-SN-99-02269.JPEG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An American major, piloting an <a href="/wiki/Observation_balloon" title="Observation balloon">observation balloon</a> near the front, 1918</div></div></div>
<p>In September the Allies <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days_Offensive#Advance_to_the_Hindenburg_Line" title="Hundred Days Offensive">advanced to the Hindenburg Line</a> in the north and centre. The Germans continued to fight strong rear-guard actions and launched numerous counterattacks, but positions and outposts of the Line continued to fall, with the BEF alone taking 30,441&#160;prisoners in the last week of September. On 24 September an assault by both the British and French came within 3 kilometres (2&#160;mi) of St. Quentin. The Germans had now retreated to positions along or behind the Hindenburg Line. That same day, Supreme Army Command informed the leaders in Berlin that armistice talks were inevitable.<sup id="cite_ref-Chron-FWW_215-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chron-FWW-215">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days_Offensive#Battles_of_the_Hindenburg_Line" title="Hundred Days Offensive">final assault</a> on the Hindenburg Line began with the <a href="/wiki/Meuse-Argonne_Offensive" class="mw-redirect" title="Meuse-Argonne Offensive">Meuse-Argonne Offensive</a>, launched by French and American troops on 26 September. The following week, co-operating French and American units broke through in <a href="/wiki/Champagne,_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Champagne, France">Champagne</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Blanc_Mont_Ridge" title="Battle of Blanc Mont Ridge">Battle of Blanc Mont Ridge</a>, forcing the Germans off the commanding heights, and closing towards the Belgian frontier.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLellan49_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLellan49-219">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> On 8<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>October the line was pierced again by British and Dominion troops at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cambrai_(1918)" title="Battle of Cambrai (1918)">Battle of Cambrai</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> The German army had to shorten its front and use the Dutch frontier as an anchor to fight rear-guard actions as it fell back towards Germany.
</p><p>When Bulgaria signed a separate armistice on 29 September, Ludendorff, having been under great stress for months, suffered something similar to a breakdown. It was evident that Germany could no longer mount a successful defence. The collapse of the Balkans meant that Germany was about to lose its main supplies of oil and food. Its reserves had been used up, even as US troops kept arriving at the rate of 10,000 per day.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004380_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004380-221">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHull2006307–310_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHull2006307–310-222">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383-223">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> The Americans supplied more than 80% of Allied oil during the war, and there was no shortage.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPainter201225_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPainter201225-224">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="German_Revolution_1918.E2.80.931919"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="German_Revolution_1918–1919">German Revolution 1918–1919</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R72520,_Kiel,_Novemberrevolution,_Matrosenaufstand.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R72520%2C_Kiel%2C_Novemberrevolution%2C_Matrosenaufstand.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R72520%2C_Kiel%2C_Novemberrevolution%2C_Matrosenaufstand.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="120" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R72520%2C_Kiel%2C_Novemberrevolution%2C_Matrosenaufstand.jpg/330px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R72520%2C_Kiel%2C_Novemberrevolution%2C_Matrosenaufstand.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R72520%2C_Kiel%2C_Novemberrevolution%2C_Matrosenaufstand.jpg/440px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R72520%2C_Kiel%2C_Novemberrevolution%2C_Matrosenaufstand.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="436" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R72520,_Kiel,_Novemberrevolution,_Matrosenaufstand.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/German_Revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="German Revolution">German Revolution</a>, Kiel, 1918</div></div></div>
<p>News of Germany's impending military defeat spread throughout the German armed forces. The threat of mutiny was rife. Admiral Reinhard Scheer and Ludendorff decided to launch a last attempt to restore the "valour" of the German Navy.
</p><p>In northern Germany, the <a href="/wiki/German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%931919" title="German Revolution of 1918–1919">German Revolution of 1918–1919</a> began at the end of October 1918. Units of the German Navy refused to set sail for a last, large-scale operation in a war they believed to be as good as lost, initiating the uprising. The <a href="/wiki/Wilhelmshaven_mutiny" class="mw-redirect" title="Wilhelmshaven mutiny">sailors' revolt</a>, which then ensued in the naval ports of <a href="/wiki/Wilhelmshaven" title="Wilhelmshaven">Wilhelmshaven</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kiel_mutiny" title="Kiel mutiny">Kiel</a>, spread across the whole country within days and led to the proclamation of a republic on 9<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November 1918, shortly thereafter to the abdication of Kaiser Wilhelm II, and to German surrender.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383_223-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383-223">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="New_German_government_surrenders">New German government surrenders</span></h4>
<p>With the military faltering and with widespread loss of confidence in the Kaiser leading to his abdication and fleeing of the country, Germany moved towards surrender. Prince Maximilian of Baden took charge of a new government on 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>October as Chancellor of Germany to negotiate with the Allies. Negotiations with President Wilson began immediately, in the hope that he would offer better terms than the British and French. Wilson demanded a constitutional monarchy and parliamentary control over the German military.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004385_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004385-228">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> There was no resistance when the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany" title="Social Democratic Party of Germany">Social Democrat</a> <a href="/wiki/Philipp_Scheidemann" title="Philipp Scheidemann">Philipp Scheidemann</a> on 9<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November declared Germany to be a republic. The Kaiser, kings and other hereditary rulers all were removed from power and Wilhelm fled to exile in <a href="/wiki/The_Netherlands" class="mw-redirect" title="The Netherlands">the Netherlands</a>. Imperial Germany was dead; a new Germany had been born as the <a href="/wiki/Weimar_Republic" title="Weimar Republic">Weimar Republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004Chapter_17_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004Chapter_17-229">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Armistices_and_capitulations">Armistices and capitulations</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_11_November_1918" title="Armistice of 11 November 1918">Armistice of 11 November 1918</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Trento_3_novembre_1918.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Trento_3_novembre_1918.jpg/200px-Trento_3_novembre_1918.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="130" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Trento_3_novembre_1918.jpg/300px-Trento_3_novembre_1918.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Trento_3_novembre_1918.jpg/400px-Trento_3_novembre_1918.jpg 2x" data-file-width="520" data-file-height="339" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Trento_3_novembre_1918.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Italian troops reach <a href="/wiki/Trento" title="Trento">Trento</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vittorio_Veneto" title="Battle of Vittorio Veneto">Battle of Vittorio Veneto</a>, 1918. Italy's victory marked the end of the war on the Italian Front and secured the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.</div></div></div>
<p>The collapse of the Central Powers came swiftly. Bulgaria was the first to sign an armistice, the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Salonica" title="Armistice of Salonica">Armistice of Salonica</a> on 29 September 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-indiana.edu-1918_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiana.edu-1918-34">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> On 30 October, the Ottoman Empire capitulated, signing the Armistice of Mudros.<sup id="cite_ref-indiana.edu-1918_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiana.edu-1918-34">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:US_64th_regiment_celebrate_the_Armistice.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/US_64th_regiment_celebrate_the_Armistice.jpg/180px-US_64th_regiment_celebrate_the_Armistice.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="113" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/US_64th_regiment_celebrate_the_Armistice.jpg/270px-US_64th_regiment_celebrate_the_Armistice.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/US_64th_regiment_celebrate_the_Armistice.jpg/360px-US_64th_regiment_celebrate_the_Armistice.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="1882" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:US_64th_regiment_celebrate_the_Armistice.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Men of US 64th Regiment, <a href="/wiki/7th_Infantry_Division_(United_States)" title="7th Infantry Division (United States)">7th Infantry Division</a>, celebrate the news of the Armistice, 11 November 1918</div></div></div>
<p>On 24 October, the Italians began a push that rapidly recovered territory lost after the Battle of Caporetto. This culminated in the Battle of Vittorio Veneto, which marked the end of the Austro-Hungarian Army as an effective fighting force. The offensive also triggered the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. During the last week of October, declarations of independence were made in Budapest, Prague, and Zagreb. On 29 October, the imperial authorities asked Italy for an armistice, but the Italians continued advancing, reaching Trento, Udine, and Trieste. On 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November, Austria-Hungary sent a <a href="/wiki/White_flag" title="White flag">flag of truce</a> to ask for an <a href="/wiki/Armistice" title="Armistice">armistice</a> (Armistice of Villa Giusti). The terms, arranged by telegraph with the Allied Authorities in Paris, were communicated to the Austrian commander and accepted. The Armistice with Austria was signed in the Villa Giusti, near <a href="/wiki/Padua" title="Padua">Padua</a>, on 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November. Austria and Hungary signed separate armistices following the overthrow of the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a>. In the following days the Italian Army occupied <a href="/wiki/Innsbruck" title="Innsbruck">Innsbruck</a> and all <a href="/wiki/Tyrol" title="Tyrol">Tyrol</a> with over 20,000 soldiers.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 11 November, at 5:00 am, an <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_11_November_1918" title="Armistice of 11 November 1918">armistice with Germany</a> was signed in a railroad carriage at Compiègne. At 11&#160;am on 11 November 1918—"the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month"—a ceasefire came into effect.
