<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a> of the Ottoman Empire's Armenian population, including mass deportations and executions, during the final years of the Ottoman Empire is considered <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IAGSletter_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IAGSletter-339">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> The Ottomans carried out organised and systematic massacres of the Armenian population at the beginning of the war and portrayed deliberately provoked acts of Armenian resistance as rebellions to justify further extermination.<sup id="cite_ref-leverkun_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-leverkun-340">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> In early 1915, a number of Armenians volunteered to join the Russian forces and the Ottoman government used this as a pretext to issue the <a href="/wiki/Tehcir_Law" title="Tehcir Law">Tehcir Law</a> (Law on Deportation), which authorised the deportation of Armenians from the Empire's eastern provinces to Syria between 1915 and 1918. The Armenians were intentionally <a href="/wiki/Death_march" title="Death march">marched to death</a> and a number were attacked by Ottoman brigands.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerguson2006177_341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerguson2006177-341">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup> While an exact number of deaths is unknown, the <a href="/wiki/International_Association_of_Genocide_Scholars" title="International Association of Genocide Scholars">International Association of Genocide Scholars</a> estimates 1.5&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-IAGSletter_339-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IAGSletter-339">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> The government of Turkey has consistently <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide_denial" title="Armenian Genocide denial">denied the genocide</a>, arguing that those who died were victims of inter-ethnic fighting, famine, or disease during World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I; these claims are rejected by most historians.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFromkin1989212–215_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFromkin1989212–215-343">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Other ethnic groups were similarly attacked by the Ottoman Empire during this period, including Assyrians and <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greeks</a>, and some scholars consider those events to be part of the same policy of extermination.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> At least 250,000 Assyrian Christians, about half of the population, and 350,000–750,000 <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Turkey" title="Greeks in Turkey">Anatolian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Greeks" title="Pontic Greeks">Pontic Greeks</a> were killed between 1915 and 1922.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_Empire">Russian Empire</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Anti-Jewish_pogroms_in_the_Russian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-Jewish pogroms in the Russian Empire">Anti-Jewish pogroms in the Russian Empire</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Urkun" class="mw-redirect" title="Urkun">Urkun</a></div>
<p>Many pogroms accompanied the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> of 1917 and the ensuing Russian Civil War. 60,000–200,000 civilian Jews were killed in the atrocities throughout the former Russian Empire (mostly within the <a href="/wiki/Pale_of_Settlement" title="Pale of Settlement">Pale of Settlement</a> in present-day <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> There were an estimated 7–12 million casualties during the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>, mostly civilians.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rape_of_Belgium">Rape of Belgium</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rape_of_Belgium" title="Rape of Belgium">Rape of Belgium</a></div>
<p>The German invaders treated any resistance—such as sabotaging rail lines—as illegal and immoral, and shot the offenders and burned buildings in retaliation. In addition, they tended to suspect that most civilians were potential <i><a href="/wiki/Francs-tireurs" title="Francs-tireurs">francs-tireurs</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Guerrillas" class="mw-redirect" title="Guerrillas">guerrillas</a>) and, accordingly, took and sometimes killed hostages from among the civilian population. The German army executed over 6,500 French and Belgian civilians between August and November 1914, usually in near-random large-scale shootings of civilians ordered by junior German officers. The German Army destroyed 15,000–20,000 buildings—most famously the university library at <a href="/wiki/Leuven" title="Leuven">Louvain</a>—and generated a wave of refugees of over a million people. Over half the German regiments in Belgium were involved in major incidents.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHorneKramer2001ch_1–2,_esp._p._76_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHorneKramer2001ch_1–2,_esp._p._76-350">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup> Thousands of workers were shipped to Germany to work in factories. British propaganda dramatising the <a href="/wiki/Rape_of_Belgium" title="Rape of Belgium">Rape of Belgium</a> attracted much attention in the United States, while Berlin said it was both lawful and necessary because of the threat of franc-tireurs like those in France in 1870.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup> The British and French magnified the reports and disseminated them at home and in the United States, where they played a major role in dissolving support for Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHorneKramer2001ch_5–8_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHorneKramer2001ch_5–8-352">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeegan199882–83_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeegan199882–83-353">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Soldiers.27_experiences"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Soldiers'_experiences">Soldiers' experiences</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_last_surviving_World_War_I_veterans_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="List of last surviving World War I veterans by country">List of last surviving World War I veterans by country</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">World War I casualties</a>, <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_War_Graves_Commission" title="Commonwealth War Graves Commission">Commonwealth War Graves Commission</a>, and <a href="/wiki/American_Battle_Monuments_Commission" title="American Battle Monuments Commission">American Battle Monuments Commission</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b2/BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg/220px-BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="95" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b2/BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg/330px-BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b2/BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg/440px-BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="347" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BVRC-Great-War-Contingent_1914.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The First Contingent of the <a href="/wiki/Bermuda_Volunteer_Rifle_Corps" title="Bermuda Volunteer Rifle Corps">Bermuda Volunteer Rifle Corps</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Lincolnshire_Regiment" title="Royal Lincolnshire Regiment">1 Lincolns</a>, training in Bermuda for the Western Front, winter 1914–1915. The two BVRC contingents suffered 75% casualties.</div></div></div>
<p>The British soldiers of the war were initially volunteers but increasingly were <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscripted</a> into service. Surviving veterans, returning home, often found they could discuss their experiences only amongst themselves. Grouping together, they formed "veterans' associations" or "Legions". A small number of personal accounts of American veterans have been collected by the <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress" title="Library of Congress">Library of Congress</a> <a href="/wiki/Veterans_History_Project" title="Veterans History Project">Veterans History Project</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prisoners_of_war">Prisoners of war</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_prisoners_of_war_in_Germany" title="World War I prisoners of war in Germany">World War I prisoners of war in Germany</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.,_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif/lossy-page1-220px-German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif/lossy-page1-330px-German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif/lossy-page1-440px-German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.%2C_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2205" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:German_prisoners_in_a_French_prison_camp._French_Pictorial_Service.,_1917_-_1919_-_NARA_-_533724.tif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>German prisoners in a French prison camp during the later part of the war</div></div></div>
<p>About eight million men surrendered and were held in <a href="/wiki/Prisoner-of-war_camp" title="Prisoner-of-war camp">POW camps</a> during the war. All nations pledged to follow the <a href="/wiki/Hague_Conventions_(1899_and_1907)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hague Conventions (1899 and 1907)">Hague Conventions</a> on fair treatment of <a href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Prisoners of war">prisoners of war</a>, and the survival rate for POWs was generally much higher than that of combatants at the front.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhillimoreBellot19194–64_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillimoreBellot19194–64-355">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup> Individual surrenders were uncommon; large units usually surrendered <i>en masse</i>. At the siege of Maubeuge about 40,000 French soldiers surrendered, at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Galicia" title="Battle of Galicia">battle of Galicia</a> Russians took about 100,000 to 120,000 Austrian captives, at the Brusilov Offensive about 325,000 to 417,000 Germans and Austrians surrendered to Russians, and at the Battle of Tannenberg 92,000 Russians surrendered. When the besieged garrison of <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">Kaunas</a> surrendered in 1915, some 20,000 Russians became prisoners, at the battle near <a href="/wiki/Przasnysz" title="Przasnysz">Przasnysz</a> (February–March 1915) 14,000 Germans surrendered to Russians, and at the First Battle of the Marne about 12,000 Germans surrendered to the Allies. 25–31% of Russian losses (as a proportion of those captured, wounded, or killed) were to prisoner status; for Austria-Hungary 32%, for Italy 26%, for France 12%, for Germany 9%; for Britain 7%. Prisoners from the Allied armies totalled about 1.4&#160;million (not including Russia, which lost 2.5–3.5&#160;million men as prisoners). From the Central Powers about 3.3&#160;million men became prisoners; most of them surrendered to Russians.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerguson1999368–369_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerguson1999368–369-356">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup> Germany held 2.5&#160;million prisoners; Russia held 2.2–2.9&#160;million; while Britain and France held about 720,000. Most were captured just before the Armistice. The United States held 48,000. The most dangerous moment was the act of surrender, when helpless soldiers were sometimes gunned down.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlair2005_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlair2005-357">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECook2006637–665_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECook2006637–665-358">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup> Once prisoners reached a camp, conditions were, in general, satisfactory (and much better than in World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>II), thanks in part to the efforts of the <a href="/wiki/International_Red_Cross" class="mw-redirect" title="International Red Cross">International Red Cross</a> and inspections by neutral nations. However, conditions were terrible in Russia: starvation was common for prisoners and civilians alike; about 15–20% of the prisoners in Russia died, and in Central Powers imprisonment 8% of Russians.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup> In Germany, food was scarce, but only 5% died.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpeed1990_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpeed1990-360">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerguson1999Chapter_13_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerguson1999Chapter_13-361">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorton1992_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorton1992-362">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1stGazaBritishPrisoners00118v.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/1stGazaBritishPrisoners00118v.jpg/220px-1stGazaBritishPrisoners00118v.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/1stGazaBritishPrisoners00118v.jpg/330px-1stGazaBritishPrisoners00118v.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/1stGazaBritishPrisoners00118v.jpg/440px-1stGazaBritishPrisoners00118v.jpg 2x" data-file-width="958" data-file-height="674" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1stGazaBritishPrisoners00118v.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British prisoners guarded by Ottoman forces after the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Gaza" title="First Battle of Gaza">First Battle of Gaza</a> in 1917</div></div></div>
<p>The Ottoman Empire often treated POWs poorly.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBass2002107_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBass2002107-363">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup> Some 11,800 British Empire soldiers, most of them Indians, became prisoners after the Siege of Kut in Mesopotamia in April 1916; 4,250 died in captivity.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup> Although many were in a poor condition when captured, Ottoman officers forced them to march 1,100 kilometres (684&#160;mi) to Anatolia. A survivor said: "We were driven along like beasts; to drop out was to die."<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup> The survivors were then forced to build a railway through the <a href="/wiki/Taurus_Mountains" title="Taurus Mountains">Taurus Mountains</a>.
</p><p>In Russia, when the prisoners from the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Legion" class="mw-redirect" title="Czech Legion">Czech Legion</a> of the Austro-Hungarian army were released in 1917, they re-armed themselves and briefly became a military and diplomatic force during the Russian Civil War.
</p><p>While the Allied prisoners of the Central Powers were quickly sent home at the end of active hostilities, the same treatment was not granted to Central Power prisoners of the Allies and Russia, many of whom served as <a href="/wiki/Forced_labour" class="mw-redirect" title="Forced labour">forced labour</a>, e.g., in France until 1920. They were released only after many approaches by the Red Cross to the <a href="/wiki/Allied_Supreme_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="Allied Supreme Council">Allied Supreme Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup> German prisoners were still being held in Russia as late as 1924.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Military_attach.C3.A9s_and_war_correspondents"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_attachés_and_war_correspondents">Military attachés and war correspondents</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Military_attach%C3%A9s_and_war_correspondents_in_the_First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Military attachés and war correspondents in the First World War">Military attachés and war correspondents in the First World War</a></div>
<p>Military and civilian observers from every major power closely followed the course of the war. Many were able to report on events from a perspective somewhat akin to modern "<a href="/wiki/Embedded_journalism" title="Embedded journalism">embedded</a>" positions within the opposing land and naval forces.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Support_for_the_war">Support for the war</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Affiche-guerre_Femmes-au-travail.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Affiche-guerre_Femmes-au-travail.jpg/220px-Affiche-guerre_Femmes-au-travail.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="332" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Affiche-guerre_Femmes-au-travail.jpg/330px-Affiche-guerre_Femmes-au-travail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Affiche-guerre_Femmes-au-travail.jpg/440px-Affiche-guerre_Femmes-au-travail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="628" data-file-height="948" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Affiche-guerre_Femmes-au-travail.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Poster urging women to join the British war effort, published by the <a href="/wiki/Young_Women%27s_Christian_Association" class="mw-redirect" title="Young Women&#39;s Christian Association">Young Women's Christian Association</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the Balkans, <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_nationalism" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav nationalism">Yugoslav nationalists</a> such as the leader, <a href="/wiki/Ante_Trumbi%C4%87" title="Ante Trumbić">Ante Trumbić</a>, strongly supported the war, desiring the freedom of <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavs" title="Yugoslavs">Yugoslavs</a> from Austria-Hungary and other foreign powers and the creation of an independent Yugoslavia. The <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Committee" title="Yugoslav Committee">Yugoslav Committee</a>, led by Trumbić, was formed in Paris on 30 April 1915 but shortly moved its office to London.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts20051189_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts20051189-368">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup> In April 1918, the Rome Congress of Oppressed Nationalities met, including <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovak" class="mw-redirect" title="Czechoslovak">Czechoslovak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italians" title="Italians">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Polish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Transylvanian" class="mw-redirect" title="Transylvanian">Transylvanian</a>, and Yugoslav representatives who urged the Allies to support national <a href="/wiki/Self-determination" title="Self-determination">self-determination</a> for the peoples residing within Austria-Hungary.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-369">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Middle East, <a href="/wiki/Arab_nationalism" title="Arab nationalism">Arab nationalism</a> soared in Ottoman territories in response to the rise of Turkish nationalism during the war, with Arab nationalist leaders advocating the creation of a <a href="/wiki/Pan-Arabism" title="Pan-Arabism">pan-Arab</a> state. In 1916, the Arab Revolt began in Ottoman-controlled territories of the Middle East in an effort to achieve independence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005117_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005117-370">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In East Africa, <a href="/wiki/Iyasu_V" class="mw-redirect" title="Iyasu V">Iyasu V</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Empire" title="Ethiopian Empire">Ethiopia</a> was supporting the <a href="/wiki/Dervish_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Dervish state">Dervish state</a> who were at war with the British in the <a href="/wiki/Somaliland_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Somaliland Campaign">Somaliland Campaign</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> Von Syburg, the German envoy in <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, said, "now the time has come for Ethiopia to regain the coast of the Red Sea driving the Italians home, to restore the Empire to its ancient size." The Ethiopian Empire was on the verge of entering World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I on the side of the Central Powers before Iyasu's overthrow due to Allied pressure on the Ethiopian aristocracy.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> Iyasu was accused of converting to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup> According to Ethiopian historian <a href="/wiki/Bahru_Zewde" title="Bahru Zewde">Bahru Zewde</a>, the evidence used to prove Iyasu's conversion was a doctored photo of Iyasu wearing a turban provided by the Allies.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup> Some historians claim the British spy <a href="/wiki/T._E._Lawrence" title="T. E. Lawrence">T. E. Lawrence</a> forged the Iyasu photo.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of socialist parties initially supported the war when it began in August 1914.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_369-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-369">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup> But European socialists split on national lines, with the concept of <a href="/wiki/Class_conflict" title="Class conflict">class conflict</a> held by radical socialists such as Marxists and <a href="/wiki/Syndicalism" title="Syndicalism">syndicalists</a> being overborne by their patriotic support for the war.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts20051069_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts20051069-376">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup> Once the war began, Austrian, British, French, German, and Russian socialists followed the rising nationalist current by supporting their countries' intervention in the war.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005884_377-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005884-377">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Italian_nationalism" title="Italian nationalism">Italian nationalism</a> was stirred by the outbreak of the war and was initially strongly supported by a variety of political factions. One of the most prominent and popular Italian nationalist supporters of the war was <a href="/wiki/Gabriele_d%27Annunzio" class="mw-redirect" title="Gabriele d&#39;Annunzio">Gabriele d'Annunzio</a>, who promoted <a href="/wiki/Italian_irredentism" title="Italian irredentism">Italian irredentism</a> and helped sway the Italian public to support intervention in the war.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005335_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005335-378">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Liberal_Party" title="Italian Liberal Party">Italian Liberal Party</a>, under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Boselli" title="Paolo Boselli">Paolo Boselli</a>, promoted intervention in the war on the side of the Allies and used the Dante Alighieri Society to promote Italian nationalism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005219_379-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005219-379">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> Italian socialists were divided on whether to support the war or oppose it; some were militant supporters of the war, including <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonida_Bissolati" title="Leonida Bissolati">Leonida Bissolati</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005209_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005209-380">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Socialist_Party" title="Italian Socialist Party">Italian Socialist Party</a> decided to oppose the war after anti-militarist protestors were killed, resulting in a <a href="/wiki/General_strike" title="General strike">general strike</a> called <a href="/wiki/Red_Week_(Italy)" title="Red Week (Italy)">Red Week</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated6_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated6-381">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> The Italian Socialist Party purged itself of pro-war nationalist members, including Mussolini.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated6_381-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated6-381">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> Mussolini, a syndicalist who supported the war on grounds of irredentist claims on Italian-populated regions of Austria-Hungary, formed the pro-interventionist <i><a href="/wiki/Il_Popolo_d%27Italia" title="Il Popolo d&#39;Italia">Il Popolo d'Italia</a></i> and the <i>Fasci Rivoluzionario d'Azione Internazionalista</i> ("Revolutionary <a href="/wiki/Fasci" class="mw-redirect" title="Fasci">Fasci</a> for International Action") in October 1914 that later developed into the <i><a href="/wiki/Fasci_di_Combattimento" class="mw-redirect" title="Fasci di Combattimento">Fasci di Combattimento</a></i> in 1919, the origin of fascism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005826_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005826-382">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> Mussolini's nationalism enabled him to raise funds from <a href="/wiki/Italian_Ansaldo_company" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Ansaldo company">Ansaldo</a> (an armaments firm) and other companies to create <i>Il Popolo d'Italia</i> to convince socialists and revolutionaries to support the war.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Opposition_to_the_war">Opposition to the war</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_World_War_I" title="Opposition to World War I">Opposition to World War I</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_Army_Mutinies" class="mw-redirect" title="French Army Mutinies">French Army Mutinies</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sackville_Street_(Dublin)_after_the_1916_Easter_Rising.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Sackville_Street_%28Dublin%29_after_the_1916_Easter_Rising.JPG/220px-Sackville_Street_%28Dublin%29_after_the_1916_Easter_Rising.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Sackville_Street_%28Dublin%29_after_the_1916_Easter_Rising.JPG/330px-Sackville_Street_%28Dublin%29_after_the_1916_Easter_Rising.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Sackville_Street_%28Dublin%29_after_the_1916_Easter_Rising.JPG/440px-Sackville_Street_%28Dublin%29_after_the_1916_Easter_Rising.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2855" data-file-height="1841" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sackville_Street_(Dublin)_after_the_1916_Easter_Rising.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sackville Street (now <a href="/wiki/O%27Connell_Street" title="O&#39;Connell Street">O'Connell Street</a>) after the 1916 <a href="/wiki/Easter_Rising" title="Easter Rising">Easter Rising</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dublin" title="Dublin">Dublin</a></div></div></div>
<p>Once war was declared, many socialists and trade unions backed their governments. Among the exceptions were the Bolsheviks, the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_America" title="Socialist Party of America">Socialist Party of America</a>, the Italian Socialist Party, and people like <a href="/wiki/Karl_Liebknecht" title="Karl Liebknecht">Karl Liebknecht</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rosa_Luxemburg" title="Rosa Luxemburg">Rosa Luxemburg</a>, and their followers in Germany.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Benedict_XV" class="mw-redirect" title="Benedict XV">Benedict XV</a>, elected to the papacy less than three months into World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I, made the war and its consequences the main focus of his early pontificate. In stark contrast to his <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_X" title="Pope Pius X">predecessor</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> five days after his election he spoke of his determination to do what he could to bring peace. His first encyclical, <i><a href="/wiki/Ad_beatissimi_Apostolorum" title="Ad beatissimi Apostolorum">Ad beatissimi Apostolorum</a></i>, given 1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November 1914, was concerned with this subject. Benedict XV found his abilities and unique position as a religious emissary of peace ignored by the belligerent powers. The 1915 Treaty of London between Italy and the Triple Entente included secret provisions whereby the Allies agreed with Italy to ignore papal peace moves towards the Central Powers. Consequently, the publication of Benedict's proposed <a href="/wiki/World_War_I#15_August_1917:_peace_offer_by_the_Pope" title="World War I">seven-point Peace Note</a> of August 1917 was roundly ignored by all parties except Austria-Hungary.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Deserter.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/The_Deserter.jpg/220px-The_Deserter.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/The_Deserter.jpg/330px-The_Deserter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/The_Deserter.jpg/440px-The_Deserter.jpg 2x" data-file-width="581" data-file-height="383" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Deserter.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Deserter</i>, 1916: Anti-war cartoon depicting Jesus facing a <a href="/wiki/Firing_squad" class="mw-redirect" title="Firing squad">firing squad</a> with soldiers from five European countries</div></div></div>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">Britain</a> in 1914, the <a href="/wiki/Public_Schools_Act_1868" title="Public Schools Act 1868">Public Schools</a> <a href="/wiki/Officers%27_Training_Corps" title="Officers&#39; Training Corps">Officers' Training Corps</a> annual camp was held at Tidworth Pennings, near <a href="/wiki/Salisbury_Plain" title="Salisbury Plain">Salisbury Plain</a>. Head of the British Army, <a href="/wiki/Lord_Kitchener_of_Khartoum" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Kitchener of Khartoum">Lord Kitchener</a>, was to review the <a href="/wiki/Cadet" title="Cadet">cadets</a>, but the imminence of the war prevented him. General <a href="/wiki/Horace_Smith-Dorrien" title="Horace Smith-Dorrien">Horace Smith-Dorrien</a> was sent instead. He surprised the two-or-three thousand cadets by declaring (in the words of Donald Christopher Smith, a <a href="/wiki/Bermuda" title="Bermuda">Bermudian</a> cadet who was present),
</p>
<blockquote><p>that war should be avoided at almost any cost, that war would solve nothing, that the whole of Europe and more besides would be reduced to ruin, and that the loss of life would be so large that whole populations would be decimated. In our ignorance I, and many of us, felt almost ashamed of a British General who uttered such depressing and unpatriotic sentiments, but during the next four years, those of us who survived the holocaust—probably not more than one-quarter of us—learned how right the General's prognosis was and how courageous he had been to utter it.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Voicing these sentiments did not hinder Smith-Dorrien's career, or prevent him from doing his duty in World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I to the best of his abilities.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1917_-_Execution_%C3%A0_Verdun_lors_des_mutineries.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/1917_-_Execution_%C3%A0_Verdun_lors_des_mutineries.jpg/220px-1917_-_Execution_%C3%A0_Verdun_lors_des_mutineries.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/1917_-_Execution_%C3%A0_Verdun_lors_des_mutineries.jpg/330px-1917_-_Execution_%C3%A0_Verdun_lors_des_mutineries.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/1917_-_Execution_%C3%A0_Verdun_lors_des_mutineries.jpg/440px-1917_-_Execution_%C3%A0_Verdun_lors_des_mutineries.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1300" data-file-height="832" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1917_-_Execution_%C3%A0_Verdun_lors_des_mutineries.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Possible execution at <a href="/wiki/Verdun" title="Verdun">Verdun</a> at the time of the mutinies in 1917. The original French text accompanying this photograph notes, however, that the uniforms are those of 1914/15 and that the execution may be that of a spy at the beginning of the war.</div></div></div>
<p>Many countries jailed those who spoke out against the conflict. These included <a href="/wiki/Eugene_Debs" class="mw-redirect" title="Eugene Debs">Eugene Debs</a> in the United States and <a href="/wiki/Bertrand_Russell" title="Bertrand Russell">Bertrand Russell</a> in Britain. In the US, the <a href="/wiki/Espionage_Act_of_1917" title="Espionage Act of 1917">Espionage Act of 1917</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sedition_Act_of_1918" title="Sedition Act of 1918">Sedition Act of 1918</a> made it a federal crime to oppose military recruitment or make any statements deemed "disloyal". Publications at all critical of the government were removed from circulation by postal censors,<sup id="cite_ref-Karp-PoW-1979_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Karp-PoW-1979-198">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> and many served long prison sentences for statements of fact deemed unpatriotic.
</p><p>A number of nationalists opposed intervention, particularly within states that the nationalists were hostile to. Although the vast majority of Irish people consented to participate in the war in 1914 and 1915, a minority of advanced <a href="/wiki/Irish_nationalism" title="Irish nationalism">Irish nationalists</a> staunchly opposed taking part.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup> The war began amid the Home Rule crisis in Ireland that had resurfaced in 1912, and by July 1914 there was a serious possibility of an outbreak of civil war in Ireland. Irish nationalists and Marxists attempted to pursue Irish independence, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Easter_Rising" title="Easter Rising">Easter Rising</a> of 1916, with Germany sending 20,000 rifles to Ireland to stir unrest in Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005584_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005584-388">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup> The UK government placed Ireland under <a href="/wiki/Martial_law" title="Martial law">martial law</a> in response to the Easter Rising, though once the immediate threat of revolution had dissipated, the authorities did try to make concessions to nationalist feeling.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup> However, opposition to involvement in the war increased in Ireland, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1918" title="Conscription Crisis of 1918">Conscription Crisis of 1918</a>.
</p><p>Other opposition came from <a href="/wiki/Conscientious_objector" title="Conscientious objector">conscientious objectors</a>—some socialist, some religious—who refused to fight. In Britain, 16,000 people asked for conscientious objector status.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELehmannvan_der_Veer199962_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELehmannvan_der_Veer199962-390">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup> Some of them, most notably prominent peace activist <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Henry_Hobhouse" class="mw-redirect" title="Stephen Henry Hobhouse">Stephen Henry Hobhouse</a>, refused both military and <a href="/wiki/Alternative_service" class="mw-redirect" title="Alternative service">alternative service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup> Many suffered years of prison, including <a href="/wiki/Solitary_confinement" title="Solitary confinement">solitary confinement</a> and bread and water diets. Even after the war, in Britain many job advertisements were marked "No conscientious objectors need apply".<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Inline_citation#When_you_must_use_inline_citations" title="Wikipedia:Inline citation"><span title="The text near this tag needs a citation. (June 2017)">This quote needs a citation</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Lenin_Leon_Trotsky_Lev_Kamenev_1920.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vladimir_Lenin_Leon_Trotsky_Lev_Kamenev_1920.jpg/220px-Vladimir_Lenin_Leon_Trotsky_Lev_Kamenev_1920.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vladimir_Lenin_Leon_Trotsky_Lev_Kamenev_1920.jpg/330px-Vladimir_Lenin_Leon_Trotsky_Lev_Kamenev_1920.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vladimir_Lenin_Leon_Trotsky_Lev_Kamenev_1920.jpg/440px-Vladimir_Lenin_Leon_Trotsky_Lev_Kamenev_1920.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2221" data-file-height="1238" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Lenin_Leon_Trotsky_Lev_Kamenev_1920.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bolshevik leaders <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Lenin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Trotsky</a> promised “Peace, Land and Bread” to the impoverished masses</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Central_Asian_Revolt" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Asian Revolt">Central Asian Revolt</a> started in the summer of 1916, when the Russian Empire government ended its exemption of Muslims from military service.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1917, a series of French Army Mutinies led to dozens of soldiers being executed and many more imprisoned.
</p><p>On 1–4 May 1917, about 100,000 workers and soldiers of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Petrograd</a>, and after them, the workers and soldiers of other Russian cities, led by the Bolsheviks, demonstrated under banners reading "Down with the war!" and "all power to the soviets!" The mass demonstrations resulted in a crisis for the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">Russian Provisional Government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a>, in May 1917, Bolshevik revolutionaries organised and engaged in rioting calling for an end to the war, and managed to close down factories and stop public transportation.<sup id="cite_ref-Seton_6_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seton_6-394">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup> The Italian army was forced to enter Milan with tanks and machine guns to face Bolsheviks and <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">anarchists</a>, who fought violently until 23 May when the army gained control of the city. Almost 50 people (including three Italian soldiers) were killed and over 800 people arrested.<sup id="cite_ref-Seton_6_394-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seton_6-394">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 1917, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Expeditionary_Force_in_France" title="Russian Expeditionary Force in France">Russian soldiers in France</a> began questioning why they were fighting for the French at all and mutinied.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECockfield1997171–237_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECockfield1997171–237-395">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup> In Russia, opposition to the war led to soldiers also establishing their own revolutionary committees, which helped foment the <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution_of_1917" class="mw-redirect" title="October Revolution of 1917">October Revolution of 1917</a>, with the call going up for "bread, land, and peace". The <a href="/wiki/Decree_on_Peace" title="Decree on Peace">Decree on Peace</a>, written by Vladimir Lenin, was passed on 8<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November 1917, following the success of the October Revolution.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup> The Bolsheviks agreed to a peace treaty with Germany, the <a href="/wiki/Peace_of_Brest-Litovsk" class="mw-redirect" title="Peace of Brest-Litovsk">peace of Brest-Litovsk</a>, despite its harsh conditions. The <a href="/wiki/German_Revolution_of_1918-1919" class="mw-redirect" title="German Revolution of 1918-1919">German Revolution of 1918-1919</a> led to the abdication of the Kaiser and German surrender.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Conscription">Conscription</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Young_men_registering_for_military_conscription,_New_York_City,_June_5,_1917.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Young_men_registering_for_military_conscription%2C_New_York_City%2C_June_5%2C_1917.jpg/220px-Young_men_registering_for_military_conscription%2C_New_York_City%2C_June_5%2C_1917.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="174" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Young_men_registering_for_military_conscription%2C_New_York_City%2C_June_5%2C_1917.jpg/330px-Young_men_registering_for_military_conscription%2C_New_York_City%2C_June_5%2C_1917.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Young_men_registering_for_military_conscription%2C_New_York_City%2C_June_5%2C_1917.jpg/440px-Young_men_registering_for_military_conscription%2C_New_York_City%2C_June_5%2C_1917.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2700" data-file-height="2134" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Young_men_registering_for_military_conscription,_New_York_City,_June_5,_1917.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Young men registering for conscription, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, 5 June 1917</div></div></div>
<p>Conscription was common in most European countries. However, it was controversial in English-speaking countries. It was especially unpopular among minority ethnic groups—especially the Irish Catholics in Ireland and Australia,<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup> and the French Catholics in Canada.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Canada">Canada</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1917" title="Conscription Crisis of 1917">Conscription Crisis of 1917</a></div>
<p>In Canada the issue produced <a href="/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1917" title="Conscription Crisis of 1917">a major political crisis that permanently alienated the Francophones</a>. It opened a political gap between <a href="/wiki/French_Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="French Canadian">French Canadians</a>, who believed their true loyalty was to Canada and not to the British Empire, and members of the Anglophone majority, who saw the war as a duty to their British heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Australia">Australia</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Australia" title="Conscription in Australia">Conscription in Australia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg/220px-Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg/330px-Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg/440px-Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg 2x" data-file-width="639" data-file-height="459" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Melbourne_recruiting_WWI.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Military recruitment in <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>, 1914</div></div></div>
<p>Australia had a form of conscription at the outbreak of the war, as compulsory military training had been introduced in 1911. However, the <i>Defence Act 1903</i> provided that unexempted males could be called upon only for home defence during times of war, not overseas service. Prime Minister Billy Hughes wished to amend the legislation to require conscripts to serve overseas, and held two non-binding referendums – <a href="/wiki/1916_Australian_conscription_referendum" title="1916 Australian conscription referendum">one in 1916</a> and <a href="/wiki/1917_Australian_conscription_referendum" title="1917 Australian conscription referendum">one in 1917</a> – in order to secure public support.<sup id="cite_ref-parl_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parl-399">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup> Both were defeated by narrow margins, with farmers, the <a href="/wiki/Australian_labour_movement" title="Australian labour movement">labour movement</a>, the Catholic Church, and Irish-Australians combining to campaign for the "No" vote.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup> The issue of conscription caused the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party_split_of_1916" title="Australian Labor Party split of 1916">1916 Australian Labor Party split</a>. Hughes and his supporters were expelled from the party, forming the <a href="/wiki/National_Labor_Party" title="National Labor Party">National Labor Party</a> and then the <a href="/wiki/Nationalist_Party_(Australia)" title="Nationalist Party (Australia)">Nationalist Party</a>. Despite the referendum results, the Nationalists won a landslide victory at the <a href="/wiki/1917_Australian_federal_election" title="1917 Australian federal election">1917 federal election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-parl_399-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parl-399">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Britain">Britain</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Conscription in the United Kingdom">Conscription in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Recruitment_to_the_British_Army_during_the_First_World_War" title="Recruitment to the British Army during the First World War">Recruitment to the British Army during the First World War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/220px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/330px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/440px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1247" data-file-height="859" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British volunteer recruits in <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, August 1914</div></div></div>
<p>In Britain, conscription resulted in the calling up of nearly every physically fit man in Britain—six of ten million eligible. Of these, about 750,000 lost their lives. Most deaths were those of young unmarried men; however, 160,000 wives lost husbands and 300,000 children lost fathers.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHavighurst1985131_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHavighurst1985131-401">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup> Conscription during the First World War began when the British government passed the <a href="/wiki/Military_Service_Act_1916" title="Military Service Act 1916">Military Service Act</a> in 1916. The act specified that single men aged 18 to 40 years old were liable to be called up for military service unless they were widowed with children or ministers of a religion. There was a system of <a href="/wiki/Military_Service_Tribunals" title="Military Service Tribunals">Military Service Tribunals</a> to adjudicate upon claims for exemption upon the grounds of performing civilian work of national importance, domestic hardship, health, and conscientious objection. The law went through several changes before the war ended. Married men were exempt in the original Act, although this was changed in June 1916. The age limit was also eventually raised to 51 years old. Recognition of work of national importance also diminished, and in the last year of the war there was some support for the conscription of clergy.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> Conscription lasted until mid-1919. Due to the political situation in Ireland, conscription was never applied there; only in <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">United States</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States#World_War_I" title="Conscription in the United States">Conscription in the United States §&#160;World War I</a></div>
<p>In the United States, conscription began in 1917 and was generally well received, with a few pockets of opposition in isolated rural areas.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup> The administration decided to rely primarily on conscription, rather than voluntary enlistment, to raise military manpower for when only 73,000 volunteers enlisted out of the initial 1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million target in the first six weeks of the war.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup> In 1917 10 million men were registered. This was deemed to be inadequate, so age ranges were increased and exemptions reduced, and so by the end of 1918 this increased to 24 million men that were registered with nearly 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million inducted into the military services. The draft was universal and included blacks on the same terms as whites, although they served in different units. In all 367,710 black Americans were drafted (13% of the total), compared to 2,442,586 white (87%).
</p><p>Forms of resistance ranged from peaceful protest to violent demonstrations and from humble letter-writing campaigns asking for mercy to radical newspapers demanding reform. The most common tactics were dodging and desertion, and many communities sheltered and defended their draft dodgers as political heroes. Many socialists were jailed for "obstructing the recruitment or enlistment service". The most famous was Eugene Debs, head of the Socialist Party of America, who ran for president in 1920 from his prison cell. In 1917 a number of radicals and anarchists challenged the new draft law in federal court, arguing that it was a direct violation of the Thirteenth Amendment's prohibition against slavery and involuntary servitude. The Supreme Court unanimously upheld the constitutionality of the draft act in the <a href="/wiki/Selective_Draft_Law_Cases" title="Selective Draft Law Cases">Selective Draft Law Cases</a> on 7<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>January 1918.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</span></h3>
<p>Like all the armies of mainland Europe, Austria-Hungary relied on conscription to fill its ranks. Officer recruitment, however, was voluntary. The effect of this at the start of the war was that well over a quarter of the rank and file were Slavs, while more than 75% of the officers were ethnic Germans. This was much resented. The army has been described as being "run on colonial lines" and the Slav soldiers as "disaffected". Thus conscription contributed greatly to Austria's disastrous performance on the battlefield.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Diplomacy">Diplomacy</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_history_of_World_War_I" title="Diplomatic history of World War I">Diplomatic history of World War I</a></div>
<p>The non-military diplomatic and propaganda interactions among the nations were designed to build support for the cause, or to undermine support for the enemy. For the most part, wartime diplomacy focused on five issues: <a href="/wiki/Propaganda_in_World_War_I" title="Propaganda in World War I">propaganda campaigns</a>; defining and redefining the war goals, which became harsher as the war went on; luring neutral nations (Italy, Ottoman Empire, Bulgaria, Romania) into the coalition by offering slices of enemy territory; and encouragement by the Allies of nationalistic minority movements inside the Central Powers, especially among Czechs, Poles, and Arabs. In addition, there were multiple peace proposals coming from neutrals, or one side or the other; none of them progressed very far.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy_and_memory">Legacy and memory</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><div class="poem">
<p>...&#160;"Strange, friend," I said, "Here is no cause to mourn."<br />
"None," said the other, "Save the undone years"...&#160;
</p>
</div><div class="templatequotecite">—&#8201;<cite><a href="/wiki/Wilfred_Owen" title="Wilfred Owen">Wilfred Owen</a>, <i>Strange Meeting</i>, 1918<sup id="cite_ref-Wilfred_Owen_2004_306-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wilfred_Owen_2004-306">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup></cite></div>
</blockquote>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><div class="poem">
<p>The War was an unprecedented triumph for natural science. [<a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon" title="Francis Bacon">Francis</a>] Bacon had promised that knowledge would be power, and power it was: power to destroy the bodies and souls of men more rapidly than had ever been done by human agency before. This triumph paved the way to other triumphs: improvements in transport, in sanitation, in surgery, medicine, and psychiatry, in commerce and industry, and, above all, in preparations for the next war.
</p>
</div><div class="templatequotecite">—&#8201;<cite><a href="/wiki/R.G._Collingwood" class="mw-redirect" title="R.G. Collingwood">R.G. Collingwood</a>, writing in 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup></cite></div>
</blockquote>
<p>The first tentative efforts to comprehend the meaning and consequences of modern warfare began during the initial phases of the war, and this process continued throughout and after the end of hostilities, and is still underway, more than a century later.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historiography">Historiography</span></h3>
<p>Historian Heather Jones argues that the <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">historiography</a> has been reinvigorated by the cultural turn in recent years. Scholars have raised entirely new questions regarding military occupation, radicalisation of politics, race, and the male body. Furthermore, new research has revised our understanding of five major topics that historians have long debated: Why the war began, why the Allies won, whether generals were responsible for high casualty rates, how the soldiers endured the horrors of trench warfare, and to what extent the civilian homefront accepted and endorsed the war effort.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Memorials">Memorials</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_memorials" title="World War I memorials">World War I memorials</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pagny_le_Chateau_monument_morts_002b.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Pagny_le_Chateau_monument_morts_002b.jpg/220px-Pagny_le_Chateau_monument_morts_002b.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Pagny_le_Chateau_monument_morts_002b.jpg/330px-Pagny_le_Chateau_monument_morts_002b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Pagny_le_Chateau_monument_morts_002b.jpg/440px-Pagny_le_Chateau_monument_morts_002b.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="750" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pagny_le_Chateau_monument_morts_002b.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A typical village <a href="/wiki/War_memorial" title="War memorial">war memorial</a> to soldiers killed in World War I</div></div></div>
<p>Memorials were erected in thousands of villages and towns. Close to battlefields, those buried in improvised burial grounds were gradually moved to formal graveyards under the care of organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_War_Graves_Commission" title="Commonwealth War Graves Commission">Commonwealth War Graves Commission</a>, the <a href="/wiki/American_Battle_Monuments_Commission" title="American Battle Monuments Commission">American Battle Monuments Commission</a>, the <a href="/wiki/German_War_Graves_Commission" title="German War Graves Commission">German War Graves Commission</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Le_Souvenir_fran%C3%A7ais" title="Le Souvenir français">Le Souvenir français</a>. Many of these graveyards also have central monuments to the missing or <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier" title="Tomb of the Unknown Soldier">unidentified</a> dead, such as the <a href="/wiki/Menin_Gate" title="Menin Gate">Menin Gate</a> memorial and the <a href="/wiki/Thiepval_Memorial_to_the_Missing_of_the_Somme" class="mw-redirect" title="Thiepval Memorial to the Missing of the Somme">Thiepval Memorial to the Missing of the Somme</a>.
</p><p>In 1915 <a href="/wiki/John_McCrae" title="John McCrae">John McCrae</a>, a Canadian army doctor, wrote the poem <i><a href="/wiki/In_Flanders_Fields" title="In Flanders Fields">In Flanders Fields</a></i> as a salute to those who perished in the Great War. Published in <a href="/wiki/Punch_(magazine)" title="Punch (magazine)"><i>Punch</i></a> on 8<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>December 1915, it is still recited today, especially on <a href="/wiki/Armistice_Day" title="Armistice Day">Remembrance Day</a> and <a href="/wiki/Memorial_Day" title="Memorial Day">Memorial Day</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/National_World_War_I_Museum_and_Memorial" title="National World War I Museum and Memorial">National World War I Museum and Memorial</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kansas_City,_Missouri" title="Kansas City, Missouri">Kansas City, Missouri</a>, is a memorial dedicated to all Americans who served in World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I. The <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Memorial" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberty Memorial">Liberty Memorial</a> was dedicated on 1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>November 1921, when the supreme Allied commanders spoke to a crowd of more than 100,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-kclibrary.org_413-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kclibrary.org-413">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK Government has budgeted substantial resources to <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_centenary" class="mw-redirect" title="World War I centenary">the commemoration of the war during the period 2014 to 2018</a>. The lead body is the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_War_Museum" title="Imperial War Museum">Imperial War Museum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup> On 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>August 2014, French President <a href="/wiki/Francois_Hollande" class="mw-redirect" title="Francois Hollande">Francois Hollande</a> and German President <a href="/wiki/Joachim_Gauck" title="Joachim Gauck">Joachim Gauck</a> together marked <a href="/wiki/Centenary_of_the_outbreak_of_World_War_I" title="Centenary of the outbreak of World War I">the centenary of Germany's declaration of war on France</a> by laying the first stone of a memorial in Vieil Armand, known in German as <a href="/wiki/Hartmannswillerkopf" title="Hartmannswillerkopf">Hartmannswillerkopf</a>, for French and German soldiers killed in the war.<sup id="cite_ref-HartmannswillerkopfMemorial_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HartmannswillerkopfMemorial-415">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_memory">Cultural memory</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_in_popular_culture" title="World War I in popular culture">World War I in popular culture</a></div>
<table class="box-Globalize plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-globalize" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="Globe icon." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_globe_content.svg/48px-Ambox_globe_content.svg.png" decoding="async" width="48" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_globe_content.svg/73px-Ambox_globe_content.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_globe_content.svg/97px-Ambox_globe_content.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="290" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">The examples and perspective in this section <b>deal primarily with the United Kingdom and do not represent a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Countering_systemic_bias" title="Wikipedia:WikiProject Countering systemic bias">worldwide view</a> of the subject</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> You may <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit">improve this section</a>, discuss the issue on the <a href="/wiki/Talk:World_War_I" title="Talk:World War I">talk page</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Article_wizard" title="Wikipedia:Article wizard">create a new article</a>, as appropriate.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">June 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:left;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:308px;max-width:308px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:John_McCrae_in_uniform_circa_1914.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/John_McCrae_in_uniform_circa_1914.jpg/150px-John_McCrae_in_uniform_circa_1914.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="213" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/John_McCrae_in_uniform_circa_1914.jpg/225px-John_McCrae_in_uniform_circa_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/John_McCrae_in_uniform_circa_1914.jpg/300px-John_McCrae_in_uniform_circa_1914.jpg 2x" data-file-width="540" data-file-height="766" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Siegfried_Sassoon_by_George_Charles_Beresford_(1915).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Siegfried_Sassoon_by_George_Charles_Beresford_%281915%29.jpg/150px-Siegfried_Sassoon_by_George_Charles_Beresford_%281915%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="211" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Siegfried_Sassoon_by_George_Charles_Beresford_%281915%29.jpg/225px-Siegfried_Sassoon_by_George_Charles_Beresford_%281915%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Siegfried_Sassoon_by_George_Charles_Beresford_%281915%29.jpg/300px-Siegfried_Sassoon_by_George_Charles_Beresford_%281915%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="427" data-file-height="600" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:left;background-color:transparent">Left: <a href="/wiki/John_McCrae" title="John McCrae">John McCrae</a>, author of <i><a href="/wiki/In_Flanders_Fields" title="In Flanders Fields">In Flanders Fields</a></i><br />Right: <a href="/wiki/Siegfried_Sassoon" title="Siegfried Sassoon">Siegfried Sassoon</a></div></div></div></div>
<p>World War I had a lasting impact on <a href="/wiki/Social_memory" class="mw-redirect" title="Social memory">social memory</a>. It was seen by many in Britain as signalling the end of an era of stability stretching back to the <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian period</a>, and across Europe many regarded it as a watershed.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup> Historian <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Hynes" title="Samuel Hynes">Samuel Hynes</a> explained:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>A generation of innocent young men, their heads full of high abstractions like Honour, Glory and England, went off to war to make the world safe for democracy. They were slaughtered in stupid battles planned by stupid generals. Those who survived were shocked, disillusioned and embittered by their war experiences, and saw that their real enemies were not the Germans, but the old men at home who had lied to them. They rejected the values of the society that had sent them to war, and in doing so separated their own generation from the past and from their cultural inheritance.<sup id="cite_ref-Hynes1991_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hynes1991-417">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p>This has become the most common perception of World War I, perpetuated by the art, cinema, poems, and stories published subsequently. Films such as <i><a href="/wiki/All_Quiet_on_the_Western_Front_(1930_film)" title="All Quiet on the Western Front (1930 film)">All Quiet on the Western Front</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Paths_of_Glory" title="Paths of Glory">Paths of Glory</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/King_%26_Country" class="mw-redirect" title="King &amp; Country">King &amp; Country</a></i> have perpetuated the idea, while war-time films including <i>Camrades</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Poppies_of_Flanders" title="Poppies of Flanders">Poppies of Flanders</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Shoulder_Arms" title="Shoulder Arms">Shoulder Arms</a></i> indicate that the most contemporary views of the war were overall far more positive.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETodman2005153–221_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETodman2005153–221-418">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup> Likewise, the art of <a href="/wiki/Paul_Nash_(artist)" title="Paul Nash (artist)">Paul Nash</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Nash_(artist)" title="John Nash (artist)">John Nash</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Nevinson" class="mw-redirect" title="Christopher Nevinson">Christopher Nevinson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Tonks" title="Henry Tonks">Henry Tonks</a> in Britain painted a negative view of the conflict in keeping with the growing perception, while popular war-time artists such as <a href="/wiki/Muirhead_Bone" title="Muirhead Bone">Muirhead Bone</a> painted more serene and pleasant interpretations subsequently rejected as inaccurate.<sup id="cite_ref-Hynes1991_417-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hynes1991-417">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup> Several historians like <a href="/wiki/John_Terraine" title="John Terraine">John Terraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Niall_Ferguson" title="Niall Ferguson">Niall Ferguson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gary_Sheffield_(historian)" title="Gary Sheffield (historian)">Gary Sheffield</a> have challenged these interpretations as partial and <a href="/wiki/Polemic" title="Polemic">polemical</a> views:
</p>
<blockquote><p>These beliefs did not become widely shared because they offered the only accurate interpretation of wartime events. In every respect, the war was much more complicated than they suggest. In recent years, historians have argued persuasively against almost every popular cliché of World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I. It has been pointed out that, although the losses were devastating, their greatest impact was socially and geographically limited. The many emotions other than horror experienced by soldiers in and out of the front line, including comradeship, boredom, and even enjoyment, have been recognised. The war is not now seen as a 'fight about nothing', but as a war of ideals, a struggle between aggressive militarism and more or less liberal democracy. It has been acknowledged that British generals were often capable men facing difficult challenges, and that it was under their command that the British army played a major part in the defeat of the Germans in 1918: a great forgotten victory.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETodman2005153–221_418-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETodman2005153–221-418">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Though these views have been discounted as "myths",<sup id="cite_ref-Hynes1991_417-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hynes1991-417">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fussell2000_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fussell2000-419">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup> they are common. They have dynamically changed according to contemporary influences, reflecting in the 1950s perceptions of the war as "aimless" following the contrasting Second World War and emphasising conflict within the ranks during times of class conflict in the 1960s. The majority of additions to the contrary are often rejected.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETodman2005153–221_418-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETodman2005153–221-418">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_trauma">Social trauma</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cover-of-book-for-WWI-veterans-by-William-Brown-Meloney-born-1878.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Cover-of-book-for-WWI-veterans-by-William-Brown-Meloney-born-1878.jpg/170px-Cover-of-book-for-WWI-veterans-by-William-Brown-Meloney-born-1878.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="271" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Cover-of-book-for-WWI-veterans-by-William-Brown-Meloney-born-1878.jpg/255px-Cover-of-book-for-WWI-veterans-by-William-Brown-Meloney-born-1878.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Cover-of-book-for-WWI-veterans-by-William-Brown-Meloney-born-1878.jpg/340px-Cover-of-book-for-WWI-veterans-by-William-Brown-Meloney-born-1878.jpg 2x" data-file-width="689" data-file-height="1100" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cover-of-book-for-WWI-veterans-by-William-Brown-Meloney-born-1878.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 1919 book for veterans, from the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_War" title="United States Department of War">US War Department</a></div></div></div>
<p>The social trauma caused by unprecedented rates of casualties manifested itself in different ways, which have been the subject of subsequent historical debate.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETodman2005xi–xv_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETodman2005xi–xv-420">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Optimism" title="Optimism">optimism</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque" title="Belle Époque">la belle époque</a></i> was destroyed, and those who had fought in the war were referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Lost_Generation" title="Lost Generation">Lost Generation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoden_421-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoden-421">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup> For years afterwards, people mourned the dead, the missing, and the many disabled.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWohl1979_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWohl1979-422">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup> Many soldiers returned with severe trauma, suffering from <a href="/wiki/Combat_stress_reaction" title="Combat stress reaction">shell shock</a> (also called neurasthenia, a condition related to <a href="/wiki/Posttraumatic_stress_disorder" title="Posttraumatic stress disorder">posttraumatic stress disorder</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005108–1086_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuckerRoberts2005108–1086-423">&#91;414&#93;</a></sup> Many more returned home with few after-effects; however, their silence about the war contributed to the conflict's growing mythological status. Though many participants did not share in the experiences of combat or spend any significant time at the front, or had positive memories of their service, the images of suffering and trauma became the widely shared perception. Such historians as Dan Todman, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Fussell" title="Paul Fussell">Paul Fussell</a>, and Samuel Heyns have all published works since the 1990s arguing that these common perceptions of the war are factually incorrect.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETodman2005xi–xv_420-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETodman2005xi–xv-420">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Discontent_in_Germany">Discontent in Germany</span></h3>
<p>The rise of <a href="/wiki/Nazism" title="Nazism">Nazism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">Fascism</a> included a revival of the nationalist spirit and a rejection of many post-war changes. Similarly, the popularity of the stab-in-the-back legend (German: <i>Dolchstoßlegende</i>) was a testament to the psychological state of defeated Germany and was a rejection of responsibility for the conflict. This conspiracy theory of betrayal became common, and the German populace came to see themselves as victims.
