The widespread acceptance of the "stab-in-the-back" theory delegitimised the Weimar government and destabilised the system, opening it to extremes of right and left.
</p><p>Communist and fascist movements around Europe drew strength from this theory and enjoyed a new level of popularity. These feelings were most pronounced in areas directly or harshly affected by the war. <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> was able to gain popularity by using German discontent with the still controversial Treaty of Versailles.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup> World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>II was in part a continuation of the power struggle never fully resolved by World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I. Furthermore, it was common for Germans in the 1930s to justify acts of aggression due to perceived injustices imposed by the victors of World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">&#91;417&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChickering2004_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChickering2004-427">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup> American historian <a href="/wiki/William_Rubinstein" title="William Rubinstein">William Rubinstein</a> wrote that:
</p>
<blockquote><p>The 'Age of Totalitarianism' included nearly all the infamous examples of genocide in modern history, headed by the Jewish Holocaust, but also comprising the mass murders and purges of the Communist world, other mass killings carried out by Nazi Germany and its allies, and also the Armenian Genocide of 1915. All these slaughters, it is argued here, had a common origin, the collapse of the elite structure and normal modes of government of much of central, eastern and southern Europe as a result of World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I, without which surely neither Communism nor Fascism would have existed except in the minds of unknown agitators and crackpots.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_effects">Economic effects</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_World_War_I" title="Economic history of World War I">Economic history of World War I</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Girl_Behind_the_Gun_1915.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/The_Girl_Behind_the_Gun_1915.jpg/220px-The_Girl_Behind_the_Gun_1915.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="327" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/The_Girl_Behind_the_Gun_1915.jpg/330px-The_Girl_Behind_the_Gun_1915.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/The_Girl_Behind_the_Gun_1915.jpg/440px-The_Girl_Behind_the_Gun_1915.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2332" data-file-height="3463" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Girl_Behind_the_Gun_1915.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Poster showing women workers, 1915</div></div></div>
<p>One of the most dramatic effects of the war was the expansion of governmental powers and responsibilities in Britain, France, the United States, and the Dominions of the British Empire. To harness all the power of their societies, governments created new ministries and powers. New taxes were levied and laws enacted, all designed to bolster the <a href="/wiki/War_effort" title="War effort">war effort</a>; many have lasted to this day. Similarly, the war strained the abilities of some formerly large and bureaucratised governments, such as in Austria-Hungary and Germany.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">Gross domestic product</a> (GDP) increased for three Allies (Britain, Italy, and the United States), but decreased in France and Russia, in neutral Netherlands, and in the three main Central Powers. The shrinkage in GDP in Austria, Russia, France, and the Ottoman Empire ranged between 30% and 40%. In Austria, for example, most pigs were slaughtered, so at war's end there was no meat.
</p><p>In all nations, the government's share of GDP increased, surpassing 50% in both Germany and France and nearly reaching that level in Britain. To pay for purchases in the United States, Britain cashed in its extensive investments in American railroads and then began borrowing heavily from <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>. President Wilson was on the verge of cutting off the loans in late 1916, but allowed a great increase in <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">US government</a> lending to the Allies. After 1919, the US demanded repayment of these loans. The repayments were, in part, funded by German reparations that, in turn, were supported by American loans to Germany. This circular system collapsed in 1931 and some loans were never repaid. Britain still owed the United States $4.4 <a href="/wiki/1,000,000,000" title="1,000,000,000">billion</a><sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">&#91;420&#93;</a></sup> of World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I debt in 1934, the last instalment was finally paid in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">&#91;421&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Macro- and micro-economic consequences devolved from the war. Families were altered by the departure of many men. With the death or absence of the primary wage earner, women were forced into the workforce in unprecedented numbers. At the same time, industry needed to replace the lost labourers sent to war. This aided the struggle for <a href="/wiki/Suffragette" title="Suffragette">voting rights for women</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">&#91;422&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>World War I further compounded the gender imbalance, adding to the phenomenon of <a href="/wiki/Surplus_women" title="Surplus women">surplus women</a>. The deaths of nearly one million men during the war in Britain increased the gender gap by almost a million: from 670,000 to 1,700,000. The number of unmarried women seeking economic means grew dramatically. In addition, demobilisation and economic decline following the war caused high unemployment. The war increased female employment; however, the return of demobilised men displaced many from the workforce, as did the closure of many of the wartime factories.
</p><p>In Britain, rationing was finally imposed in early 1918, limited to meat, sugar, and fats (butter and margarine), but not bread. The new system worked smoothly. From 1914 to 1918, trade union membership doubled, from a little over four million to a little over eight million.
</p><p>Britain turned to her colonies for help in obtaining essential war materials whose supply from traditional sources had become difficult. Geologists such as <a href="/wiki/Albert_Ernest_Kitson" class="mw-redirect" title="Albert Ernest Kitson">Albert Ernest Kitson</a> were called on to find new resources of precious minerals in the African colonies. Kitson discovered important new deposits of <a href="/wiki/Manganese" title="Manganese">manganese</a>, used in munitions production, in the <a href="/wiki/Gold_Coast_(region)" title="Gold Coast (region)">Gold Coast</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreen1938cxxvi_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreen1938cxxvi-432">&#91;423&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Article 231 of the Treaty of Versailles (the so-called "war guilt" clause) stated Germany accepted responsibility for "all the loss and damage to which the Allied and Associated Governments and their nationals have been subjected as a consequence of the war imposed upon them by the aggression of Germany and her allies."<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">&#91;424&#93;</a></sup> It was worded as such to lay a legal basis for reparations, and a similar clause was inserted in the treaties with Austria and Hungary. However neither of them interpreted it as an admission of war guilt."<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">&#91;425&#93;</a></sup> In 1921, the total reparation sum was placed at 132&#160;billion gold marks. However, "Allied experts knew that Germany could not pay" this sum. The total sum was divided into three categories, with the third being "deliberately designed to be chimerical" and its "primary function was to mislead public opinion&#160;... into believing the "total sum was being maintained."<sup id="cite_ref-Marks237_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marks237-435">&#91;426&#93;</a></sup> Thus, 50&#160;billion gold marks (12.5&#160;billion dollars) "represented the actual Allied assessment of German capacity to pay" and "therefore&#160;... represented the total German reparations" figure that had to be paid.<sup id="cite_ref-Marks237_435-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marks237-435">&#91;426&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>This figure could be paid in cash or in kind (coal, timber, chemical dyes, etc.). In addition, some of the territory lost—via the treaty of Versailles—was credited towards the reparation figure as were other acts such as helping to restore the Library of Louvain.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">&#91;427&#93;</a></sup> By 1929, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> arrived, causing political chaos throughout the world.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">&#91;428&#93;</a></sup> In 1932 the payment of reparations was suspended by the international community, by which point Germany had paid only the equivalent of 20.598 billion gold marks in reparations.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">&#91;429&#93;</a></sup> With the rise of Adolf Hitler, all bonds and loans that had been issued and taken out during the 1920s and early 1930s were cancelled. <a href="/wiki/David_A._Andelman" title="David A. Andelman">David Andelman</a> notes "refusing to pay doesn't make an agreement null and void. The bonds, the agreement, still exist." Thus, following the Second World War, at the <a href="/wiki/Agreement_on_German_External_Debts" class="mw-redirect" title="Agreement on German External Debts">London Conference</a> in 1953, Germany agreed to resume payment on the money borrowed. On 3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>October 2010, Germany made the final payment on these bonds.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">&#91;j&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The war contributed to the evolution of the <a href="/wiki/Wristwatch" class="mw-redirect" title="Wristwatch">wristwatch</a> from women's jewellery to a practical everyday item, replacing the <a href="/wiki/Pocketwatch" class="mw-redirect" title="Pocketwatch">pocketwatch</a>, which requires a free hand to operate.<sup id="cite_ref-npr_444-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr-444">&#91;434&#93;</a></sup> Military funding of advancements in radio contributed to the postwar popularity of the medium.<sup id="cite_ref-npr_444-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr-444">&#91;434&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

<ul style="display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Footnotes">Footnotes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The United States did not ratify any of the treaties agreed to at the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919" title="Paris Peace Conference, 1919">Paris Peace Conference</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bulgaria joined the Central Powers on 14 October 1915.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Ottoman Empire agreed to a secret alliance with Germany on 2 August 1914. It joined the war on the side of the Central Powers on 29 October 1914.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The United States <a href="/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_I#Austria-Hungary" title="American entry into World War I">declared war on Austria-Hungary</a> on 7<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>December 1917.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/First_Republic_of_Austria" class="mw-redirect" title="First Republic of Austria">Austria</a> was considered one of the <a href="/wiki/Successor_states" class="mw-redirect" title="Successor states">successor states</a> to Austria-Hungary.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The United States <a href="/wiki/United_States_declaration_of_war_on_Germany_(1917)" title="United States declaration of war on Germany (1917)">declared war on Germany</a> on 6<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>April 1917.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_(1920%E2%80%9346)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)">Hungary</a> was considered one of the successor states to Austria-Hungary.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">Treaty of Sèvres</a> was intended to end the war between the Allied Powers and the Ottoman Empire, the Allied Powers and the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Turkey">Republic of Turkey</a>, the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, agreed to the Treaty of Lausanne.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-327"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-327">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A German attempt to use chemical weapons on the Russian front in January 1915 failed to cause casualties.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-443"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-443">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">World War I officially ended when Germany paid off the final amount of reparations imposed on it by the Allies.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">&#91;431&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">&#91;432&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">&#91;433&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>

<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.loc.gov/law/help/digitized-books/world-war-i-declarations/ww1-gazettes/France-doc-3-OCR-SPLIT.pdf">"Le Président de la République, R. &#91;Raymond&#93; Poincaré et al., 'A La Nation Française<span class="cs1-kern-right">'</span>"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Journal Officiel de la République Française</i>: 7053–7054. 2 August 1914<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHull2006307–310-222"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHull2006307–310_222-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHull2006">Hull 2006</a>, pp.&#160;307–310.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383-223"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383_223-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStevenson2004383_223-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFStevenson2004">Stevenson 2004</a>, p.&#160;383.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPainter201225-224"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPainter201225_224-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPainter2012">Painter 2012</a>, p.&#160;25. Over the course of the war the United States supplied more than 80&#160;percent of Allied oil requirements, and after US entry into the war, the United States helped provide and protect tankers transporting oil to Europe. US oil resources meant that insufficient energy supplies did not hamper the Allies, as they did the Central Powers.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-225"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-225">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">K. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMagliveras19998–12-245"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMagliveras19998–12_245-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMagliveras1999">Magliveras 1999</a>, pp.&#160;8–12.</span>

<li id="cite_note-324"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-324">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Cox, Mary Elisabeth (21 September 2014). "Hunger games: or how the Allied blockade in the First World War deprived German children of nutrition, and Allied food aid subsequently saved them. Abstract". <i>The Economic History Review</i>. <b>68</b> (2): 600–631. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1111%2Fehr.12070">10.1111/ehr.12070</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0013-0117">0013-0117</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economic+History+Review&amp;rft.atitle=Hunger+games%3A+or+how+the+Allied+blockade+in+the+First+World+War+deprived+German+children+of+nutrition%2C+and+Allied+food+aid+subsequently+saved+them.+Abstract.&amp;rft.volume=68&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=600-631&amp;rft.date=2014-09-21&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1111%2Fehr.12070&amp;rft.issn=0013-0117&amp;rft.aulast=Cox&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary+Elisabeth&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-326"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-326">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Devlin, Patrick (1975). <i>Too Proud to Fight: Woodrow Wilson's Neutrality</i>. New York: Oxford University Press. pp.&#160;193–195.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Too+Proud+to+Fight%3A+Woodrow+Wilson%27s+Neutrality&amp;rft.pages=193-195&amp;rft.pub=New+York%3A+Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1975&amp;rft.aulast=Devlin&amp;rft.aufirst=Patrick&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-AJPH-328"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-AJPH_328-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-AJPH_328-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-AJPH_328-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-AJPH_328-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Fitzgerald, Gerard (April 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2376985/">"Chemical Warfare and Medical Response During World War I"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/American_Journal_of_Public_Health" title="American Journal of Public Health">American Journal of Public Health</a></i>. <b>98</b> (4). <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.2105%2FAJPH.2007.11930">10.2105/AJPH.2007.11930</a>. <q>In the late afternoon of April 22, 1915, members of a special unit of the German Army opened the valves on more than 6000 steel cylinders arrayed in trenches along their defensive perimeter at Ypres, Belgium. Within 10 minutes, 160 tons of chlorine gas drifted over the opposing French trenches, engulfing all those downwind.&#160;... The attack that spring day, nonetheless, marked a turning point in military history, as it is recognized as the first successful use of lethal chemical weapons on the battlefield.&#160;... Although chemical weapons killed proportionally few soldiers in World War<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I (1914–1918), the psychological damage from 'gas fright' and the exposure of large numbers of soldiers, munitions workers, and civilians to chemical agents had significant public health consequences.&#160;... By the time of the armistice on November 11, 1918, the use of chemical weapons such as chlorine, phosgene, and mustard gas had resulted in more than 1.3 million casualties and approximately 90 000 deaths.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=American+Journal+of+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Chemical+Warfare+and+Medical+Response+During+World+War+I&amp;rft.volume=98&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.date=2008-04&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2105%2FAJPH.2007.11930&amp;rft.aulast=Fitzgerald&amp;rft.aufirst=Gerard&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC2376985%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-329"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-329">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Schneider, Barry R. (28 February 1999). Future War and Counterproliferation: US Military Responses to NBC. Praeger, p. 84; <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-275-96278-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-275-96278-4">0-275-96278-4</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-330"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-330">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Taylor, Telford (1993). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/anatomyofnuremb00tayl/page/34"><i>The Anatomy of the Nuremberg Trials: A Personal Memoir</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Little,_Brown_and_Company" title="Little, Brown and Company">Little, Brown and Company</a>. p.&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/anatomyofnuremb00tayl/page/34">34</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-316-83400-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-316-83400-1"><bdi>978-0-316-83400-1</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 June</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Anatomy+of+the+Nuremberg+Trials%3A+A+Personal+Memoir&amp;rft.pages=34&amp;rft.pub=Little%2C+Brown+and+Company&amp;rft.date=1993&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-316-83400-1&amp;rft.aulast=Taylor&amp;rft.aufirst=Telford&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fanatomyofnuremb00tayl%2Fpage%2F34&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-331"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-331">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Graham, Thomas; Lavera, Damien J. <li id="cite_note-349"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-349">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFMawdsley2007" class="citation book">Mawdsley, Evan (2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QnwRMQAACAAJ"><i>The Russian Civil War</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-433"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-433">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Anton Kaes; Martin Jay; Edward Dimendberg, eds. Harper Collins Publishers. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-06-270056-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-06-270056-8"><bdi>978-0-06-270056-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Harper%27s+Encyclopedia+of+Military+History%2C+4th+Edition&amp;rft.pub=Harper+Collins+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1993&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-06-270056-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dupuy&amp;rft.aufirst=R.+Ernest+and+Trevor+N.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fharperencycloped0000dupu&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></li>
<li><i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i> (12th ed. 1922) comprises the 11th edition plus three new volumes 30-31-32 that cover events since 1911 with thorough coverage of the war as well as every country and colony. <a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/1922_Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" class="extiw" title="s:1922 Encyclopædia Britannica">partly online and list of article titles</a>

New York: Dorling Kindersley. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7894-9627-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7894-9627-0"><bdi>978-0-7894-9627-0</bdi></a>. <a href="/wiki/OCLC" title="OCLC">OCLC</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/52541937">52541937</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=World+War+I&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Dorling+Kindersley&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F52541937&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7894-9627-0&amp;rft.aulast=Willmott&amp;rft.aufirst=H.P.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></li>

The past and future of a right-wing myth". <i>Harper's Magazine</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Harper%27s+Magazine&amp;rft.atitle=Stabbed+in+the+Back%21+The+past+and+future+of+a+right-wing+myth&amp;rft.date=2006-06&amp;rft.aulast=Baker&amp;rft.aufirst=Kevin&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AWorld+War+I" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></li>

<li>Trout, Stephen. <i>"On the Battlefield of Memory: The First World War and American Remembrance, 1919–1941</i> (2013)</li>

            </li><li style="min-height: 31px;"><span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikibooks-logo.svg/27px-Wikibooks-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="27" height="27" style="vertical-align: middle" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikibooks-logo.svg/41px-Wikibooks-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikibooks-logo.svg/54px-Wikibooks-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300" /></span><span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;"><a href="https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Special:Search/World_War_I" class="extiw" title="b:Special:Search/World War I">Textbooks</a> from Wikibooks</span>
            </li><li style="min-height: 31px;"><span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/27px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png" decoding="async" width="27" height="27" style="vertical-align: middle" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/41px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/54px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="193" data-file-height="193" /></span><span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;"><a href="https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/World_War_I#Q361" class="extiw" title="voy:World War I">Travel guide</a> from Wikivoyage</span>
            </li><li style="min-height: 31px;"><span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Wikiversity-logo-en.svg/27px-Wikiversity-logo-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="27" height="24" style="vertical-align: middle" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Wikiversity-logo-en.svg/41px-Wikiversity-logo-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Wikiversity-logo-en.svg/54px-Wikiversity-logo-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="900" /></span><span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;"><a href="https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/Special:Search/World_War_I" class="extiw" title="v:Special:Search/World War I">Resources</a> from Wikiversity</span>
            </li></ul>
</div>
